review_body: Hotel is situated in the heart of Ikebukuro. The building is big but very old. The shopping mall just downstairs which I like. However the wall is really thin which I can’t believe, you’ll feel no privacy as you can hear the next door the people talking. The service staffs is hospitality and they provide shuttle bus to airport. Compare the price and room, I would choose other new hotel to stay.

Stayed in this hotel with a group. Hotel is nice. Staff is helpful and gave us 15 rooms on the same floor which is commendable. The hotel is in close proximity to the all the market places, pubs and cafes. The rooms are small and bathroom is also very small. In fact on the entire floor they had the same room size. The breakfast spread was elaborate. Hotel is attached to the mall which was a plus point. Overall a decent place however prices are on the higher side.

The location of this hotel is good. Many shops and dining options. 5 mins from Higashi-ikebukuro station but almost 17 mins to JR Ikebukuro station. Check in time is early at 2 pm but so is check out time at 11am. Lifts to rooms are slow and always packed in the mornings. Service at breakfast is lacking but at check in and out, service is good. Breakfast is nothing to rave about. Better to eat out.The rooms are very small. Feels like a cabin on board a cruise boat. Bathroom seems prefabricated. My biggest grouse is the temperature. There are no windows and there is no air con during winter. Airflow is bad. Central heating is too hot and stuffy. Most uncomfortable. Read many complaints on this but nothing has been done. Not staying again.

The experience was good. Spent 4 nights there.Got lost a couple of times in the hotel and had trouble figuring out how the elevator works because some of the lifts only go to certain floors. The staff was so polite and respectful. The food was ok! Close to a shopping mall which was plus points.

My family of four stayed at the Sunshine City Prince Hotel on 12/4/2019-12/12/2019. This was the second time we’ve stayed at the Sunshine Prince. Check-in was quick and easy without any issues. Our 2 rooms this year were for the City Floor Twin Room B configuration on the24th floor. We had the twin Type C configuration last year. The additional cost for the B configuration was well worth it. Room B is a traditional side by side bed configuration while Room C is an end to end bed configuration. Room B is also about 50 square feet larger. The beds were firm and 2 pillows were provided per bed. Both pillows were very flat and my wife and I ended up having to use our travel pillows in order to provide adequate support. The rooms had a small desk, a small refrigerator, a small open closet area (in one of the 2 rooms), and a safe. The TV was approximately 32” with just one station that broadcasted in English (NHK). The bathroom had a small counter and a combo shower/tub. Water pressure was very good as was the water temperature. Climate control for the room was not good. There was no way to turn on the AC and there was no ventilation in the rooms so the rooms were constantly warm and stuffy (~75 degrees). Wi-Fi was excellent; we were always able to connect to the internet and we did not experience any dropped connections while we were there. Housekeeping was excellent as was the hotel staff (very friendly and they speak English). Despite our issues with the pillows and climate control, the location of the Prince still makes it an ideal hotel to consider. It’s proximity to the Sunshine Mall (convenience store, restaurants, souvenir stores), the Sunshine Strip (stores, eating establishments, game arcades), and closeness of the subway stations can’t be beat. The Airport Limousine also drops off and picks up directly from the hotel. I highly recommend the Sunshine City Prince Hotel and look forward to staying there again in my future visits to Tokyo.

review_body: We can hear the conversation from the other room. Security is not so adequate. It’s a few hundred meters from the central area so that’s a plus. There were no CCTV anywhere. Breakfast was just ok. When we checked in, pardon the picture but it said semi-double which I didn’t understand. They wanted 2 adults to fit in one bed. The staff were inconsistent. Some were helpful others were dismissive. I will not go back to this hotel.

In regards to my wife being molested in this hotel premises on 27 Dec 2019 by a guest, because there was no surveillance camera at that specific area, her case was not pursued further by local police which angers me. If this is the case of her being killed , injured or harmed in any sense. Would the local authorities still have said the same thing! it makes me wonder how safe it will be to stay in this hotel for the visitors coming next year for the upcoming Tokyo 2020 Olympics. This hotel will really have to tighten their security seriously. It could happen to anyone including your loved ones. LOW CRIME DOESN'T MEAN NO CRIME.

We stayed in this hotel for 3 nights. With 3 adults, we have booked their special rooms that fit us all. They offered us a room with 3 comfortable beds on the upper floor. In terms of Tokyo hotel, it is roomy. We were able to open our bags without any problem. Bathroom is clean and not small with good water pressure. We didn't find any problem on elevator as we used the special one for upper floor. To avoid pulling lugagge, suggest you to take airport limousine bus that stop right in front of the hotel. Lots of restaurants and shopping areas nearby. In case of snow, you can just stay at the sunshine city and can spend the day. We haven't got the breakfast package but tried once with average comment. Otherwise, eat outside is not a problem. Wonder why they got only 3.5 stars. Should be 4 points.

Despite of winter time with less than 10 degree celcius outside, but the hotel room is hot around 24+ degree. I call the front desk, but the staff unable to do anything.Be prepared if you don’t like sleep in hot air

The hotel is good. Missing good AC in the room. The breakfast is great. The service is fine. For Tokyo fair price. Shopping center is near by, hoeever far from the Shibuya cross. WiFi is free and fast .

This hotel is relatively close to 3 stations (Ikebukuro station (~12 minutes), Higashi-Ikebukuro (~7 minutes) and Ōtsuka station (~12 minutes)) making it easy to go around Tokyo. Most locations I wanted to visit I could reach in 30~45 minutes. The hotel has it own convenience store and is adjunct to a shopping mall.The room is relatively spacey compared to other Japanese hotels, although the bath room can be a little cramped if your a lot longer then 180 cm.The worst part is potentially the number of lifts relative to the number of rooms/floors.

Myself and my wife stayed here as part of the England Rugby tour. Rooms are on the small side and very dark - small window. Breakfast was OK but not fantastic. There is no bar as such but you can buy a drink in one of the restaurants, but this closes at 9:30pm. The shopping centre is great to have a wander through, we saw a girl band performing. Staff very friendly and spoke a good level of English. The area the hotel is in, Ikebukuro is great for walking round, try to find bar street to drink with the locals and it is on the circular line so it is easy to get around. Not an unpleasant stay.

1. Check in took an hour. There was a line but it shouldn’t have taken that long. I’ve stayed at 5 star hotels to boutique hotels and never had this type of check in experience before. Any request or question you have is a bureaucratic and lengthy process. No one is empowered to do anything without going up a long chain of command. 2. If you’re a foreigner visiting, be aware that they charge per guest, not per room. My reservation was under my name and was a big room that was designed for 2-3 people. When my spouse and I arrived, I was surprised to learn that there would be extra charges attached because he would be in the room even though none of the amenities had changed. This also happened to two businessmen who were checking in next to me. They booked a room with two beds and were surprised to learn that there would be more charges attached. Be aware that some Japanese hotels will do this. If this bothers you, like it did for me, consider looking into hotels that are part of a more upscale global chain. Mathematically, you should check to see what the difference is — if those hotels charge per room and the locals ones like Prince, charge per guest, you might as well stay at a 4 star hotel if the price discrepancy is nominal. 3. The bathroom is atrocious. It looks like a a plastic box they just added on. It feels like you are showering and using a toilet in a trailer versus a hotel. Very low ceilings. I saw 3 different rooms and they were all the same. Toilet in the rooms have low water pressure (although the shower pressure was strong). 4. While the hotel claims to have nonsmoking rooms, we had to change rooms twice because it stunk so badly. 5. Pillows/Towels/amenities - The pillows were incredibly flat and uncomfortable. No body lotion and no bar soap. Expect the bare, bare, bare minimum. Towel count was low. 6. Location - very convenient that there’s a Family Mart convenience store inside and there is a mall attached to the hotel (food not good but the shops had some solid tourist goods). Harakuju, Shinjuku, Shinbuya are at least a 20 mins taxi ride with no traffic. Train stop is about half a mile away and is also a 20-30 min ride to these areas.7. Breakfast Buffet - it’s not great. Not atrocious but not something you would ever want to pay for out of pocket. We ended up trying to find other places to eat at. In short, if you are looking for a no frills hotel where you can just lay your head at night to rest and the location is close to where you have to be, it’s just fine. The staff is generally polite, some definitely more polite than others. I thought Mr. Kim was wonderful (he is the reason why I’m bumping it up from 2 star to 3) and there’s another woman who spoke English who was helpful. But come with a translator (human or electronic) because it will be easier to communicate. Most of the staff don’t speak English (which I don’t fault them for since it’s Japan but being that it was a hotel, it would have been less frustrating if there was more on staff who could). If you are looking for a place in a trendy, bustling area where it is more of a luxury or comfortable hotel experience, avoid. Japan is a lovely country but next time I plan on spending more and booking at a chain hotel. It’s worth it. Everyone is different but personally, I like being very comfortable when I’m traveling and away from home.

review_body: Hotel is in a good location with rail station only a short walk away and a large shopping mall adjacent. Room and bathroom was small by western standards. Main problem for us was the lack of storage space in the room as there is no cupboard space or shelves in the room or bathroom, just some open hanging space on the wall which meant we had to live out of our suitcases in a room with little space for suitcases. Lack of space was really the only problem we had as the room was clean and beds comfortable, and hotel breakfast buffet was reasonable quality. Check in staff were polite and friendly, and had reasonably good English, however some of the restaurant staff’s english was not very good but they did their best to help when needed.

This hotel had all the offerings of a 5-star hotel, from luxury toiletries to a cell phone guests can use during their stay. Concierge and staff were all very helpful and friendly. While not everyone in the hotel was able to speak English well, their attitude and commitment to quality service definitely made a difference. Would definitely consider staying here again although it is a tad further on the Yamanote line, compared to being in Shinjuku or Shinagawa and requires a 10 to 15-minute walk to the JR Ikebukuro Station. However, for the service they provide, the distance might be worth it.

This hotel is situated in the middle of the sunshine city complex near the Ikebukuro station north east of centre of Tokyo.The room was spacious with twin beds. Bathroom was a prefab unit but it functioned very well but of course there is only room for one person at a time.There are multiple dining options in the hotel or more choice in the shopping complex and streets around the hotel. The service was first class.Highly recommended.

I hated this hotel when I stayed here 6 years ago. It was so dated. And I thought I was staying in a hostel .It went through renovation and because i decided to stay in Tokyo for two more days, there were not many hotels available, I gave it another go.I read the reviews , I didn’t have much expectation about this hotel at all.Surprisingly , it was so much better than before. The staff were all very nice. They were all very helpful. I asked the housekeeper to lend me the hoover so I could vacuum pack my stuff.she was so kind and helped me. I didn’t experience anything like “no smile” “bad attitude” from the staff like what other reviewers said at all.The room was small but was a standard size in Tokyo .It was spotless .i had 2 big suitcases, one big travel bag and a handbag , and the room was spacious enough to accommodate me to open all the suitcases and bags at the same time. I was staying at the panoramic floor.the view was great. I didn’t experience the lift problem like other reviewers said at all! Most of the time, I was the only one in the lift and i didn’t have to wait more than 30seconds for the lift. I did take the lifts stopping at all floors, but it was not crowded at all.The only downside of the room was the air conditioning. You could adjust the speed of it. However, the room was still very warm.It was in the shopping centre and about 10 -15mins walk from the Ikebukuro station if you have luggages with you. However , they have the bus going to haneda airport and Narita airport right outside the hotel.I think most “single” or “double” room in Tokyo is really comfortable for one person only . So perhaps spend a bit more and book two rooms if you are travelling with ur friend/partner to avoid complaining about the size.I had a lovely stay at the prince hotel and I definitely will come back.

We stayed here as part of a Wendy Wu tour. The hotel is a high rise hotel and in an interesting area close to shopping, restaurants, underground station etc. the rooms were clean and wi fi was ok. Nothing brilliant but acceptable. Staff and service levels were average, again nothing to excite you.We did find that we had to manage our own luggage into and out of the hotel and our tour bus couldn’t park under the cover of the hotel but out on the street even while it was raining. Most unusual and on our departure all of our group got wet, this made for a very uncomfortable tour for that day.Breakfast and some of our dinners at the hotel were buffet style with a good range of Japanese and European food. Coffee on the other hand was horrible.One issue we had on all of our time at the hotel is that the time it took to get from the lobby to our floor. It sometimes takes 10-15 minutes due to the number of guests and the scheduling of the lifts. Very annoying particularly if you are in a hurry.All in all we wouldn’t probably wouldn’t stay here again.

My first life time experience of viewing dusty and dirty hotel room. Horrible. Room number is 910. I can tell I did something wrong by putting the cleaning spray onto the top. Please check the picture in detail. In addition the waitress in breakfast canteen shows no Japanese smiles. She looks like the security guard. Bad services. Bad hygiene conditions. We strongly recommend the hotel management to try with personal experience. Bad bad bad bad ............It’s also my first special remark in trip advisor.

I stayed here for 10 days while on a tour of Tokyo. As to be expected, the hotel was very clean, from the common areas to the restaurants, elevators and room floors. The check-in process was somewhat challenging, as the staff here speak VERY LITTLE to NO English. However, with a couple of short words, we were able to commmunicate. The rooms ARE NOT like those in American hotels. The rooms are VERY SMALL. However, it worked out fine for me, as I was in a room alone. My room was on the 32nd Floor....SUPERB VIEW OF THE CITY! Both at night and during the day, it was great to just stare out the window at the skyline! Back to the room: THERE ARE NO CLOSETS. There is a rack to hang clothes on; I had brought my own hangars for my suits, slacks, and shirts, so it was okay. The bathroom is VERY SMALL. It is similar to a standard bathroom on a cruise ship. Mine was a "step up" and had a tub and shower. The bathtub is short, maybe about 4 ft long, but nice and deep for a relaxing bath at the end of the day. The breakfast buffet in the hotel is okay. It came with my reservation so I took advantage of it. The food is the same everyday; the don't change it, at least not while I was there. It is fresh and, as to be expected, a combination of some American staples (eggs, pancakes, French fries) and Japanese cuisine (fish, rice, soup). The same outlet provides a dinner buffet as well. There are two other restaurants in the hotel, one offering Chinese cuisine and another offering traditional Japanese cuisine. The hotel has a convenience store which is like a mini 7/11. You can get some refreshments and even some hot meals there, along with alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks. You need to have either a credit card or yen because they DO NOT accept Amiercan currency. The hotel is connected to a FABULOUS mall, inclusive of some really nice stores and restaurants. The mall also contains an aquarium, which I visited and was quite enjoyable. There is also a planetarium (did not visit) as well. The Mall has a location to exchange money, which YOU WILL DEFINITELY NEED TO UTIIZE. The hotel/mall is also a direct conduit into the subway, which was very convenient for getting around the city. There are shops in the subway too! Again, BRING A CREDIT CARD OR YEN. Staying at this hotel, you are right in a very busy section of the city. If you walk through the Mall, down into the subway area and through, you will reach the outside of the hotel and there are TONS of shops and restaurants right in the hotel's perimeter! I found a post office, TGI Fridays, Denny's, and of course, Starbucks, all within a 5 minute walk from the subway! There are electronic, clothing, and shoe stores right on the street, along with 2 video arcades; there's a SEGA store with multiple floors for playing games! The street will be CROWDED, but don't worry, it's quite safe! The only con to staying here is that there isn't anyone on staff that speaks good English. However, with patience and kindness, you can work through those barriers and get whatever you need in the hotel. Asking for directions to get to an attraction was tough. I relied on google and the tourist app from the Japanese tourism bureau for subway directions. For that reason, when I do return, I would stay at an American hotel. However, that's not to say that this is not a good place to stay. I hope, with the Olympics in Tokyo next year, they will bring onboard staff that speak good English.

Location was great - kind of walkable distance to the Ikebukuro train station. The checkin was smooth and staff friendly. The rooms however was tiny, like really tiny.Although the rooms are tiny, the bed is massive leaving literally no space to walk around in the room. The bathroom is small too but not too bad. Breakfast buffet was decent - had all the basic brekky cereals, etc.Overall i would give it a 3.5 stars.

I stayed in this hotel for 10 nights and I really enjoyed it. The hotel location was great it has a linked pathway to the nearest metro station through the sunshine shopping mall I didn’t have to step out of the hotel to go to it. I loved that the hotel is linked to the shopping mall which has a variety of restaurants, clothing boutiques and many more. The hotel staff were friendly and helpful but their english was weak I struggled sometimes communicating with them..also the towels smelled bad sometimes but overall I recommend this hotel for families looking for affordable stay.

Prior to booking this hotel I've read quite a number of reviews but thought I give it a try.First, the hotel looks modern and seem to have gone through renovation in recent years. I purposely choose high floor (panoramic twin room) and I knew the room size, etc prior to booking the room and issue with lifts when staying on lower floors due to tour groups.Location wise, it's about slightly less than 10 minutes walk from ikebukuro station but the limousine bus stops in front of the hotel if you are arriving from airport, which is good. If you're a member, you can check out at 3pm instead of 11am.The hotel has washer and dryer located on level 6.I have two main issues with the room am staying. Been a frequent traveler to Japan I understand how small a room can be. The issue I have is that for a proper twin room, it can hardly accommodate two big luggages. The other main problem I am having is the air cond. Despite setting it to high, there is hardly any cold air coming out from the vent and to some extent my partner end up perspiring, which hardly happen when we stay in a hotel.Mind you, you cannot set the air-cond temperature (refer to picture).

For a group tour this hotel was very good. The room was bigger than many I have stayed in Japan. There are two restaurants for breakfast and the staff are friendly and responsive. The hotel is clean and has easy access to shops and public transport.

The air conditioner is too weak. Thanks reception operator for lending us a fan. However, I shall not come again during summer but winter. In fact, the bedroom is quite nice if the temperature is not the problem.

Stayed there for 4 days, aside from being attached to the mall, it is very near the shopping area. The room is more spacious than the usual Japanese hotel and very clean. There was an earthquake at the time but barely felt it. One downside though is that the breakfast is the same every day... but since there are lots of variety then I guess it is ok.

We actually stayed over in Jul 2018. It’s our third stay with the hotel, so apparently we like it. The hotel is nicely located in Ikebukuro with access to Sunshine City Mall. I’m trying to book again for Jan 2020 under Seibu emi and I’m currently confused by the 5 night (room only) rate for our 13 nights stay.Can the hotel staff get back to me ASAP, I’m not able to locate an email link for this inquiry.

the hotel is at a very good location, nearby shopping places, adjacent to a mall with lots of restaurants and shops too. The hotel is at the train station which makes it convenient to go around Tokyo. The rooms are big and convenient as well.

The room was immaculate and clean. All staff speaks good English. Breakfast has a good variety. Location is superb, there is a 24hrs Seiyu just cross the road and a mini-mart right in the hotel lobby. Connected to Sunshine City Shopping Mall, then by underground walkway to Tokyu Hands and other major shops and eateries.However, on the day we had an early schedule, it took us 30minutes to get down from our room to the lobby. Every lift that stopped were full. So if you are leaving hotel between 8am to 9am, do plan for extra time just to get down to lobby.

Strongly recommended, great and conveniently located near to shopping mall, train and subway station. Good for families and travelling groups.Located in the Ikebukuro district of Toshima, Tokyo. For my family, moving around Tokyo, airport, Outlets, Disneyland and almost everything is a bliss. Thumbs up

We stayed here as part of a tour group. Lovely hotel with good amenities. The hotel is adjacent to a shopping mall where you will find lots of stores and restaurants . There is also a minimart next door. Rooms were a decent size and very nice bathroom products and very large deep bath. Breakfast was varied and plentiful.

Hotel has direct link to sunshine mal was very conviniece with many choice of restaurant in 3 th floor a 24 h Familymart in the groud floorRoom was small but very clean with all amenity with cityviewAirport limousine bus counter in in the Lobby hotel make us very easy to the aiport

We stayed at this hotel during a bus tour and found our experience, on the whole, was very positive. The only issue was the elevators. If you were on a lower floor you had to use the 4 elevators that serviced the whole building. If you were on a higher floor, you had a specific elevator that only serviced the higher floors. This caused an absolute nightmare during checking in of our tour group. The whole process took quite a considerable amount of time before the lobby was cleared. Once we mastered the elevators and were able to time our comings and goings, things worked a lot better. The staff at this hotel offered a great service. Breakfast was also very acceptable.

I just concluded a 10 days stay on the 36th Panorama Floor from 4/23/19 till 5/3/19. I have stayed at this hotel 6 or 7 times in the past 10 years so maybe I am a stickler for pain? But the hotel, like any other, can be pleasant if you know what to expect.Over the years, I learned some lessons the hard way and would like to share some ways to avoid the hassles, in general and in specific to Sunshine Prince.1. This hotel caters to a lot of tour groups and I mean A LOT! That means check-in or check-out could be horrendous, so you should plan your ins and outs to avoid the groups. Avoid trying to check-out the hour before 11am, or check out at 2-3pm, which is when the tour groups are on the move.2. Request for a high floor room, 25th-37th floors as there are exclusive elevators serving only those floors (better if you are at 33 and above, as 1 elevator is exclusively 33-37 only). The other 4 elevators are shared by the rest serving ALL floors which means it is always crowded esp around check-in, check-out and dining hours!The lower floors are where the tour groups are accommodated.3. The 'air-con' is a central air-conditioning feed which means you CANNOT control individual room temperatures! You can only control the volume of air that goes into your room i.e. low, medium or high, which unfortunately doesn't make much difference.4. To keep the air 'fresh' in your room, the hotel provides a plasma ion humidifier/dehumidifier, which technically will freshen the air in your room with the release of negative ions. But a BIG warning here, some of the plasma ion machines seem to have not been maintained in a long time and the air filters are clogged with dust. If this is the case, it will emit bad air and smell into your room. DEMAND that it be changed with a clean unit IMMEDIATELY. You might suffer from breathing the re-circulating air from the unit instead. It is a major cause of the funny smell you get in hotel room.5. Make friends with the housekeeping staff on your floor. They are real nice people and you can get stuff like new towels, refreshments like water and coffee refills more easily than trying to call the housekeeping dept or reception.6. The breakfast option is expensive. It will be cheaper to have a comparable breakfast at the shops just outside the hotel.7. If you are coming in by the Airport Limousine Bus, (not the cheapest but most convenient method as it stops at this hotel), AND if you intend to leave by the same Airport Limousine Bus service within 14 days, it will save you money by buying a RETURN ticket instead of One-way to the hotel and then buying a new ticket back to the airport at the end of your stay. But this works only if you are travelling in pairs.A 14-day return ticket cost Y8000 for 2 paxs, whereas one way tickets will cost Y3100 each person each way, meaning you would pay a total of Y12,200 instead of Y8000. These are just some points, I could go on but I'll just leave you with these street smart tips for now.

The reason my boyfriend and I decided on this hotel was because of their excellent location. We arrived in Tokyo pretty late at night and wanted a hotel that wouldn't be too far of a walk. Since the Sunshine City Prince is one of the only 3 stops for the Limousine Bus in Ikebukuro (the other two being Hotel Metropolitan and Ikebukuro Station), we decided to book this hotel.I have three main issues with this hotel:1. The elevator situation.Since this hotel is used by a lot of tour groups, the elevators are absolutely horrible. There is a total of 6 elevators, but 2 are designated for the "upper" floors. If you are planning on leaving your room anytime between 6:30 AM until 11:00 AM (checkout time), be prepared to be packed into an elevator in a situation that rivals rush hour on the trains. Although we were in a higher room, the separate elevators made little to no difference. We were packed into elevators with other hotel guests (who were not even staying on the higher floors) traveling in the OPPOSITE direction just because that's how slow and packed the elevators were. In all the hotels I've stayed in, they've all had sensors in their elevators to make sure that hotel guests were only allowed to visit the floors that they stayed in! This is also a security concern that the hotel should take seriously. Hotel guests should not be allowed to visit any floor that they choose.2. Cleanliness of the rooms.At first glance, the rooms look clean. But when my boyfriend and I checked into our room, there were hairs in the bathroom, around the toilet and inside the tub. On our last day, we found a roach running around under the beds. I've never seen a roach running around on the sidewalks of Tokyo or even in the dirtiest of restaurants... For there to be a roach on an upper floor of a "newly renovated" hotel, was beyond disgusting to me. I wouldn't want to see how the lower floors look like.3. Customer service.On our last day, my boyfriend and I asked the front desk staff upon checking out if it would be possible to hold our bags for a few hours. They said they could, but directed us to the Bell Captain's desk across the lobby. Once we waited for the gentleman working at the desk to finish with his first customer, he told us we had to first purchase a ticket for the Limousine Bus. We figured this was normal practice, so we went to purchase our ticket from the Limousine Bus desk and returned a few minutes later. A lady named "蒲田" proceeded to take our suitcases and told us she was going to take it outside. She spoke little to no English and made no attempt to explain what she was doing with our suitcases. I asked for an English speaker, and the same man from before came to help us. He tried to explain that they store all of the suitcases for customers traveling on the Limousine Bus outside. He also tried to tell us that it was "more convenient" because our bags would be automatically loaded onto the bus for us. I've traveled many times with the Limousine Bus and I'm well aware that this is convenient for some customers, but since my boyfriend and I were planning on shopping a bit before our departure, we wanted to be able to repack our bags before inside the hotel, not outside on the sidewalk. I tried to explain this to the male staff, but he didn't seem to understand or care. I even told him that we had been staying at the hotel, since they were able to store other people's luggage directly behind the Bell Captain's desk. But after much debate and confirming that he would not keep our bags outside, we handed our suitcases over and watched as he wheeled them outside... This was the last straw. Once my boyfriend and I returned to pick up our bags, we kept on getting dirty glares from the Japanese-speaking "蒲田' and felt completely unwelcome even though we had been staying at this hotel for the past few days.I do not recommend this hotel at all. There are many other hotels around the Ikebukuro area that are cheaper, cleaner and have kinder staff than the Sunshine City Prince.

Very busy hotel with a lot of groups coming and leaving.Very clean small room with no cupboards, no way to open a window and A/C not very effective."Coffee" facilities in the room but only green tea available. High step to reach the bathroom. Very busy and poor buffet. A lot of items missing.No sufficient lifts and 10-15 minutes time waiting time until the lift arrives(full of people, no way to enter). Suggestion: go up in order to go down!

For several years we've been bringing 15-20 high school students from the US to Japan and we always stay at the Sunshine Prince because of its location. This year we decided to skip the breakfast buffet . It's OK and convenient, but for the price, you can eat better elsewhere. The real challenge is the elevators in the morning. If you are staying on the lower floors floors, you need to plan well in advance to get to the lobby. In most cases, when the elevator stops on your floor, it's too full to get on. This year I noticed they added another express elevator, but it hasn't made any difference that I can notice. Speaking with other guests, they expressed the same frustration.

We arrived here and we have felt a very professional atmosphere. Large room, large and very comfortable bed. Enough amenities in the bathroom those are ready for you to use. Fast wifi. Super clean room. Super fast elevator. Really good hotel.

This is our first family trip to Tokyo, Japan. I chose this hotel simply because they have the Airport Limousine Bus right at their front door. 24-hours supermarket and lots of restaurants around. Not busy as Shinjuku area but still has several big departments store for shopper.I made the booking directly with Sunshine City Prince Hotel. Their reservation department is very helpful and always replies my emails on time. They even gave us therir SeiBu Prince Club member's discount before we checked in. We (4 adults) booked 2 City-Twin Room Type C rooms for 4 nights. We didn't book their Panorama-Fourth Room because it was quite expensive for 4 adults. We stayed there from 16/01 to 20/01 in Room #1627 & 1628. Two rooms look the same but #1627 is a bit smaller than 1628. As this hotel has a lot of tourist groups so the lifts are always busy especially in the morning.Airport Limousine Bus has a counter on the ground floor too. Better to book your return bus to the airport (Haneda or Narita) once you have checked in to secure your seat. Family Mart (convenient store) is on the ground floor. Easy to go to the Ikebukuro Station(池袋) & Higashi-ikebukuro (東池袋)。We had a wonderful stay there. Reception staffs are nice, friendly and helpful. As a SeiBu Prince Club member, we got a free English newspaper every morning. If you choose for not cleaning your room for a day (maximum 2 days per room), the hotel will offer you one $500 Yen voucher to use in their restaurants. We save $2000 Yen all together and we spent it to buy their desserts at Cafe & Dining Chef’s Palette the night before we checked out. Really delicious and it's a good way to end our stay there. Strongly recommend this hotel for those who travel with young children or elderly especially for first time travellers to Tokyo unless you don't want to meet tourist groups. Be aware of their room size is quite small. We definitely will stay there if we can organixe another trip to Tokyo again.

Traveling to Japan for more than 30 times in all these years, I’ve been staying with Sunshine City Prince Hotel in Tokyo for number of times until I found that the hotel rooms were really getting too old. I was told by my friend lately that they had a renovation recently and the rooms are much better now. Therefore, we choose to stay with them again this time from 17-21Jan19 and while making the booking with our travel agency, we emphasised to have a room in the newly renovated floor. We booked for a twin room with breakfast for two and the total amount we paid was HKD6000 for four nights. (HKD1500 per night). While checking in at the reception, I asked if the room assigned to us is newly renovated and the answer was YES. We were given room 916 and when we opened the door for our room, we were so disappointed as only the wallpaper and the carpet which I believe are renovated but not all the furniture and everything inside the toilet. The room, being a twin, is considered as extremely small and all the furniture are being squeezed into the room not in the appropriate positions. To make the situation even worse, we found a strong smell of urine from the toilet and the smell doesn’t go away even after flushing for a few times. There are also stains around the rims of the washing basin which looks quite dirty.Dirts/black spots are found all over the toilet mirror because of it’s long service inside the bathroom. Moreover, the air-condition unit is as what it was 20 years ago and the room was actually a bit hot even if we turned to ‘high’. The plug for chargers is strangely built in on one side of the wooden desk next to the bed and is difficult to place or hold the cellphone when charging with a short cord.The so-called wardrobe is only 1 foot away from one of the bed and the door was hardly to be opened if you stand in front of it. The TV set is placed on the desk which is on the left side of the two beds, definitely not a considerate or ideal position for watching TV from the beds. The walls are so ‘thin’ that I can hear clearly the talking from people next door at nighttime and the noises made by people from the upper floor as well.As our schedules were so tight and we left the hotel every morning after breakfast and return to the hotel at around 2100-2200. I really hate to waste my time wrestling with their management and to hear all those excuses that I don’t want to hear if I raise a complaint to the front desk. Because they will certainly have a different definition of ‘newly renovated’. Also, I don’t want to hold up my friends traveling with us and staying on the same floor. I therefore sent my complaint to the hotel group on the second day via the website they provided for inviting comments. However, I received no reply from anyone till my departure day and neither did anyone approach me about the complaint.Not sure if it is because the money that I paid was not enough to enjoy a real renovated room, if so, the front desk staff should have told me instead of telling me that it is a newly renovated room. To reflect more on this incident, two of my friends traveling with us and stayed in room 914 have extended their stay for two more days (till 23Jan) with lower room rate at around HKD1100 but without breakfast, and they were offered a room at 36 floor for the two extra days and which is fully renovated and with a much better view. In other words, the money we paid should be enough to enjoy the same even with breakfast.Anyhow, HKD1500 for a room with strong urine smell is just too expensive. I feel like being cheated and I decided to punish them by not staying with their hotel group anymore in the future. Also, I’m going to share this experience with my friends who are traveling a lot to Japan.

The hotel is nice to stay, surrounding the are also nice. There is a mall next to the hotel.The room was clean, and bathroom is small like many typical hotels in Tokyo.Breakfast was ok, with limited of choice. We were staying on high season in December 2018, so there are a lot of groups from other countries.There is a Family Mart 24hour behind the check in counter.

I've stayed at this hotel for 10 nights on New Year's Eve Vacation. We were a group of over 30 people and they gave us rooms at the same floor in order to be together. We arrived before the check-in time so they took care of our luggage until we could check-in, and they made it very quickly. The room was quite large to be a Japanese hotel, there were even a desk, a tv and some space to put the luggage and move in a comfort way. Towels, slippers and dressing gown were changed every day and in the bathroom you could find toothbrush, razor, comb, hairdryer and big flacons of soap, shampoo and gel douche. The bed was very comfortable and you have all the light switches near it. The service was excellent, very kind and always ready to solve your problems. The waiters in the breakfast room bring you personally to your table and the receptionists are very quick to help you and to do the ordinary work. The breakfast buffet was huge and with a great variety of sweet and salt food. What makes this hotel greater than it seems is its position, it is directly connected to a huge mall with lots of shops and restaurants and its district is full of arcade game, pubs, shops and lots of different kind of great restaurants. There's a subway station underneath the hotel and another one, which is bigger and has more lines linked, just 5 minutes walk away and both of them are just a few stations away from the most important districts of Tokyo, like Shinjuko, Akihabara, Asakusa, etc.In conclusion it was a great and comfortable stay in a hotel where people is very kind and helpful and were you can easily enjoy not only the neighborhood but also the most famous districts of Tokyo.

Booked into Sunshine City Prince Hotel for four nights, with three different grade rooms for my parents, me, my sister and brother-in-law. Rooms were small but otherwise acceptable - it is Japan. Full amenities provided, good views of the city, conveniently linked to a large shopping mall. If you want to use the toilet, there's a huge step to climb into it, for some reason. Lifts were chaotic at dinner time - we had to queue to get into an elevator, and no staff were around to help usher guests where a giant line blocked the entire entrance to the lift areas.Here is why my entire family checked out the very next day with a full refund, and went back to Metropolitan hotel in Ikebukuro (we've stayed there prior to another part of our Tokyo trip). 1) Staff have 0 initiative. Upon entering the lobby, no one stepped forward to help us with any of our luggage, or offered to ask us how they can help us. Upon speaking to someone, she flatly told us what time check in is (we knew we were early) and did not offer us any alternative. Don't wait for the guest to ask for early check in, or where they can store their bags while waiting, or that you actually have a guest lounge - take initiative. You might even earn some money for us choosing to do an early check in. 2) Rooms were DISGUSTINGLY, relentlessly warm. The fact that they used a centralised air conditioning/heating system (a very money-saving technique) is not stated ANYWHERE in the hotel information - only that air con is a part of their facilities. I beg to differ on their definition of air conditioning. We were extremely uncomfortable and the rooms had 0 air circulation even when staff came to adjust the fan. The manager who assisted in moving me (Watanabe) to another room, was sweating himself! 3) Murakami personally handled our issues with the a/c. He insisted the rooms were 'much cooler' despite us showing him the temperature in the actual room. He insisted that there were absolutely no other rooms available as the hotel was fully booked. He insisted there were no fans left in the hotel. Twenty minutes later, a fan turned up. An hour later, we showed management a whole two pages of available rooms found on Agoda and Booking.com. Murakami decided not see us any further, and threw his assistant manager, Watanabe, under the bus to deal with us and to help me move from one to another supposedly 'cooler' room. 4) Me and my sister woke up sick the next day - sweating in said rooms. Tokyo's temperature? 0 degrees. Sunshine City Prince Hotels' room temperature? 25 degrees. Both me and my sister fell violently ill, ran a fever, had intense nausea and we had no alternative but to check out immediately. We got a full refund, and had to move back to Metropolitan hotel, where the hotel staff immediately took all our luggage for us, sent me to a clinic nearby after finding us an English-speaking clinic, ensured all our rooms were beautifully cool and comfortable for an early check in so we could all recuperate. Sunshine City Prince Hotel did not even bother to help us find a cab when we left. Not one staff helped us take our altogether seven pieces of luggage out to the taxi line or even asked if they could assist us any further after issuing us refunds and a check out.Is it a good hotel? Probably. If you engaged a tour group, you'll probably end up here in a crowded, chaotic, noisy lobby with staff that look presentable but do nothing else for you. Is it a hotel I would return to ever again in my lifetime? Not a single probability.

I can say it's got a little more room than quite a few of the hotels I've stayed in Tokyo. Can't compare to some other cities like KL or Singapore but the rooms were relatively larger. Beds were rather small for 2 persons though. I'd put it as a super single or small queen? Rooms were clean, well equipped and so was the toilet. Request for a high floor and we were put on the "Prince" levels which were really so much better especially when there was a special lift that served only levels 33 to 37. So it was really great to take the express elevator. Convenience store was located on level 1 which was wonderful to buy most stuff. The shopping complex just beside the hotel was pretty large though shops closed at 8pm sharp except for the restaurants on level 3. Only 2 in a room so kids were in the room next door. So family or no family, only 2 in a room max. Wheelchairs would find it a problem to get into the rooms as the corridor in the room after the door could only fit one and a half of me standing abreast (at best, maybe less). Certainly it wouldn't fit me and my luggage beside me as I had to push it in front of me and opening the door was an issue when coming out So it wouldn't fit a wheelchair.

The hotel is clean and nice.Everything is good.Btw, as title, I lost the brand-new electric toothbrush in the room.I wonder if I can get it back by any mean.If you find it, please let me know or contact me.Thank you.一切都很好~裡面乾淨舒適。另外，如標題，我把一組全新的電動牙刷遺留在房間了。不論用什麼方式，我都想要把它拿回來。如果有找到的話，請讓我知道或者聯繫我。謝謝。

Very nice hotel. Room was clean and spacious for hotel in Japan specially in Tokyo. Connected to mall, higashi ikebukuro station, restaurant. Check in and check out was very easy. We sent luggages to Osaka from this hotel for 2000 yen each. They really help us.

Although it takes time to go to any major attraction from here, it seems to be a pretty good value. It's near a metro station, so as long as you can navigate that, you're set. It's next to Sunshine city mall, which is convenient. The buffet breakfast was great as well. Room was efficient, and since this was my 1st time in Japan, the bathroom/toilet was quite an experience! There was only one English-speaking TV channel, however, that I could find, a news/event channel, I believe. Bed was comfortable. The worst part of staying here, and it was an issue, is that the AC is not adjustable. I like it cool, as in 68 degrees F or lower, and it must have been 75 or higher the whole time! If I were not with a group, I would have considered another place, unless this is typical of Japanese hotels. It was explained to me that Asian body temp is warmer than Caucasion's (by a Japanese tour guide). Not sure about that, but it was hot at night inside, windows don't open either.

I cannot praise this hotel enough. We arrived from Osaka to Tokyo and was already quite tired, taking many bags. Firstly the concerige allowed us to put our bags in the hotel for storage for a few days free of charge. Secondly the friendly front office guy helped to take our bags, helped us to check in within 5 mins, took us to the newly renovated lift lobby, helped to show us our room, we cannot thank him enough, but we didnt take down his name, if not i would want to write a letter of compliment.We stayed on the Paranoma floor, 36th floor and with a great bird's eye view of the Tokyo city skyline and was very pleased. Next, we were very surprised to learn that there's a amenity kit being prepared for my child. Also, there's a 24 hour big Family mart convenient store and shopping mall attached to the hotel which makes is so easy. There's also a limo bus counter located at the ground floor of the hotel too, for easy reach to Narita and Haneda airport. I have last stayed in this hotel 10 years ago, this is my 2nd time. If i ever come back to Tokyo again, i would definitely high recommend this hotel for their 10 star great customer service.

This is the second time for us to stay at Ikebukuro area, this time we decide to stay at this hotel. The room quite small as per you expect in Japan especially in Tokyo but with a nice view. They also has a coin laundry at level 6 which is handy for us and the location only 10 min walk from JR Ikebukuro Station and above a mall. Lots of store along the way from the station to the hotel or you can use underground access to the nearby subway. The hotel also provide a bus limousine to take us to the airport (Haneda/Narita) which is handy as we don't have to carry our luggage and simply wait for the bus to arrive in front of the hotel. The only negative experience for us, the hotel was not a quite place as we would love to be and the wall quite thin. On the first night we can hear our neighbour turn on a music quite loud until midnight and there was another incident where the guest next door (different person) decide to have a conference early in the morning (around 4-5am in the morning) and talking so loud. We need to hit the wall so many times to remind him that we can hear clearly and he woke us up from our sleep. Otherwise we quite happy to stay at this place.

This hotel is at Ikebukoro area. The hotel is charming, the room is fit, free wifi, shower, shampoo, conditioner brand “pola”.Soft beds with 2 feather pillows. The food is very delicious, especially the fish in Saba.

Got this chance to stay in this hotel for 4N and overall experience is very good. I must say that, yes, it is strategically located and everything is like within reach.+ Walking distance to mall, themed park, station, shopping area, restaurants etc.+ Check in is fuss~free, the waiting lounge for our group is a good idea+ Customer Service is excpetional, housekeeping is efficient and everyone is prompt+ Window View is stunning. Got to see tokyo from they top while sipping cup of tea.+ Wifi is fast and the Info Guide is on the TV Monitor. (Please add an English Option for foreign guests)Downside- Room needs renovation. The carpet smells bad and undeniably fading.- Breakfast is sumptuous but the menu is repeating everyday. I skipped once as i know il be eating the same. Work with a cycle menu.- The room is not well ventilated. Its humid and hot inside the room.

Location is very convenient .shopping mall is very good . easy to walk to take the subway from the hotel Got a big department store in the subwayBut the bad part is the washroom exhaust fan is not work . So it got smell . But overall is good.

Horrible experience from the moment I checked in. Last year I stay in the same hotel and they gave me a room whereby the twin bed is side by side. To my horror, this year my twin bedroom is 2 beds being put head to head. I asked to change room, they said I can't. Unfortunately I extended 1 more day in the same hotel but they cannot put me in the same room. It is either I accept a lower grade room or I must check out and check in again. I asked to extend my check out time for 1 hour. They denied me again. They said not possible and I have to pay 1 hour 1,000 yen. I guess this hotel is not doing hospitality business. They are solely into just renting out rooms. Customers satisfaction, convenience and needs are not important at all to them. If I'm in HK, Taiwan, Singapore, China or Korea. This will not happen to me. Travelling close to 12 hours and encountered this type of check-in experience, life really suck. The trip is already a bad head start. I still have 5 more days to endure here. I went to the front desk to speak to them, they told me no matter who I speak to at the hotel, all answers will be the same. They cannot do anything aside from what they told me during check-in. Lousy customer service especially customers experience, needs and satisfaction are not something they seems to care especially in my case.

My husband and I were booked into this hotel by our Japanese exchange daughter who lives nearby. A perfect location, 10 minute walk through busy shopping area to Ikebukuro Station to get anywhere in Tokyo. Lots of shopping and restaurants, an aquarium in the attached mall, international ATM right off the lobby in the ‘Family Mart’, Limousine Bus to/from airports at the door and tickets sold in the lobby. Downside is no storage for clothes so literally live out of your suitcase, and very oddly, absolutely no temperature control in the rooms! All you can do is adjust the fan speed in the room, windows do not open. It was too hot to comfortably sleep one night, likely as it had been a sunny day and we were on the top floor. We complained and they gave us a portable cooling fan which helped but even our local friends thought it was strange. Apparently they monitor the hallway temperature but that doesn’t allow for a small enclosed room after a couple of hot showers! So 22 degrees Celsius as showing on their computer for the 37th floor did not accurately reflect how our room felt. We would have rated this hotel much higher except for these issues.

The hotel itself is nice the room however has no storage space such as drawers or a closet for your clothes. We had to throw our clothes on the desk they have in the room. Also for those using the subway while its about 10 to 15 min walk from the hotel coming back to the hotel can take longer depending on which exit of the subway you depart.

Airport Limousine Bus stopped right in front of the hotel. The staff are helpful and friendly. Sunshine City Mall have most of the stuff we need and there is food everywhere be it in the mall or outside. Personally, i feel that it is faster to walk to Ikebukuro Station than to the Higashi-Ikebukuro Station., with more things to see along the way. As for room wise, it is big enough for 2 big luggage to be fully open, one just had to take bigger steps to cross. Everything was perfect.

Inside sunshine city mall so no problems finding food etc. we found the walk to Ikebukuro station a bit long everyday but that’s us. airport bus stops here so very convenient if you have many bags going home.

I was traveling with my family and the teenagers wanted this hotel because it was near everything they desired to see & do. At first we were assigned a different hotel and I had to beg my travel agent for this hotel. I was surprised and happy that I was assigned this hotel because it was a fantastic place to stay.The rooms were bigger than I had expected. The Sunshine Mall was excellent. There's a Pokemon Center, in the mall. The location was perfect because we were able to walk to the train station. We could shop and find restaurants close by.There was a Hotel Airport bus that took us back to the airport for a reasonable price.I read in other reviews about too much crowding in the lobby from tour groups and I didn't see this!I also read that the elevators would be too crowded to get on, to go down. I didn't see over crowded elevators.I used the Connivance store often, because it was right off the lobby.We had a wonderful stay and would return, if we visit Tokyo again.

review_body: Inclined to write a review to level up... and also I've stayed here way too many times. There is a direct bus service from Narita and Haneda Airport, the shopping mall is downstairs, the rooms are very slightly bigger than rival hotels in the vicinity, the 24-h supermarket is just outside the shopping mall, Sunshine 60-dori is abundant, and the number of train lines above and below ground at Ikebukuro is way too convenient for you to get to places within and outside Tokyo city. Saitama prefecture is just above this neighbourhood as well.Service in this hotel is acceptable - ask and assistance would be given, and they'll do a decent job for you. If you don't ask, they pretty much would leave you to your own devices.I never have issues with the bed and pillows, but perhaps due to age or a change of furniture due to renewal (renovation), this time round I wake up daily with slight aches. Hmmm.My only gripe is the level of stuffiness in the rooms and you can't do much to the air-conditioning. I think this was the case before renewal (renovation), but after renewal, it seemed to have gotten worse. This applies regardless of room size and the number of occupants within. If you don't have a strong throat, you sneeze easily, or if you're travelling with someone who may catch a flu along the way, good luck - the lack of air circulation and the high level of humidity may affect you.Do your research on when the hotel gets really crowded - the waiting time for lifts and the FamilyMart convenience store can be long.I would consider staying here again next year if the bed, air circulation and conditioning issues be addressed and improved.To all who are travelling to Tokyo for the first time and looking to get an overall good impression of the city, this accommodation might be it.

My family of four stayed at the Sunshine City Prince Hotel on 8/14/2018-8/22/2018. Our 2 rooms were for the twin Type C configuration on the 10th floor. The Prince Hotel was very easy to get to from Narita airport. We took the airport limo ($3100 yen pp) which dropped us off directly in front of the hotel in about 2 hours. Check-in went very smoothly without any issues. Our side by side rooms consisted of 2 twin size beds that were configured end to end and separated by a 3 foot high wall. The beds were very firm and 2 pillows were provided per bed. The room had a small desk, a small refrigerator, a small closet area (in one of the 2 rooms), a safe (one was not working in one of our rooms), and a cell phone which you could use for free (indoor and outdoor) during your stay at the hotel. The TV was approximately 32” with just one station that broadcasted in English (NHK). The bathroom had a small counter and a combo shower/tub. Water pressure was very good as was the water temperature. Climate control for the room was somewhat limited. There was no way to turn the AC up any higher, however the room never felt too hot or stuffy. Wi-Fi was excellent; we were always able to connect to the internet and experienced no dropped connections while we were there. Although the hotel has a number of restaurants, we never tried any of them and instead ate at the restaurants at the Sunshine Mall (4th floor). There is also a currency exchange machine in the lobby. The indoor mall is connected to the hotel and has an impressive array of stores in addition to an aquarium, observatory, planetarium, and 2 themed areas Nanjatown and J-World. There is also a Food-Mart and mini supermarket which were great sources for picking up bottled water, inexpensive food, and other household items. The mall leads into the outdoor Sunshine City Strip (very busy/crowded) which again has many stores, eating establishments, and really fun game arcades. At the end of the strip is Ikebukuro train station where you can catch both the Metro and JR trains. Although I found our rooms a tiny bit cramped, I think all the amenities, i.e. location, mall, restaurants, proximity to subway station, and easy transfer to and from the airport more than made up for that. I highly recommend the Sunshine City Prince Hotel and I would not hesitate staying there again when I return to Tokyo one day.
