review_body: It was a very good staying..it was more than a 3 star hotel. Convenient and comfortable amd spacious. Complete with bathroom toiletries tv and more. Clean. Walkable to mrt. Inside a mall.nice viewe. Good

I was very disappointed at first. The reservation system asked for the number of guests and supposedly, should offer me a room for four, but I only get two single beds that is not possible to sleep four. The reception suggest I change to a panorama room, which has semi-double bed. So I paid 1000Yen per person to upgrade to the panorama room. We liked the room and had enjoyed our stay here, I just think they should be honest with their smaller rooms and small beds on the system.

It was a first time say in Sunshine City Prince for us. Been trying to book it last times we were in Tokyo but it was always fully booked. Finally we were successful and it was a good experience. I wanted to stay in the Sunshine City area moreso we came from the Kansai region of Japan and we wanted to immediately settle in our hotel to prepare for the next days' trips. So easy to stay here coz the Ikebukuro Station is just a walking distance. Not very near but a good, easy walk along a nice shopping area to the hotel. Plus the Sunshine Road (on the way from Ikebukuro Station to the hotel) is a pedestrian only road so no problem in taking your luggage to the hotel. The hotel's staff were also very helpful and accommodating. Our room was ready when we checked in at about midnight after a Shinkansen trip from Nagoya. Ikebukuro Sunshine City bus terminal is also just behind the hotel so it was very convenient if you're taking the bus to and from anywhere outside Tokyo. There are so many restaurants and entertainment centers around. The biggest anime department store is also located here in Sunshine City Ikebukuro. So anime fans would have a ball staying here in this area. With the Ikebukuro Station just near, you can take the JR Yamanote Line which circles around Tokyo. You can even design your own tour. Just google and you're good to go! Some tours also pick up participating travelers from Prince Hotel so very convenient for the traveler. Even airport limo buses originating from either Narita or Haneda have drop off/pick up points in SC Prince Hotel. Very convenient indeed. As for food, I say you can go east or west of Ikebukuro Station and find both Michelin and regular restos here. There's Ippudo and Mutikiya on the west side. Some unknown to us but still very good food they have. Even the regular restos would offer you the best quality food. The Japanese are known for their high quality foods served in even the regular restos. Go adventure and you'll not regret it. They also help you in booking for your airport limo buses to Narita or Haneda which we took. Our 4D/3N stay wasn't enough! By the way, there's also a quite big supermart just across the hotel. I just forgot the name but its a famous chain of Japanese supermart. We bought our food souvenirs from thee. There are also many convenience stores around the hotel.Enjoyed our stay much!

very great we got a phone to use while we stayed :) and a great airco! Handy when it is 34°cThat is all I have to say but it needs to be at least 200 characters. But I do recommend the cat cafe mocha very expensive but great!

The rate is a little bit expensive for us and heard that not a lot in the area speaks English. But, we were amazed how good the staff were who greeted us. Staff are very respectful. Our room is very clean and basically complete on what you need except for limited English TV channels. We got a full 2 days package tour and wow! the tourist guides are so knowledgeable, accommodating, punctual and helpful. Everything is good and no thieves! very clean and of course food are so yummy.We will definitely go back to Japan and visit more historical and beautiful places and sceneries.

it is such a normal hotel but convenient to go anywhere in Tokyo, a lot of people from different country. clean and cozy hotel as it could be in Japan. the price is ok not too cheap and not expensive.

I have stayed here for multiple times and the best part of this hotel is its location. Train station 15 mins walk away. All sorts of shops and restaurants right beneath the hotel. But usually there are a lot of mainlander and groups checking in so it can be quite noisy and crowded sometimes in the lobby. Air-con a bit weak but that's common everywhere in Japan.

The location of the Hotel is good and the coach is available from Narite airport dir3ct to this hotel . The staff is very average and slow. Hospitality is completely lacking unlike other hotels I stayed in Japan. The rooms ar3 very small and smaller bathrooms but they have comfortable Japanese potty

Stayed here with my colleagues for our incentive trip. Location is very good, connected to a mall and near shopping area and some restaurants. There is also a Family Mart convenient store inside the hotel. They have a decent breakfast though almost the same every day.

The hotel is situated in a shopping precinct so you can walk in the dry and light on a damp evening. Our room was a reasonable size but there was only a rail on the wall to hang clothes, and the bathroom was very small. The breakfast buffet area was always crowded and there was little choice for Europeans. One good thing was that there was a small shop where you could find a range of necessities and things to eat. The staff were friendly but not many that we encountered spoke English.

I usually like to say a few nice things about a hotel to justify the fact that I am even forcing someone to read my review. Unfortunately, I really can’t say anything nice at all about this hotel- excepted that it appeared to be free of vermin.The location is poor - it is very, very far away from the main part of town. We were, unfortunately, the first to be picked up on tours, and the last be dropped off because we were so remotely situated in Tokyo. I would say, in summary, that it was a dormitory for the touring masses. The lobby is a zoo filled with tour groups assembling at all hours. All our fellow guests seemed to be members of a prepaid gigantic tour groups, thus the hotel seemed to have no incentive to provide anything that wasn’t strictly required. There were no flowers, nor art, nor anything the least bit attractive or humanizing in this building or any of the rooms. (Yes, the room walls of our room were absolutely blank.)WARNING: Many of the rooms are ridiculously, ridiculously, ridiculously small unless you demand – DEMAND and refuse to leave – a normal – sized room. The room we initially got was only as wide as fingertip to fingertip, and it contained a double bed. Apparently, there are six different categories of room sizes here. Be sure you’ve gotten one that will allow you to inhale, exhale, and turn around. NO KIDDING. You can’t count on those things at this ridiculous hotel. It would be preferable to stay in one of those novelty Japanese “capsule” hotels, so at least you wouldn’t have to pay the regular hotel rates they charge here, and you would have an amusing experience about which to tell your friends....The bathrooms also were incredibly small and stripped down and, as my husband observed, probably pre-– fab. They were about the size of the facilities on an airplane, and they were about as lovely and comfortable. There was a lip on the edge of the bathroom on which you easily could trip and fall in the middle of the night – very dangerous. The safe was so small that an iPad wouldn’t fit in. The walls were thin and you could hear everything. There were minimal amenities, no coffee, and the towels were fraying. They gave us four – count ‘em, four! – hangers on which to hang our clothes. The elevators are a nightmare – they only ran two out of six even though they were totally packed for this 38- floor hotel at 8a.m.:. Do not stay here.

This is the second time I had stayed here. Stayed on the 34th floor. Rooms are definitely nicer than it was when I stayed 2 years ago. Lobby has been renovated. Room: We took the rooms on Paranoma floors so I am not sure if the rooms are bigger. But it is ok size by the standard of hotels in Japan. There is enough space for 2 big luggage to be open. There is a bathtub in the room and bathroom amenities are provided. Surroundings: Hotel is connected to Sunshine 60 mall which has an underground walkway to bring you to Ikebukuro shopping area. There is a Family Mart on the ground floor.Transport: Airport Limosuine bus stops right in front of the hotel. Hotel is around 10 to 15 mins walk to the metro or JR stations.

This hotel was clean and pleasant, but with drawbacks. The beds were Japanese-typically hard, with pillows to match. Staff was good about bringing softer pillows. The dinner choices after a 14 hour flight to Tokyo left a lot to be desired. And too expensive. The breakfast buffet was only so-so. Great variety of Japanese and Western choices, but nothing was hot except the Miso soup. Saving grace was the good coffee! Location was good - within walking distance of some great sights and certainly subway accessible. Attached Sunshine City Shopping Mall was great with a lot of choices, both for shopping and eating.Be ready for a jam-packed lobby every morning as the day's travel tours depart. You'll see a multitude of groups gathering and boarding busses, making getting through the lobby (much less getting on an elevator) a challenge. Even finding your travel group if you are on one of the tours!

Room is small, but not as small as I expected. Bed is very comfortable. Room comes with a courtesy Android cell phone with voice and data. Hotel is connected to the mall. Family Mart (convenience store) right at the hotel and there is another Family Mart on 3rd floor mall. Less than 10 mins from the JR/Metro station. I took the limo bus service between airport and hotel, to avoid the hassle taking subway/train with the baggage. Room has air cond. You can only adjust how strong of the air, but not the temperature. Temperature is ok, but I do prefer a little cooler.Minor complaint is too many hotel guests. At times, especially early morning, had to wait long for the elevator.

Rooms are smallish ;beds comfortable ;well located for rail /local bus use ;staff helpful and prices quite fair .Shopping mall (huge!) is co-located ; great restaurants . Suitable for the average tourist budget

Spent three nights in this hotel which tour operators describe as 4 star. Large reception area but with no atmosphere. Had to ask if our cases could be taken to our room as no attempt was made to take them for us. We were given a room on the 16th floor which was actually a single but had two single beds squeezed in by placing the beds together headboard to headboard which left a small corridor approximately 2 foot wide which you had to use to store your cases as no cupboards or wardrobe. You had to walk over your cases to get to the beds and only one person at a time. Ridiculous!! There was a small rail on the wall with 3/4 hangers should you wish to use them. The air con was not working properly and you were unable to open the window making it uncomfortable to sleep in. No bottled water offered in the room. Bathroom was a decent size which confirmed to us that this was indeed a single room and if had one single bed this would have been sufficient for a lone person and the hotel could have furnished it properly. As we were a couple this room was really not suitable for two people. This room could only be described as a box room. One bed was like sleeping on a board. The buffet breakfast had a very good variety but it was so busy you had difficulty getting a table so my advice is to try and go after 9 but you risk not having the food replenished as they stop serving at 10am. We did ask to change the room but informed this was not possible. We did speak with another couple who managed to get a room on the 36th floor which was a normal double. So try and get a room on the higher floors. No English speaking tour desk so not able to arrange tours. My advice would be to use another hotel with better amenities as this hotel only has a convenience shop, coffee shop and restaurant. Not impressed.

Friendly staff, quick check-in.Rooms of course small. Just tea no coffee in the room.Airco could be much better. Bathroom very good, nice hot and strong shower.Safe in room very small when lifting IPad they just fitted in.Breakfast extreamly pricy and hot food never really hot.

Hotel is in a good location, 20 minute by taxi to central area. Service was excellent as was the room and the dining and bar areas. desk staff very helpful and language was not an issue. I had a power point issue ( Western 3 prong plug will not work in all hotels. The majority of converters only allow for you to plug in two prong plugs into get a power converter plug.) They suggested I go to Bic Camera who had the plug. One I could find anywhere in Australia, in any outlet or airport.Food was buffet but excellent.

As a group tour this hotel was selected by the organizer. As I preferred staying along I had to pay S$600 extra for 7 days stay. I have been thinking “Prince Hotel” is a high end hotel but after staying here and the quality I should say it is a quite ordinary hotel with lots to be improved. This may not apply for other Prince Hotels. This hotel seemed to me mainly for foreigners from Asian countries (Chinese, Korean, Malaysian, Indonesian, Singaporean, Vietnamese et all). You can enjoy hearing all sorts of languages spoken there.As I never thought of writing a review on this hotel I did not take photos. But I would like to say certain things for those who wish to stay this hotel.Good points: 1. Airport shuttle bus service is available both from Narita Airport and Haneda Airport.2. Connected to the big Shopping centre with all kinds of shops including lots of restaurants from ordinary ones to high end, and also amusement facilities like aquarium etc.3. Helpful staffBad points:1. Bathtub was not clean; I notices dirt in the wall of bathtub when I wanted to dip myself in hot water in the tub. Therefore I asked the front to clean. After two days again the similar dirt was found. This shows they do not scrub the tub wall every day.2. No writing pad in the room3. Too crowded during morning breakfast. Then everyday same items. This is a bit too much for those who stay more than a week.4. We were caught in morning rush hour elevator. It took almost 30 minutes to get in for checking out. That too after calling the front desk frantically.5. A bit far away from train/metro stations.6. Though this is an old hotel noise from next room could be heard at night.

Hotel very clean, but small room for European people and slightly basic. Good value for money. It had a small mini market inside the hotel, handy for buying sandwiches and drinks etc.The big plus for the ladies it is attached to a large shopping mail.Within walking distance to the underground network.

Stayed at this hotel at the start and end of our tour of Japan.First impressions was large (37 floors) modern hotel attached to shopping mall. Check in wasn't too bad as a group, we took our own cases from coach to the room. First room we had was small, bathroom was like the pod type and small. There was a small wardrobe but trying to place 2 suitcases out was challenging. Buffet Breakfast choice was fairly good if you got there before the rush, people had to queue. Breakfast restaurant not big enough for size of hotel. There were 6 lifts but had to wait at least 10 minutes to get in one at peak times. The trick is to catch one going up if space as the fill up coming down.Being attached to shopping mall is good and large 24 hour supermarket across the street.WiFi speed quite good.On our last night in Japan we came back to this hotel and got a room upgrade as our allocated room was right opposite the lifts/elevators. The room was much bigger but still tired looking. This was the worst hotel we stayed in, we stayed in 4 hotels in total.

We were warned that hotel rooms in Tokyo are small before we went, but we were still surprised as to How Small! That said, the layout of the room had made best use of every inch of the space. Our hotel was included in the guided tour we were on, so I don't know if in terms of price and value how this hotel compares to other hotels in Tokyo. But the room and the hotel in general was very clean. Mostly large groups stay there and for that reason you will always have a long wait for using the elevator and you often will have to let go of a couple full elevators before one that has room will stop for you.The breakfast was my least favorite of all the hotels we stayed at on this trip to Japan but it was still good, more expensive foods were not included in the breakfast buffet.The location is good if you would like to be walking distance from the vibrant and action packed part of Tokyo, but not the more high end areas.

It is a great place . I like the location, it is the best and at the center of many things like shopping, cinema, and other kind of entertainment for anybody. The staff is very nice . When we got sick , they did everything they could to help us to find an English speaking doctor . And it was just before a holiday in the evening , and they did it. We have stayed there numerous times and every time if we had a problem , they would fix it right away or/ and even upgrade our room for a better one without extra charge , being sorry for the trouble . Great restaurants with authentic dishes and very interesting presentations of them. Attached to a Mall and I think is one of the best out there. Lots of things to do . Will come back to this place again , like we did before .

37-storey hotel in the middle of a busy district close to train and metro stations. Small but well-equipped rooms. Good wifi. Excellent Japanese restaurant. Also Chinese restaurant, which we didn't frequent.

This hotel has a good location, adjacent to a large shopping mall. The rooms are adequate and bed comfortable, however there was no storage. Lifts tended to be packed and very uncomfortable. As for breakfast - on the first day we stayed we had to queue for 15 minutes and then there was an inadequate supply of food and coffee. The staff seemed overwhelmed by the number of guests. The next day was slightly better but still seemed to take a long time for items to be replenished at breakfast.

I booked renewed room located 10-24floor according to the pics showed equals 15000 jpy but checked in at 7th floor. Infront office lied to us this is renewed room but actually it’s not. Now we have to pay extra fee for updating room. Infront office provide very bad service and the attitude is really bad. Such a terrible experience.

I spent 5 nights at Sunshine City Prince Hotel and was pleasantly surprised by all the conveniencies around the location - shopping centre, lots of restaurants and entertainments that you visit without even leaving the building complex. There were no wardrobes in the room but later I found out that was typical for other Japanies hotels as well. Breakfast was good.The only disadvantage was the long queue and waiting time in front of the elevator. It took me more than 30 minutes one morning to get down with the suitcases from the 20th floor.

We travelled last month for the Cherry Blossom , which was magnificent. The staff at the hotel do not speak much English so its useful if you have an interpreter. Ask for a room away from the lifts as this is a very noisy area.Do not expect help with your luggage. There is enough room in the rooms to have built a small wardrobe but as this is used by the Chinese a lot they do not think it important. No matter how early you go down for breakfast the Chinese will have been there before you the noise level and free for all takes some getting used to. There is not enough staff to replace food that has consumed by very hungry Chinese so when its gone its gone.The coaches have difficulty waiting outside so you may have to walk a short distance with your luggage.The dinner's are very much the same. Its a great hotel for loosing weight..Do not let this put you off Japan. an amazing country, culture and people.

31 March-9 April. Floor 25 and 37. We stayed in two different rooms. The first one was big (25 f), great view. The second one (37f) was small but renovated, amazing view. They cleaned everyday, satisfied shampoo etc, very polite and helpful. Breakfast is fine but you can always take sth from the mall next to it. The airport bus stops at the hotel as well. Good value for money!!

Stayed in this hotel for 6 nights for our family trip to Tokyo. The shuttle limousine between Narita airport and the hotel was handy. Hotel is within 10 mins walk from JR/Metro station. We were lucky enough to be upgraded to a bigger room and that was good. Room cleaning was a problem. The used glasses and cups were not cleaned or washed. Things got worse on the third day when we were back at night as we found that a bag of garbage was left behind the room! There is a convenience store inside the hotel and that could well be the busiest Family Mart around!

I spent two nights at this very bland hotel. It forms part of a large shopping and office centre. The main users appear to be large groups travelling together. From the outside you would not suspect this was a hotel.Check-in was quick and efficient. Plenty of lifts took us to the 19th floor quickly and quietly. My room was typical of single accomodation in large chain hotels throughout the modern world, as such it was comfortable to sleep in |(I ws very jet-lagged) and not much more. No where to open suitcase except on bed. Restaurants for breakfast and dinner were all cafeteria style, and bland as the dishes they served. Thankfully we did not have to spend much daytime in it.

Very nice hotel, clean and exclusiveWhen i stay it was 2'C and the heater works very wellThis hotel also connect with mall and tokyu store..walking distance to Ikebukuro street where you can find Matsumoto store, ABC mart, Uniqlo, etcHas a 24 hour mini mart name Family Mart then you can go anytimeBest choice for stay in Tokyo

We stayed in this hotel for 3 nights. It is centrally situated to reach all the tourist sites of the city. The underground is walkable. The hotel is also built into the complex Sunshine city shopping mall and there is an entrance from the hotel itself. It is an extremely busy hotel with lots of tour groups. The reception are extremely efficient and even though we couldn't book in until 2pm they did give us our room just after 1pm, which was a bonus after a 13 hour flight! There is a safe storage where you can store or leave your luggage. There is a lovely cafe just off the reception that serves snacks and drinks and cakes to die for!! There is also a convenience store in the hotel which sells sandwiches and salads as well as hot and cold drinks. It has a wide selection of food to cater for tourists.The rooms themselves are small by European standards. There is no storage space whatsoever so you have to be canny with your packing and general organisation in the room!! The bathroom is compact but has everything in it you want. A generous toiletries tray, lovely shower and hot water and hairdryer.There is a kettle and tea but no coffee or milk, so if you are a coffee drinker you need to bring your own and coffee whitener. If you don't like drinking out of green tea bowls it is worth packing mugs and a teaspoon.The restaurant gets VERY busy for breakfast. As we had to be up early we got there as it opened. It's a bit of a 'bun fight' when all the tourist groups arrive and they do limit entry as service progresses and it gets more crowded. Variety is good and it is heavily ladened with Japanese food.There is a limited selection for the western palate but cereals, fruit, yogurt and a kind of cooked breakfast is there.Remember this is Japan and be prepared to try different cuisine.It was generally quiet at night except when big tour groups come in late and do make a racket. If you are a light sleeper take ear plugs. Upper floor rooms are better away from the lift area. The views are over a heavily populated city.We enjoyed our stay here and would thoroughly recommend it.

You can grab a shuttle right outside the terminal to the front doors of the hotel for about 3100 yen, which takes about an hour. First impression was how stunning the lobby is. We were excited to see the rooms as we had understood that hotels in Japan would be much different than in Canada. Understatement of the year. First of all smoking is rampant in Japan so just accept that this gorgeous country reeks of cheap tobacco. Stepping off the elevator was a shock, old faded carpets in desperate need of cleaning. The room was clean, with many amenities including a courtesy smart phone. Unfortunately my 6’5” husband could touch either side of the room when standing in the middle, and frequently bumped his head the first few days. Our room definitely smelled of stale old cigarettes (was advertised as a non smoking room) Our friends in the room next to ours had issues with their AC so in addition to the cigarette smell also had a sauna. The hotel includes a breakfast buffet which when we ate in the upstairs restaurant was lovely, however if they say they are full and try to take you to the downstairs restaurant REFUSE! It was disgusting. I don’t understand how there was such a stark contrast in food quality! Amazing plus is that the hotel is attached to the sunshine city shopping complex which features numerous shops, restaurants, access to metro, and entertainment. The hotel also has a very convenient little store in the lobby. A big negative was the shuttle to get back to the airport was full despite us checking early in the morning. Book that early! Staff were friendly and helpful.

This has been described previously. Sunshine Prince Hotel has to do better regarding the ventilation. It is April now. Outside is cold but the rooms are stuffy! This is my first stay at Sunshine Prince hotel, although I have stayed at many Prince Hotels all round Japan.

This was the first hotel in a long stay while visiting Japan. The pictures looked amazing and the reservation lobby area was very nice. But when we got off the elevator it all kind of stopped. The hallway was musty and the carpet needed to be cleaned. The room was nice and clean and quite.

The Sunshine City prince hotel is an great find, because it is attached to the sunshine city mall where you can find anything from food, entertainment, and clothing .. Outside the hotel /mall it also full of stores, restaurants, and entertainment. The hotel was a bit hot, but we were able to ask for the AC to be turned up. The staff was welcoming and kind and eager to assist. Another pro was the airport limousine bus picks up and drops off in front of the hotel, so no lugging luggages on trains. I would stay there again ! Lastly, it is an amazing VIEW from the top floors!

I just finished 3 night stay in the hotel. We came to the hotel late evening every day but still had heat problem in the room. As others mentioned, the rooms are tinny, so we had to leave our clothes in the suitcases. In the room are coffe/tea facility, hair dryer, and a free cellular phone to use during your stay with full internet and local calls. Short distance from the hotel is a Bussines area around the Ikebukuro station with shops and restaurants. 37 floors of the hotel are on the Sunshine city mall with selection of shops and restaurants. My main complains are: There are 6 elevators (one of them to the VIP rooms at the upper floors) but we had to wait always long periods for them. Most of the stuff does not speak english but try to help. They supply purified water to the coffee cattle, but it was not done every day.The Yamanoto JR line takes you to the attractions of Shibuya, Shinjuku and many other places around that circular line.

Nice place to stay. Big and clean room. Connecting with big shopping mall. The shopping mall has lots of food to offer. However, the shopping mall close at 8pm. You can also walk to the train station which is at another shopping mall. Around 10 mins walk. The hotel also near lots of shops and other restaurant.

The room is bigger than we expected. Clean and has space for our luggage to lie flat on the floor. Downside is, we cant open the window in our room. Granted that the weather is cold outside, we still need some ventilation. there was no air coming our of the air vent.

Stayed here a couple of nights for a short holiday to Tokyo to shop and eat! And also to catch up with local friends.Couldn’t have chosen a better place to stay!I usually stay Shinjuku and Akasaka area but Ikebukuro was vibrant and full of amenities and things to do.Landed early into Haneda and check in strictly adhered to for 2pm (as usual for Japan). So dropped off my luggage and explored the area.Reception was friendly and also wisely cautioned me from going too early to Shinjuku as the trains would be packed until after 10am.It was quite pleasant to walk around the area and look at the thousands upon thousands of office workers streaming to work. Managed to see a few places open for breakfast but caved in and walked into a Starbucks for coffee.Came back at 2pm to check in and was swiftly processed.Room is compact but functional and very clean. I was given a renovated room with a double bed on the panorama floor and what a view! Could stare at it all day till night!The hotel seemed to have rectified the ventilation system and also had a cooling humidifier placed in the room. So no issues with too stuffy rooms.Definitely can open up my huge luggage with ease but maybe because I was on my own. Can be a little squeezy with two persons in it.Hotel had a Family Mart convenient store in lobby level and that was extremely helpful.Airport bus limousine from Haneda also dropped and picked up right at the hotel.Hotel was linked up to the massive Sunshine City shopping mall and was an easy 10-15min walk above ground through much shopping and restaurants to the train station.Tokyu Hands, Seibu, Tobu department stores all nearby. I counted at least 3 Bic Cameras in the area and more than 15 pharmacies selling beauty products etc.Ikebukuro is only one stop from Shinjuku so that wasn’t a problem if I wanted to get out of the area. Highly recommend the hotel. Staff were friendly and efficient! Stay was comfortable. Extreme value for money in my opinion! Definitely will be back!

We had arrived to the hotel rather late as we had travelled to Kyoto and left Kyoto quite late to utilise the maximum time there before heading to Tokyo. The hotel staff were still there and very helpful and got us to our room in no time!I had plan my Japan trip quite late and many hotels were sold out I went with Sunshine as my sister had stayed here before and recommends, I had to stay 1 night in a lower level (hence cheaper) room for the 1st night and then the rest of the week I stayed on a higher level (more expensive) room so I can review both.Both are just as great, if i had to point out the difference would be in the cheaper room you have a desk and chair, also cheaper branded shampoo and body wash. The expensive room you have a table and sofa instead with branded shampoo and body wash and obviously being at a higher level amazing views of tokyo (ikebukuro) both day and night views!The best thing about the hotel is that it is connected to Sunshine city shopping centre so (be aware later time this entrance is closed), the other good thing is outside of the hotel you have 24hr Seiyu which is like a huge convenient store great for late night snacking and sweets for gifts!You can also purchase airport bus tickets from the hotel at the reception and you just wait outside.The hotel is quite a walk from the main Ikebukuro station roughly 10-15mins but you are surrounded by so many restaurants and shops! Also many arcades which i loved the most!I would recommend this hotel if you are looking to stay somewhere connected on the JR line, quite central and bustling area but the hotel is far enough to be quiet. The hotel isn't the cheapest but i felt it was worth it!

It's a good hotel, probably some will be disappointed about the size of the room (if you stay in a single or double bed), but the overall service qualities, and with the integrated facilities of entertainment nearby, this hotel is one of your good options of staying in ikebukuro area

The hotel is located between 2 train stations. Walking is a little bit far but still manageable. The shopping center attached to it is very convenient for food etc. Depending on where you want to visit, you either walk to Ikebukuro main station or East Ikebukuro. Paid washing machines are convenient and working well. This is a plus point if to stay longer in Tokyo.

We stayed here Sept '16 and Feb '18 so I feel I can give a pretty good opinion. I'm going to start with the negatives in case any of them are deal breakers. Storage: there are no drawers or closets. Our second time we did have four hangers for jackets but that's about it. Plan to keep your clothes in your luggage. Trash: This is kind of a weird negative, but the trash can they provide you is incredibly tiny. For all the bottles of water we were chugging and the onigir wrappers from breakfast we constantly have extra bags stacked around the can for housekeeping to collect. Temperature: it is incredibly warm in this hotel. Granted, most buildings in Japan are, but even staying here in the winter we were constantly sweating. They provide you with a humidifier than can run on just fan mode and there's a switch on the wall for a fan but even with those blasting 24/7 and the shade always down, it was incredibly warm (my normally hard shea butter was liquid). We bought ice to put in front of the fan and pretty much stayed naked whenever we were in our rooms. Also there is no ice machine so plan to purchase ice from the konbini. This is probably the biggest issue I have with the hotel. That all said, this hotel is so convenient. Being attached to such a large mall means you can get almost anything without even stepping outside. Book stores, clothes, candy, restaurants, toys. We buy a lot when we go to Japan and so it's great to have such access to so many stores. The ikebukuro station is also fairly close. It took us a couple days to realize that you can do a lot of walking underground. On the first floor you can walk a bit and come out near Tokyo Hands. Then a little bit past that take the entrance to Tokyo Metro. Even if you're using JR that passage will connect eventually. It's a lot quicker and great for when it's freezing out. Another convenience is the konbini on the first floor. We bought from there almost twice a day for our week stay. Too tired to eat at a restaurant? Konbini food! Blisters from walking? Bandages at the konbini! End up with tonsilities(my poor husband)? Masks at the konbini! Friends back home want to try weird kitkats? Konbini! Can't find something but see it on Amazon? Order it and have it delivered to the konbini! For us, the convenience of this hotel makes the negatives worth it.

I couldn't say the hotel located on best location but it's one of great choice. Limousine bus to Haneda Airport and Narita Airport are stop right in front of the hotel. But It's take time walking to train stations. The hotel connect to Sunshine City which is good for shopping and kids friendly. The room was nice and there is convenient store at the lobby floor.

Been to Tokyo many times but this is the first time I stayd in Ikebukuro area. The hotel is quite nice. The room is clean despite of its small size which is usual for hotel room in downtown Tokyo. Less than 10 minutes walk to Ikebukuro subway station and Sunshine City Shopping complex. Actually it is connected to underground walkway leads to a few number of restaurants and shops. Quiet sufficient amenities in the room with free wi-fi, a very very small fridge, hair dryer, free? looked alike mobile phone "handy" provided in the room for taking out for (snapshot) or what ever,did not have time to look into !! . Breakfast is Japanese style with a few western dish such as macaroni, bacon,sausage,broil cauliflower flower & broccoli, and pancake. For Japanese soup,rice, boil rice with lots of condiments- varieties of pickle veggies, boil mullet fish, sweet Jap.omlette, pickle plum to name a few. Should have more fresh fruit other than banana and grape fruit dough. Worth the price to stay.

Horrible hotel. Double rooms are in fact single rooms with an extra bed. Presence of one chair and one bed lamp confirms this. No wardrobe, no shelves or drawers for clothes and personal effects. There are two(!) clothes hangers per person and nothing more. All personal things have to be kept in the suitcases.No traditional for the hotels special places for suitcases, no even space for them. So suitcases lie on the floor, occupying an already minimal free space.Cramped incredible. Awful soundproofing: being in the room, full of the illusion of being in the bath room (when the second person is in); the text of conversations in the next room is hearable; from closing the door in the next room your bed is jumping; noise of the elevator is also heard.But the main thing is awful air conditioning system (windows do not open). The room has nothing to breathe. It is stuffy and hot. No fresh air, no oxygen. It looks like the hotel air circulates in a circle. And no climate control. So you are unable to regular the temperature, this is already decided for you.Maybe I do not understand the format of this hotel. Perhaps the absence of many basic things, without which, in my deep conviction, it is impossible to stay comfortable, is the norm for the hotel?.. Perhaps...You can relinquish something, forgive something, but not lack of ability to breathe. Without air, staying at the hotel becomes unbearable.I am 61. I have no health problems. I have visited over 40 countries. I stayed in the very different hotels: luxurious and poor. But no one offered me impossibility to breathe.In Dec, 21-31, 2017 I got my 2nd personal experience with this hotel (room 2230). My 1st one was in 1990, 27 years ago. Prince Hotel - the worst of those where I have ever stayed.And now I say to myself: NEVER AGAIN!

Surprisingly the Prince hotel is newly renovated. The size of Renewal Deluxe Twin Room is good enough to open 3 big luggages at a time. With an excellent location, it's convenient to JR station. And you can grab what you need as they have a 24-hour convenient store next to hotel lobby.

A large hotel, almost 40 stories high. Very quiet rooms with views over Tokyo. Interestingly we could not find a bar, so used the one on the top floor of the shopping centre next door (this also had excellent and even higher views). Sometimes the restaurant was busy at breakfast, but quickly turns over and a table becoming quickly available. There was a wide range of Japanese and non-Japanese items at breakfast. Omelettes made to order. A good start to the day.An evening buffet was just okay.There was a lack of a shelf or just somewhere to place a few belongings in the bedroom.A limousine bus from the airport stops here. Even with it being the first stop, there was heavy evening traffic congestion that day and it took over an hour.There is an express lift to the top floors.A post office across the road enabled stamps to be bought for postcards.The roof of a building opposite seems to be for training drivers how to drive!

Very clean room, but very small space for 2 people with luggages. It has FamilyMart near the lobby, so it’s great not to leave your hotel for food. Near to Sunshine City and Ikebukuro, very enjoyable hotel.

Tannertan
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I stayed at the sunshine city price hotel for 4 nights as a solo traveller during my trip to Japan in November. I flew in to Haneda airport which was quite convenient as there is a limousine bus that one can catch from the airport that stops at the hotel. The location of the hotel is very convenient as it is attached to the sunshine city mall and is a short walk to Ikebukuro subway station. The area surrounding the hotel (as well as the sunshine city shopping mall itself) is lively with lots of places to shop and eat. The hotel itself had a lot of amenities and a convenience store on the ground floor which was quite useful. The room I stayed in was clean and tidy and the bed was quite comfortable which meant a good night’s sleep. The room itself was not very large, but this being Tokyo and for the price I paid I thought it was quite reasonable and being out sightseeing all day, all I needed was a safe and clean place to sleep at night. The only drawback I might mention is the lack of any cupboard/shelf/ drawers where one can put some clothing. There is a clothes rack with some hangers, but most of the clothes I had didn’t require hanging. The lack of any wardrobe space meant that all my clothes had to stay in my suitcase for the duration of my stay. Apart from that and considering my stay was for only 4 nights, this didn’t bother me too much. Check in and check out process was smooth and the staff were friendly and helpful. All in all it was a very comfortable stay and very good value for money. I would definitely stay here again next time I am in Tokyo.

The smart phone in the room help me when I shopping and lost the way home. Besides; the room is very modern and it was comfortable to sleep inside. I feel great to live in the hotel such this.Thanks for the services.

We stay for 1 night only, because we join the tour.. it was a small room, but it was cool.. there was a bathtub even in small size.. they provide shampoo, conditioner and the bath soap in an unique container. But i forget to capture it. This hotel connected to mall and there was a Family mart inside..We were going to Hachiko Statue at Shibuya, we took train from Ikebukuro Station. We reach Ikebukuro Station by using Taxi. We spend about 570 Yen. And we buy ticket for our trip, the fee was 170 each trip/person (Ikebukuro-Shibuya Station) and 170 Yen also for getting back to Ikebukuro.. Maybe you can use this advice to go to Hachiko statue from this Hotel..

Stayed here for 3 nights on a Wendy Wu tour of Japan. Small but clean rooms, no wardrobe or drawer space so had to live out of suitcase which was fine but not a lot of space for two cases but we coped. Bathroom also small. Rooms were very warm too and there didn't seem to be any way to cool it down. Wasn't over impressed by dinner (only on the first night), in the canteen like restaurant. Thought breakfast room was much nicer and catered for most tastes. They also did take away tea & coffee which was a nice touch. Lifts very fast which were needed in this busy hotel. Very centrally placed hotel so easy to walk to shops & restaurants.

Large hotel seemingly catering mainly to an Asian clientele. Large lobby with a couple of benches but no proper lounge area. Very courteous hotel staff however, a bit weak on English conversations skills, very typical for Japan. Very clean premises throughout. Our standard twin room was quite spacious for Japanese standards and had 2 large beds, a spacious desk with integrated power outlets, refrigerator and TV, but no closets or drawers – it is obviously designed for short stay guests willing to live out of the suitcases. The oddly elevated bathroom is very small with small mirror and very little vanity counter space, but has a good sink and curtained tub/shower with good shower head and water flow. Good buffet breakfast served in the restaurant to the side of the lobby. We spent quite happily 5 days in this room. The Ikebukuro train/subway station is about 10 minutes walk away and on that way there are plenty of restaurants and more in the mall.

This hotel had its better days. First used this hotel in the early 1980s. It was at its best then. Today, its decoration looks tired. Facilities are rather outdated. But that said, it still has something to offer.First of all, it is connected with airport buses from Narita and Haneda. For those with kids and or a lot of luggages, it's convenient. It is 10 minutes' walk from the JR station but it is not difficult to find the direction. Second, it's connected to a shopping mall. Good for some last minute shopping. And of course, many places for food and coffee (even a convenience store just 30 seconds from the lift lobby).Room is small but that's normal in Tokyo. Otherwise, it's OK. You'll hear noises from the corridor. There are many tourists joining package tour to stay here. So there will be kids and people going out early. There will be noises. But I had a good sleep.I didn't try its breakfast. Plenty to choose from in the nearby areas.Not bad.

Great service! Fascinated by Handy! Never saw anything like this before. What a novel and unique idea! Pity that we spending only a day in Tokyo. This will certainly attract visitors to your Prince Sunshine City hotel. God bless!

Built above and as part of a shopping complex. The room was fine, but small, wi-fi worked well. Beds were comfortable and tea and coffee making facilities were good. Breakfast was very good with lots of choice. We had one dinner in the hotel which was only OK, but I believe there're other restaurants within the complex. We were part of a Wendy Wu tour so joined with the rest of the group. The staff were helpful.

The hotel is connected to a shopping mall, which is convenient to shop and eat. A convenience store is available inside the hotel lobby. Room is clean but may have some noise when people walk pass. It takes around 10 mins walk from train station to the hotel which may take time to get to the hotel.

We were booked into this hotel for three nights before embarking on a cruise around Japan and across to South Korea with Princess cruises.We were in the hands of Wendy Woo Tours.The Hotel was very good and the staff were very friendly. Our twin room was clean and fresh with an amazing Japanese style toilet. (having one installed at home now :) )The hotel has direct access to an large shopping mall where we found many excellent restaurants for dinning.The only downside was the breakfast. The choice was strange for western pallets and the food was not very warm with limited choice. This might have been because we were on a package with Wendy Woo. Though that in its self should not be a reason for poor standards.We found the location fine for our needs being on organised trips and ventured out on the streets to take in the local cafe bars and shops which we found all in walking distance.Except for the breakfast it ticked all the right boxes.

Kevin J
Doncaster, England, United Kingdom

review_body: A very busy hotel, connected to Sushine City Mall. Hotel room was clean, and reasonable space for a standard twin, but no closet to hang clothes. There was no a/c as the hotel switched to heating, but hotel provided a fan so able to stay comfortable. Buffet dinner in Bayern Restaurant was mediocre, sparsely served, eg., beef carving was pretty good slice of roast beef, but the tempura selection was limited. Crab legs included in the buffet line, served cold. However, the breakfast buffet in the lobby restaurant was pretty good with a variety of Japanese and western options. Since it’s connected to Sunshine City, lits of dining options and a short walk to Ikebukuro train station.

Rooms at Sunshine are well-maintained, modern and nicely-sized on Tokyo standards, bright and spacious. SomeHave a good view - rooms on the non smoking floors are definitely better. Housekeeping very efficient and super friendly, too.In house restaurants offer a lot of choice, along the tons of restaurants in the adjacent mall - it makes for a lot of options. The hotel also has a very useful family mart on the ground floor.Otherwise, staff more or less friendly with various levels of English... Staff isn’t the hotel’s strength as it takes such an amount of time to even get an question answered although 6 people are standing in the lobby. Wifi problems for 5 days without solution or compensation. Altogether a very good standard, good hotel - just average service.

Found this hotel to be very good. The room was clean and well appointed with an excellent shower, great hot water. Check-in staff were attentive and efficient. The one criticism was the lifts. It took 25 min one morning to go from the 20th floor to the lobby as all the elevators arriving on the floor were chock a block full. It seemed only 2 or 3 elevators were working. Our room was not cleaned on several occasions when we came back early (2.30pm)Breakfast was included and was good value.

The hotel room was very good but breakfast was just average. Adjacent to the mall so shopping and eating places were very accessible even late at night. However, the nearest train station is at least 500m, which is not ideal if you have kids. We were happy with the hotel room and the beds, which were very comfortable.

We stayed here for 5 night after our Disney trip. It's a decent hotel. Since it's a Japanese owned hotel chain, the room was small in comparison to the American chain hotels (i.e. Hyatt or Westin)We liked the accessibility of the hotel. I enjoyed shopping at the mall. There was a toys r us in the mall which we spent sometime in there. There was an aquarium at the mall but we did not go. Plenty of food options around the hotel. We also enjoyed the hotel breakfast. It was not a huge breakfast buffet. But it was nice enough. There was a convenient store in the hotel. A supermarket was just across the street to the entrance of the hotel.The airport transfer which the hotel offered was convenient for traveling with children.

stayed 3 nites here for group tour... room is clean & spacious for a japan standard hotel... complete amenities in room with bathrobe & shiseido body wash, shampoo & conditioner! buffet breakfast selection is good with japanese & western selection... staff is polite & friendly but speaks very little english... there's a family mart in the lobby & entrance to sunshine shopping center... overall good stay...

I stayed in this hotel for 4 nights in August 2017 beginning 6th August during a 10 day group tour from Sri Lanka. The hotel was very comfortable and luxurious for the whole tour group. The meals were also very nice and the staff were very hospitable. It was from this hotel that we went on tours in Tokyo area. I recommend this hotel for anyone who travels to Japan.

The room was fine. The location good.But the deal breaker is no air conditioning controls - just a dial saying "air volume control" with a low, med, high setting and NO TEMPERATURE SETTING. So many complaints about this. On an Autumns night the room was so hot I couldn't sleep.Also overheard a very condescending Indian man at the reception in handle of talking to English with customers. He was very unprofessional and dismissive of the lady he was serving. She was turning to me in disbelief.Kuuki ga Yomenai 空気が読めない

I have stayed in this hotel maybe 5 times since 1997. This was my best experience so far. I choose this place for a few reasons. it is located next to a shopping mall and very close to the Sega/St Tropez arcades which I still love going to 20 years later! The bus from the airport stops here. Also Ikebukuro station is useful for access to everywhere in Tokyo.The online price was very good as I booked way in advance.The check in process was easy. The guy spoke decent English (my Japanese is terrible). As I had booked on their website and signed up to the member program I was offered free breakfast. He also lent me a USB charger for my phone which was super handy as I was ill prepared. The room I was given was on the top floor - 37. There is a lift that services the top few floors only which is a nice touch. 37 can be accessed from the other lifts also and they are pretty efficient.Obviously as with all of Tokyo the room was pretty compact. I have stayed in smaller though. The room has been renovated since my last visit and had a great view. There isn't any storage but they have some hooks on the wall with about 4 hangers. There was a Nespresso machine and kettle, free water. The bathroom was big enough, every free item you could think of. Comb, brush, toothbrush, hair tie, razor etc. Plus free slippers!! Good hairdryer!! I didn't see a control for the air con. It wasn't too bad but may be an issue in the hot summer.Breakfast was interesting. They have the usual continental options but also bacon and eggs, salad, pasta and fries! I tried a few of the Japanese options also which were very nice. There is a Family Mart on the bottom floor which is open 24 hours. Unlike the usual hotel shops, they don't inflate the prices here. Great range. There is also an ATM here which accepts overseas cards. Min 10,000 yen withdrawal.If you are coming from Ikebukuro Station take exit 35 for the hotel and follow signs for Sunshine City. I usually take the escalator down next to Tokyu Hands and follow the signs for the hotel. I don't actually know the other way but I dare say you cannot miss the building!! It is the white building next to the huge one. The mall is great for shopping, aquarium, Namja Town. Lots of food options from 11am-10pm. Nearby is Seibu department store, check out the cake section on the bottom floor (can access from station). I also noticed a rabbit café opposite the Sega arcade.

This hotel is built in and around the Sunshine City shopping centre with direct access to the centre from the ground floor of the hotel. There is a small convenience shop just inside which is quite useful. The hotel, like most I saw in Japan was clean and efficient, the staff were courteous and helpful. Our room was on the 24th floor - I must admit to taking a step back when I opened the curtains. It was a long way down and there was no balcony or ledge. The room was small but adequate with dressing gowns, slippers, hairbrush, toothbrush, razor a kettle and a fridge, green tea was provided but no coffee. The bathroom was typical Japanese 'pod' style about 4' square but at 6'2" I found it OK if a little cosy. Beds a little hard but again OK, pillows which for us are always an issue were a little on the firm side. Irons and ironing boards along with the ubiquitous vending machines were available on each floor. The rooms have little storage space and only a small hanging rail. There are free safes in the room and the free WiFi is quite reliable, air-con was passable but could be an issue in hotter weather 22c for us. Don't know about the TV as it was never turned on. The buffet evening meal provided a good range of options - not surprisingly mostly with an oriental twist. Breakfast was also buffet style, the restaurant can get busy at peak times but was not really a problem. The main issue was that the hot food wasn't - lukewarm at best unless you had an omelette. Coffee machines were also a bit slow. As a transit hotel it was fine, comfortable enough with most facilities and easy access to Tokyo, it is not a place to stay more than a few days in my opinion, built for speed rather than comfort.

A comfortable hotel albeit small rooms which is typical of Tokyo. All necessary amenities in the room, bathroom with adequate bath and tea / coffee facilities.No lounge or bar in the hotel which again seems to be typical of Japan.Breakfast was good and choice of restaurants for lunch and dinner.

A family of four, we stayed here for our first night in Japan before going on to Nagano and it was perfect. We considered staying near Tokyo Station but we had already spent time in Tokyo in the past and also had a weekend in Tokyo planned prior to our departure. The train from the airport was easy, but the train station is so massive that even though we had researched the walk from the station to the hotel it was late, confusing (we exited on the wrong side of the station and had to walk around), and took a little figuring out. Finally, we found an entrance to the mall. On the positive side, our kids loved walking through Sunshine City at night (child said "this is just what I imagined Tokyo to be like" when we passed the Sega store...). The mall is massive and instead of walking through the mall we could have probably gone a block or so and crossed and been at the hotel entrance, but live and learn.Check-in was very efficient. The room was on a high floor (no need to check out the observation tower!) with a fantastic view. While there was a tour group waiting to check-in we were helped very quickly.One of the reasons why we selected this hotel (beyond access to Pokémon) was that it slept four people (which is rare in Japan). We had a corner room. To the right there was a mini refrigerator, mini-freezer, an electric teapot, and a variety of amenities. There was also a long couch, coffee table, and flat screen TV. To the left was a luggage storage area, toilet room (awesome Japanese toilet!), and a bath room with an enclosed wet room including a very deep soaking tub (maybe the best ever) and then a dressing and getting ready area with a ton of amenities. In the corner was a separate enclosed room with four beds. This sleeping room was fantastic because it got very, very dark. The beds were twin sized but they could be pushed together if needed. Each bed had a night stand with reading lamp and again amenities were plentiful.We LOVED this hotel. My husband and daughter got up early and went across the street to Family Mart where they bought cup of noodles. They could sit in the TV area and make and eat their noodles while my son and I slept obliviously in the sleeping room. Each of us took a bath in the soaking tub which was incredibly refreshing. Regarding location; the mall has a variety of restaurants and the first night we were there we ate in a tonkatsu restaurant that everyone enjoyed. While waiting for the Pokémon store to open we also checked out Namja town and J-World and walked around the area. There are a ton of different anime and electronic stores and we wish we had more time to see them. Our train left from Ikebukuru station in the early afternoon. The Pokémon store was the main attraction and being able to stay right there and be at the biggest store was a huge hit with the family. So, yes, we chose our hotel because of proximity to the largest Pokémon store in the world.Family Mart (open 24 hours)

Fifth visit in two years: we stay here because it is close to where our family lives. It has gone downhill since Seibu emi took over the Prince Hotels. First, English language skills at front desk limited to none. Then, they refused to honor a breakfast offer for Seibu members which I received as an email. True: it required reservation to be made on their website, but this stipulation was in tiny print at the bottom of the email which barely printed. When I told them I didn't realize the requirement, showed them how this restriction appeared on the otherwise large font advertisement, they wouldn't make ANY accommodation. Room was even smaller (but same category) as last visit. No place to store clothes. No shelves. No nothing except a desk top. Four hangers for two people in miniature closet?Fourth, in breakfast buffet, the help was overwhelmed by number of guests. Tables left with dirty dishes the whole time we were there. No server offered coffee. Egg preparation chef was swamped and slow, so forget an omelette made to order. Even hard to get a fried egg. I tried twice. Always gone. Bottom line: don't stay here. It's not worth the headache, hassle, language barrier problems, unfriendly management. Oh. And I forgot. Lots of travel groups with children and adolescents running around at all hours. If you're used to even a modicum of peace and quiet at the hotels you usually patronize, you'll be sadly disappointed at this place.

Horrible hotel! 1) I came with a group of 20 people 2 persons per room so I had the opportunity to see all the rooms and the air conditioning didn't work in any of them!2) the rooms are all very dirty and old!3) lets not even talk about the bathrooms! "my toilet even has #2 on it"4) although our floor (27) was non smoking it smelled like the inside of a smoking room because people smoked in the hallways like if it was normal5) fridge doesn't work 6) location not to bad(Don't know much) but not very pretty "Low class Japanese area"  If this is your first and maybe your last time here please stay in a better place!!!!!!

Location is not ideal , 10 minutes walk to metro station Room was OK and breakfast was good but a bit expensive , hotel is integrated in a shopping mall , not that many restaurants for breakfastMore a hotel for business men than tourists

I chose the hotel despite the relatively high price because I was travelling with my parent who has arthritis and therefore, limited walking mobility. The hotel has a direct limousine bus from both Narita and Haneda airports which is so convenient and negates carrying luggages up and down trains. The staff was polite and nice when checking in and helped bring our luggage up to our room. We took a high floor room which was located on their panaroma levels from 33th onwards and it was worth every penny. Fantastic view! Room was small of course but that's the way it is in Tokyo hotels. The 24hr Family Mart at the lobby was useful for amenities that we forgot to bring (hairspray, haha).And best, it's located next to Sunshine City with several entrances leading directly to the shopping complex itself so my parent can shop and eat to her heart's content without over-tiring her legs. Plenty of resting spots inside Sunshine City so it's great for seniors and children. There's an observatory and aquarium as well if you want to do some touristy things besides shopping and eating. The surrounding area, Ikebukuro, has tons of shops and eateries to explore too with the nearby Tobu and Seibu.Downside is if you want to use it as base for going to other parts of Tokyo, it is at least 15-18mins walk to Ikebukuro Station. You will need to walk out of Sunshine City (5mins), walk to an underground station tunnel (10mins) via Sunshine Doori street, and another 5mins or so to reach the actual station. Not really as near as said but Ikebukuro Station does have most of the major train lines needed to explore Tokyo. Another alternative which is slightly nearer is Higashi-Ikebukuro Station linked directly via an underground tunnel from Sunshine City and about 10-13mins walk. But only one line, Yurakucho Line, runs there and it does go directly to Shin-Kiba Station where you can switch to the Disneyland monorail. Despite the inconvenience to the train station, still recommended highly for Sunshine City, Ikebukuro, lovely staff and room view if you're high enough!

Stayed here for 4 nights, booked the high floors twin bed room as the cost is just slightly more than the regular twin bed room, but it's worth paying because they have an exclusive elevator just for going up to 31 floors and above (quicker and away from tourist groups who stayed on lower floors), a nice city view of Ikebukuro, quiet, and a spacious room and bathroom (compare to other Japanese hotels). No wardrobe, but have small hanging space by the wall outside the bathroom. Always have 2 complimentary bottles of water, an electric kettle, and a coffee machine. Best part is it has direct shuttle bus to and from Narita and Haneda airports. If you signed up for Prince Emi Card (their membership card) during your stay, you can enjoy a bus ride to Hakone at 1000yen per person per one way, but do make the reservation at least 1 day in advanced, the bus counter opens between 7:00-20:00.

Located above the Sunshine City mall, Prince Hotel brings everything you need within a stone's throw away. The mall has lots of restaurants, gift shops and entertainment options.The staff are friendly and accommodating despite the language barrier but are firm in enforcing the hotel's policies. The hotel lobby is spacious and modern while the rooms are a bit outdated. The room and bathroom were spacious by Japanese standards and was a welcome surprise. The mini ref was a bit too tiny and no free bottled water which I normally encounter in hotels of the same caliber. Bathroom water pressure was strong but sprinkler hose type shower head was a little bit difficult to maneuver as it would turn on its own when the shower was on. Buffet breakfast area had nice interiors and had a reasonable spread that everyone could choose from. If you don't get to catch breakfast, there is a Family Mart on the hotel's ground floor where you can buy a variety of hot and cold food as well as other goods and even souvenirs.There is a machine that can change $US to ¥ yen on the ground floor in case you need local currency right away. The nearest Metro station is not too near nor too far to walk to, but passing through the Ikebukuro shopping area made the walk less noticeable. The hotel is also serviced by the Airport Limousine Bus so that getting to and from the airport is hassle free. No need to use the train, unless you missed the bus which departs on an hourly schedule. I would definitely return to this hotel, especially to bring children, as the rooms is spacious and the mall next door has a planetarium and aquarium and other child friendly activities. Overall I am happy with my stay, all things considered.

Sunshine City Prince Hotel位在池袋地鐵站, 約要走路15分鐘才到. 延路是經過sunshine city 60通往飯店, sunshine city 60通整條路都是熱鬧的商店和餐館. 可以一網打盡想買的物品. 另外, Sunshine City Prince Hotel位在Sunshine City百貨公司內, 裡面有許多服飾店, 雜貨店, 和餐館. 對面也有超市. 每天回飯店, 都覺得很快樂. 我們是住二張單人床的房間, 乾淨! 早餐雖然要價2000日圓, 若能機+酒含早餐, 他們的早餐真的很好吃!

First of all, let me get this out of the way. The great thing about this hotel is the fact that it is located/connected right next to the Sunshine City Alpa. Everything, and I mean EVERY thing that you could possibly want or need is right next door. There is a 24 hour mini-mart located within the hotel for all your necessities. The train station is less than a ten minute walk, what more could you ask for?Unfortunately, one of the biggest things I was silently asking for I did not get. It is Tokyo after all and space is at a premium. The room we got had zero space to move around and everything was cramped. You literally had to live out of your suitcase as there was no space to even set aside clothes to wear for the following day. The restrooms were also quite small and there was really no place to put your sundries or cosmetics or anything like that. One other thing that got to me as well was the fact that I could not adjust the airflow or thermostat. I mean, there was a switch but it was in Japanese and even though I played around with it, I noticed no change in air flow (minuscule) or temperature. Thankfully the weather was deliciously cold, it being Springtime and all but I wonder if it was different during the summer months.Otherwise, it was a pretty nice and clean place, inside and out. Breakfast was passable. Nothing great but not terrible either. The thing that made me say this hotel was average was that we got a good rate for it (about 25% off the normal price). If we had paid the true price, I don't think I would have been too happy.Bottom line: If you can get the rates for a very cheap price, do it. If not, then seriously consider other places.

Stayed in May timeframe. Room temperature was always warm despite having AC. Pillows are very small and very thin. Breakfast was included in our rate and was good. Egg station with omletes or fried eggs. Buffet had scrambled eggs that did not seem to be cooked enough. Coffee was good, no sweeteners so bring your own. Hotel,is inside mall so very convenient for shopping and restaurants. Ikebukuro train station is within 5 minutes walking time. Free wifi is available and was very good speed.

Hey, what's going on guys. I would like to let you all (especally Thai people) that I did figured out another restaurant with the crab. The restaurant I mentioned is located at the underground. It might not be fun without windows to see some views but you might want to enjoy the crabs there. I was with some Thai friendlies and saw them enjoying their crab. I ate it as well. This crab was totally juicy and I loved it. You better not miss it guys. You can make a reservation by call, or maybe by the email as well.

We arriced at the hotel for a two night stay to find reception was efficient and we soon headed for our room on the 8th floor, well it turned out to be more of a box room, very small, but the main thing the bed was confortable. Next morning we headed for the lift to go to breakfast, it was chaos every lift going down was packed. After trying to get on a lift going down for ten minutes we got on one going up. We went all the way to the top and then down again, stopping at our own floor we saw people who had been waiting with us still there. At last we arrived on the ground floor and joined the queue for breakfast it took about 15 minutes to get a table. The breakfast was fine, but we did have to rush as we had transport booked. The following day we just jumped into the first lift that was going up and avoided the long wait, but again a queue at breakfast. After 9am the lifts flow freely it is just first thing when they do not have the capacity.
