John G
South Walsham, United Kingdom

review_body: The hotel was clean. But the thermostat didn't work, poor insulation, one could hear babies crying in next room., no wardrobe, very small rooms. We waited up to ten minutes for a lift. The breakfast was in a basement cafeteria, type restaurant, again huge queues. The hotel is situated up to 15 minute walk from the train. The area is suitable for teenagers,not over 65's. Loads of shopping areas and fun parlours for teenagers.

it's been a couple of weeks since I was @ the sunshine. even though the staff does not fully command english true thrived to bring an excellent service and they did achieve it. i was there for about 7 days and can not complain of anything. of course you should know that in Japan spaces are quite reduced and you know what to expect in hotels, so keeping that in mind the service was quite good.only thing I advice to travelers staying here is to leave your room 5 minutes in advance when you are to go somewhere as elevators can get really crowded when the tours hit the hotel.

It is a normal hotel for its standards, the only drawbacks are that rooms are a bit small and in my opinion it is a bit far from the interesting parts of Tokyo. The positive aspect is that it is next to a Mall were you can have plenty of food and there are several shops and metro station that connects with the entire city.

Rooms are small but clean. Rooms are renovated since I last visited a few years back so everything looks new! About 10 mins walk from Ikebukuro station. Direct link to Sunshine City. Provides airport limousine bus service for direct transfers to and from the airport. Across the road is a row of anime shops. Lots of cafes and food places nearby. Liked that they have an Animax channel.

We came here in 1983 and we're not impressed. The room was so small that we went onto the bed from the washroom.33 years later, the building is dated. The room is actually spacious and well maintained. The location is close to Ikebeuro station. For 5 minutes walk, there are endless cafe and shops to explore.

This is my second stay and stayed here for 5 nights. Clean & basic room. Room can be quite warm at times. Check in was fuss free. Location is ok even though it was a 10 minutes walk to the train station. Reception area is newly renovated and looks better than before. There is free shuttle bus service to Seibu Departmental store.

Rooms were very small. No drawers, no wardrobe and insufficient room to place two suitcases on the floor. Inadequate lifts - and the stairs between floors were alarmed! Breakfast satisfactory buffet style. No lounge nor bar but there is a coffee shop.

The hotel is nicely located in central tokyo. Good jumping point in exploring Tokyo. Hotel is nice with ample size room by japanese standard. The breakfast was acceptable. The staff was superb. However when we were there, there were a lot of group checking out at the same time that the elevators seemed inadequate to handle the volume of clients.

We stayed here during a 5-day visit to Tokyo and had a wonderful experience. Our visit was for our honeymoon, and the staff kindly upgraded us to the Panorama floor for free and left a really nice handwritten card in our room.The Panorama floor was amazing and the view was just spectacular. We even went up Tokyo Tower and felt our hotel view was better! The room and bathroom was also a great size, with good amenities like a sink outside the bathroom and a big couch along the wall to enjoy the view. Breakfast was great with both a Japanese and western section. The hotel provided bottles of water each day, and the laundry services were great (washer-dryer combo with soap for 500Y). It has a convenience store inside that's open 24/7 and sells most of the essentials (travel items, meals, snacks, drinks, alcohol, etc). The front desk can provide free umbrellas when it rains. Two things worth mentioning, though. First, there is a wide disparity between the different types of rooms. We walked through one of the lower floors for the laundry and the hallway was very outdated and seemed not nearly as nice as the Panorama floor. Second, it is a good 10-15 minute walk to the Ikebukuro train station, so maybe isn't the best pick if you're planning to do frequent journeys each day on the train or want to come back to the hotel often. Overall, though, it was a great experience and we really recommend, especially the Panorama floor :)

Hotel is attached to Sunshine City Mall. Rooms small basic but efficient and clean. Seems to host a lot of tour groups. When busy extremely long waits for elevators. Stayed here as part of a group tour. Breakfast is good with variety but offerings never change.

This was close to the subway and it was easy to get onto the line to see some of the highlights of Tokyo, including great places to eat. We were warned the rooms would be small, but compared to Europe they were not that small. Clean comfortable, with full amenities. Breakfast was included and provided a choice of Japanese or western cuisines. No bar for a drink though. We found out later we could have gone to the shopping mall next door to the top level to see the lights of Tokyo.

It has a nice location , clean rooms, cute bathrooms. It has a lot of guest quite delaying in using the elevator. Even in breakfast buffet we had to line up because of the volume of guest. We love the family mart just downstairs very convenient.

Stayed here for 2 nights before embarking on a cruise, Reception and all other public areas were modern, clean and kept in excellent condition. The rooms though still needed to be modernised and were very small and dated, though they were kept very clean and tiny. The service from all staff on Reception and dining room was excellent and they were all really friendly and had excellent english. The hotel is situated in the Sunshine city complex, so there are plenty of shops and restuarants in the complex, it is also close by to 2 metro stations, so getting out and about isn't a problem. Only downside to hotel, is that it's slightly out from all the major attrations and you definitely need to use the Metro to get around.

An OK place to stay. We came here with a tour group. The staff were really helpful. Double room was just big enough and the nice surprise was that the beds were about 4 feet wide. Dinner and breakfast buffets had good choices.

We stayed at the Sunshine City Prince Hotel as part of a tour group. We were told prior to our trip that the rooms were small, but the travel agency books the hotel because of its convenient location. It is connected to a HUGE shopping mall with LOTS of shops and restaurants. It is also connected to a subway station. We had a room on the 16th floor, and it was sufficient for a 2-night stay. We have stayed in much smaller rooms in Europe and in NYC, so the size did not bother us. There was no closet, so it might be a problem for longer stays. As with other hotels in Japan, the hotel did provide a lot of toiletries (toothbrushes, hairbrushes, razors, shampoos, lotions, etc), robe, slippers, hot pot to brew tea, etc. Negatives for us were the hard beds (extra extra firm) and crowded elevators. When we tried to go down, it was full from upper floors. We finally had to go up to go down.

This large hotel (more than a thousand rooms) is attached to a large chopping centre, and so convenient for finding restaurants and shopping (if you need that). While the Ikebukuro Station is not that far away, it is also not necessarily that convenient. There is a lengthy outside walk to get there and if it's raining (as it was for us), it makes it not so convenient. It's also not so close if you have any accessibility issues. The staff are friendly and helpful. Even though they couldn't fulfil one of my requests, they didn't in the most polite and apologetic way. Overall, it's a worthy hotel and if you're mobile, and the weather is fine, the walk to the station isn't a reason to not stay here.

Nice hotel. ..Sure it's small but not as small as you think it's going to be.... as people say how small tokyo hotels are...comfortable...very clean...friendly staff....when you pay pay in yen as cheaper...nice view of the city....like 10 minute walk from train station...

The Hotel was excellent, very clean and the staff extremely helpful. We had there Buffet in the evening and it was very delicious..Nothing was to much for them and I highly recommend it. Also there was a big shopping center near it, so it is in a verry convenient position.

Lots of shopping opportunities on-site. One can walk underground to Higashi-Ikebukuro subway station. There didn’t seem to be an underground walkway for the short walk to the JR Ikebukuro station. This hotel has a nice breakfast buffet but it can get crowded with some wait times depending on how many tours are staying there. WI-FI in the room worked great.

Stayed here for a week as I had a course to attend. Rooms are fairly small with no wardrobe space at all. I stayed in the twin room as I had to share with a colleague. The main problem was there was no space literally to store it clothes. There's a shopping mall on the ground floor of the hotel which is convenient. However, it's about 15 mins walk to the train station which is kind on inconvenient if you have loads of luggage to carry about.

OK for a Japanese hotel with small as ll grooms and frenetic breakfasting arrangements.However we and all colleagues found bedrooms too hot and uncomfortable. Airton did not work at all. Fan offered was useless.Also only some lifts working and lift waiting times are just too long.

This hotel located in Ikebukuro area, not so far from shinjuku. you can take Train or taxi. this hotel have a large lobby so its possible to handle group checkin. and this hotel have convenience store located in lobby floor.

We visited for two nights at the start of our holiday in Japan. The location was ideal for touring the city, being just 10 minutes walk from the major station at Ikebukuro. Our twin room on the 22nd floor had extensive views over the city. Although on the small side the room had all the facilities we needed, including two good sized single beds.The buffet breakfast was plentiful and varied. We also sampled a set meal at lunchtime which was excellent value at around £10. Even more so as we shared one between us. The staff were all very helpful and charming.The hotel was very clean and well-maintained. Our room was rather warm - though we think this was because the air conditioning was not yet switched on as we visited early in the year and the weather was unseasonably warm.

We can look at city view from the window of hotel. We can walk around the hotel for shopping and there are many restaurants under ground floor. Staff can speak English very well and very friendly. That's the good place for foreigner.

As usual staff are friendly and helpful. 5mins walk to the nearest mrt. Hotel is within a big shopping mall where you can shop n eat. Familymart is inside the hotel so anytime you can get a quick bite. Airport shuttle bus reach directly infront of the hotel and takes around 35-40mins to reach from Haneda Airport.

Direct bus service from Airport , save the hassle of dragging your luggage across stations...3rd stay in the hotel already, improvement stay after stay, especially this time after renovationAlso, show your room key to some shops in the mall for 10% off !Excellent services from front desk and housekeeping !Will stay here again for sure !

Hotel is clean and safe,, very friendly staff..Facility is provided to leave your big baggages at the hotel when you want to travel to other city light. Family mart in the hotel and smoking area at the lobby. Smoking rooms are available.. but as all Japanese rooms they are very small unless you upgrade your room.

We came to see my son for Christmas and decided to all meet in Tokyo. I had never booked at the Sunshine Prince Hotel and as always going into another country, you are always worried if the pictures were true to real life. But we were very happily surprised, the hotel was great! We upgraded to the Newly Renovated Rooms, 33rd floor and up, and it was worth it! It is a very clean hotel, we had paper slippers to use and a bathroom was on our bed. The bathroom was kept very clean with all types of extras, even bubble bath! I definitely recommend this hotel. The only exception to note was that there was no central heat or air, just a humidifier, this can be used as an air conditioner, but does not make the room very cool. So a suggestion would be bring lightweight sleepwear, even in the winter and maybe pack a top sheet, as they do not provide one, just a comforter. But do not let that stop you, it is a great hotel.

Every time we go to Tokyo, we like to book this hotel because it is at good location with valuable price.Location: The location is good for people taking limousine bus as it is linked the hotel to and from the airport. Besides, it is only 8 mins walking distance to Ikebukuro Station, it is convenient to take JR or metro to other places.Along side with the hotel, it is a shopping mall "Sunshine City" where you can shopping and dinning there. Also, there is a 24 hours convenient store at lobby floor and a large supermarket near by.Reception: The attitude of the receptionists, lobby servers and porters are good, polite and helpful.Room: We stayed at the high floors “Panorama Floor”, which is renovated with a better view. The room is narrow and in rectangular shape. The size is acceptable, as it have space to open three big luggages. Besides, it also provide the facilities which five stars may have: nesspresso coffee machine, air purifier, bubble bath gel and many toiletries in the washroom. Conclusion: We satifield the hotel' services and facilities. One thing we would like to recommend to the hotel is the room should better have a small dinning table with chairs or at least have 2 chairs. We need to ask the reception for one more chair last time. It is not convenient for two people in the room with one chair only.

We stayed 6 nights in the Panorama Twin A room and it was great. We arrived close to midnight and check in was fast and efficient. We had signed up online for the Seibu Prince membership to take advantage of better rates, and all this was processed on check in with no problem. Arriving late, we noted that the coffee house was closed for the day and the hotel did not have room service. However, there is quite a large Family Mart and this is open 24 hours a day. Managed to get some sandwiches and even a burger which the cashier warmed up for us. That did the trick for the night.The room was very spacious with a convenient little round table which served both as a work table and for having our breakfast. LAN connection was good and reliable. The row of sofa seats across an entire wall (with the windows) allowed our family members from other rooms to join us comfortably. What I liked about the bathroom facilities was that the wash basin is outside of the bathroom and toilet. In that way, the basin is accessible even though someone is taking a bath. The Shiseido toiletries were a treat. The little walk in wardrobe was well designed and could surprisingly hold a large luggage. One comment though, is that the bathroom is not level with the room floor. We had to take a step up of about half a foot to get in and step down when getting out. This may prove a little difficult for the elderly or less mobile. The hotel is connected to Sunshine City which is a large shopping mall with lots of food options. This was very convenient. Getting to the Ikebukuro station is a good 10 to 15 minute walk through the mall, depending on your pace. When we got back late a couple of nights, we took a taxi from the Ikebukuro station to the hotel. The fare was about 800 yen.Overall, we enjoyed our stay at the Sunshine City Prince Hotel.

I've been staying here for more than 15 years. Finally the renovations are all underway. The new lobby area is beautiful. I stayed on 35th floor this time in large double room. It was very good, portable AC evaporative unit using water helps cool the room and humidity it. Beds are great and nice linens. Large sofa seat along windows.Much more expensive than I've paid but worth the money. If you're staying, try to pay for the upriver renewal floors.

I really was not dissapointed, when I chose to stay in Sunshine City Prince Hotel at Ikebukuro, Tokyo, during my holiday with my family, even though for semi double room we booked seemed to be very small. But with all the amenities and the good services rendered, we really enjoyed staying at the hotel. The location was superb within all major shopping centers and the train station. There were two things happening that We will always remember and we should give the hotel big applause. First, when my wife left behind in the room her jewelry, the jewelry was still there untouched when we came back in the evening. Secondly, when we were beginning to panic due the strong earthquake on 22nd November morning, we soon heard the ennouncement to all room that all hotel guests should remain calm and stay where we are because the hotel is safe and earthquake proof. We could not imagine as foreigner, staying on 31st floor during earthquake without such announcement. We will share all the good news. Thanks to the hotel and staff. Wish you a Great Success!

The location is right at the shopping district of Ikebukuro. It is within walking distance from the train stations. It is connected to the Sunshine City Shopping Centre which has a lot of good restaurants and interesting shops.The hotel rooms are old. The hotel was undergoing renovation when we were there. So several sections were out of bound. The restaurant for the breakfast was under renovation, so breakfast was in the small function rooms.No complains though, since we were out most of the time, and only needed a place to shower and sleep.

Japanese standard for hotel and staying is something different,you must know about the smaller size of everything and more expensive fees,but be sure about the result,I mean quality, everything are in order.If you wanna have any business affairs in Ikebukuro district,it's the best choice with many facilities in Sunshine 60 building which connected to the hotel by underground passage.Subway is about 10 minute walking distance and some stores around provide you basic demands.

This Prince hotel is adjacent to Sunshine City and in business for years. No complaint about the location - connected to Sunshine City which is a nice shopping mall with average priced clothing and different choices of restaurants. Opposite to the hotel is a 24 hr supermarket which is fabulous. Do note the tax-free counter only opens from 10 am till 8 pm. Less than 10 minutes walk to Ikebukuro metro or JR station. The 2 large department stores Seibu and Tobu next to the station where you can spend 2-3 days for shopping.Rooms are very old except 33/F - 37/F. Stains are almost everywhere inside the room. The bathroom is kind of dirty especially around the sink. The corridor carpet is like 60's, faded and torn. Fortunately it's not smelly. I stayed there for 4 nights and would suggest at least give a little better room.

Was in Tokyo for a quick business trip and company booked me in the Sunshine City Prince hotel.......seemed a cheerful enough place when you read the name.......For convenience sake , its around a 10 min walk to the Ikebukuro station and plenty of shops and eateries nearby so quite nicely placed. Lobby was quite nice , a bit of nice panelling and mood lighting and staff were Japanese - so ever so efficient and polite.My horror started when I opened the door to my room , some countries this would be classed as a closet and not a room. It was small , pretty manky , and utterly characterless..........The furniture was cheap and probably brought in the Edo period , last century. Really nothing to write about positively about this room. I guess the only saving grace was the toilet , which had these ultra sensitive bidets installed..... Price wasn't cheap either ......... The hotel really needs to sort out the rooms otherwise its such a wasted talent of a hotel which is so nicely situated.

We had a huge, newly renovated room with separate living area at the panorama floor with city view with perfect view of sunrise. Toiletries provided are from Shiseido:), good size hair dryer, capsules coffee machine, etc.Hotel staff are helpful and friendly where most of the front desk staff speaks good English.Good location with 2 train stations within walking distance, direct drop off point for airport limousine.Right next to big shopping mall, Sunshine City, where the mega Pokemon center is located.Basically can get almost everything from food, clothing, electronic goods, anime items, etc within 5 mins walk. But must note that Japan hotel don't allow extra person in room as they basically charge by per person. If additional person need to stay, please get another room or you can request for an upgrade to a bigger room with a charge.They are pretty strict on check-in time, you will have to wait till 2pm if you reached earlier. Possible to request for late check out with a fee, when available.

It is located at the center of Ikebukuro, so it is convenient for me to go shopping or take the public transportation living here. The room is a bit small but neat and equipped enough. Each floor has vending machine. But the breakfast, which is the same everyday, is not as good as i think. And at the time i lived there, the hotel was under decoration making the lobby pretty samll and crowded. In general, i think it is not a bad chioce to live here while traveling in Japan.

Stayed here with a group of friends for a couple of days. They have a great buffet breakfast downstairs. The rooms are modern with sufficient space to move around, and the hotel is conveniently located near a Family Mart and Anytime Fitness gym. One let down was that the walls/sound proofing isn't too good. Was having a laugh with mates in our room one night and we were asked by Security to keep it down and that we were too loud, although we really weren't. Would highly recommend this place as it is connected to a mall, very convenient!

Hotel is very deceiving! Very flash and new from reception but the rooms were so dated and small. The halls and room smell strongly of cigarettes and the rooms even come with ash trays which suggests smoking is allowed... the bedding is very dated too. Staff friendly...but the hotel needs a lot of work..

Good location but very small rooms. Average breakfast. Staff are very friendly. Not really recommended except for it's very good location. This hotel is somewhat outdated and is in need of some renovations. As stated you have got to be impressed with the staff, they are so friendly and even though the English is a little 'broken' you have no problem communicating at this hotel. 3rd level food restaurants are good value.

This hotel was exactly what some people were describing it in the reviews I had read before my trip. We were there with a tour group, the staff is amazing and the entrance of the hotel plus location is great. The night we arrived we did not have any problems it was not busy and the had are key ready for us. When we went up to our room is just how it was described from many other reviews I had read. This hotel rooms are really old, they do smell like cigarette there was actually one night that the smell of cigarette was really bad and we were suppose to be in a non-smoking floor. But otherwise everything else was great, the room view was beautiful and staff as I mentioned before are really nice and helpful, oh if you are like me that iron all your clothe make sure you ask for an iron no rooms in any Japan hotel has irons.

This hotel is just a few blocks from the Ikebukuro station, on the north side of the Sunshine City mall. Four floors of shopping, restaurants, rental car, and attractions are all steps away without going outside. Our room was small, but modern and clean. The lobby is functional, busy, not a place to sit and relax, or to meet people. Plenty of English-speaking staff to get you settled. There is a service in the lobby to ship your luggage to the airport a couple of days ahead (good for a large family renting a car for an excursion out of town).The Sky Circus observation area is expensive and cheesy, but gives amazing views looking down on Ikebukuro's busy neon streets. The aquarium is small but interesting, on the rooftop. The museum is only when you run out of things to do.

The hotel lobby is under renovation, it looks better then its previous dated look. I was lining up to check in but they offered me a faster way to check in using biometrics. But the set up process took even longer than if I stayed in the queue. The Indian staff has no idea what to do and refused help from his Japanese colleagues. The room is so small especially when they put in 2 twin beds side by side. The reason why I stayed here is because my hotel of choice was fully booked, Sunshine Prince is always my back up plan as the airport limousine bus stops there. Location is relatively good as it is connected to a shopping centre with lots of shops. It is a long walk to the JR station.

This hotel is outdated and a bit old. I found the cleaning service to be subpar, really did not trust the cleanliness level of the hotel. Furniture and bedding are old.The hotel is attached to a mall which was convenient. I would not stay there again

Nice room, clean, safe.staff was good and helpful. There is a convenient store at the floor 1. Nothing to complain. But you have to walk to the nearest station. Not so far. The bathroom and the toilet is in 1 space. Quite narrow. I recommend this hotel

This is my second time stay in this hotel. This time I've stayed in this hotel for 4 nights in Semi Panorama Double Room on Panorama Floors (33rd to 37th floors) that just have a full renovation so the room was modern nice and clean with amazing view of the city. The room is quite big very comfortable for 1 people.The air-conditioner is set by the hotel you cannot adjust the temperature in the room you can set for high and low wind so it quite a weakness. During the stay it's was very nice room fully equipped with amenities, hotel staff very kind and try to communicate. Hotel provide free WiFi. Transportation is very convenience just 5 mins walk to JR station and also have a Airport Shuttle Bus stop and counter at the hotel. Hotel was connecting with Sunshine Department store that have a lot of shop and restaurant so it was a great spot.I hotel staff inform me that the hotel are now during renovation most of top floor room are done. the lobby and restaurant are now in progress.I'll recommend this hotel because it was convenience to transport travel and shopping.

I've stayed in this hotel for 3 nights ( leaving tomorrow) as part of an organised group tour of Japan. On a positive note the location is good the staff are really friendly, cheerful, and very willing to help. And free speedy wifi throughout hotel. However the room I stayed in on the 28th floor is in desperate need of a refurb. I acknowledge that in general Japanese rooms are smaller than I'm used to but this one is seriously small and stuffy with very dated furnishings.The bathroom feels like one on a cheap cruise ship but plenty of instant hot water and the excellent electric toilet. Why don't we have those in England! On balance disappointed and will register this with tour organiser.

The check-in process is a bit slow. The staffs are quite nice. Smile can always be found on their faces. The room is clean and tidy with nice air-conditioning. The only thing that annoyed me is that the height of the toilet is too short. My hands has always been hitting the ceiling during shower time.

We stayed in this hotel for two nights prior to our cruise. We were apprehensive however pleasantly surprised as we were anticipating a very cramped room. The room was small but perfectly adequate. The bathroom, also small, featured a nice shower and soaking tub. The view from our window on the 28th floor was magnificent. The room also included a mini fridge and tea kettle with complementary tea. The breakfast which was included as part of our package was expensive and included both Western and Japanese items. We would not hesitate to stay here again.

This hotel can be reached by the limo bus from both Narita and Haneda airports. The rooms are pretty much Japanese standard. We stayed in the older part of the hotel. The light design is very stupid. Either you turn on all the lights or none. So, if you are going to the bathroom at night, you're going to wake up everyone in the room. I have to use a flash light to go. Unbelievable. We were making use the subway to go everywhere. Just a little walk to the stations. Not too excited about this hotel.

Here near shopping place and have so big center in underground. Maybe you will get lost if you go the first. From here i go to Ikebukuro, famous shopping district, consumer goods, clothing, food and electronics functions...Yamada denki（山田電気) have so much cheap electronics

The standard rooms are very small, extremely dated, had stained bed covers that looked like they were purchased in the 1980's and to top it all off - had a heavy smell of cigarette smoke. When we requested a non-smoking room, we were informed that we would have to pay more money which is absolutely absurd! Surely in this day and age, smoking should be prohibited in hotel rooms and a few rooms set aside for smokers. Because it is not possible to open up windows, you are connected to a central airconditioning system that seems to draw the cirgarette smoke from one room to the next. Upon leaving the hotel, all of my bags and clothing stank of cigarette smoke and needed to be washed. Extremely disappointing.The lobby is constantly very busy with very large groups of tourists and the breakfast spread - of both western and eastern foods - is just above average. It is nothing to write home about.On a positive note, the staff are very friendly, helpful and kind.

Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: I was booked to this hotel because we have some business in Ikebukuro. The hotel is not modern, kinda old, and quite musty. The entrance to the hotel is just a door and it doesn't have the grandiose lobby I was expecting for a big hotel in Tokyo. The receptionist and staff were very helpful and they speak English. They were very accommodating when I requested for a room upgrade and when I need help on my Airport Bus Limousine.The room that they booked me was very small and old with dated furnishing. I was very uncomfortable with it so I booked for an upgrade for $25/night. The receptionists helped me with it so I was able to stay in a very nice Prestige Floor in a Double Room Type B. It was big, has nice view, with soft pillows and blankets. The washroom is also nice and had nice amenities.The hotel is connected to the Sunshine Mall and has a Family Mart in the ground floor for all your hotel needs. One thing good about this is hotel is its connection as a drop-off point to the Airport Bus Limousine to the Haneda and Narita Airports. It's very convenient and it's just a little bit higher in cost with the Narita Express.

I really love staying at this hotel. I would recommend this hotel to everyone. This hotel was recommended to me by a travel agency in Hawaii about 5 yrs ago,and ever since then I have been staying at this hotel,although the rooms are a bit small,this did not bother me because I was hardly in the room. The hotel is resonably priced too.This hotel is very safe and lots of things to see around and not to mention shopping! What I really like is that the staff at this hotel are very friendly and so helpful and will take care of you too.I noticed as I was leaving they were renovating the lobby. The next time I staydocome back it will be complete! This hotel has also a limousine bus service from and to the Airport. This is what I look for in choosing a place to stay. It is not very expensive to take the service. The train station is from walking distance and there is a park right next to the hotel if you just want to sit and relax. The hotel has a shopping tmall right in back of the hotel which is kind of nice to me because in case you do not owant to walk to thetrain station to take the train to go places or you are tired or in case it rains at least you have another option to shop. The entrance is located right inside the back part after you pass the mini mart. There are lots of restaurants in the shopping mall so no need to worry. There is also what Japanese call a police box right as you walk out of the hotel passing the park along the way so I feel safe and I don't have to worry about anything when I stay out late because there are lots of policemen here and there looking out for people. I like to take my trip in the summer time because there are always sales during that time. Also down the road as you walk towards the train station,there is a movie theater,and game centers where you can win prizes. This is something I enjoy doing,then a department store at the train station too.!

The hotel room is simple and clean but small compared with other hotels we stayed at but it was so convenient because it is connected to a large shopping mall with a food court. There's a food market in the basement so you can purchase bottled water and other food and snacks.

Not a hotel which caters to English speakers except for groups. But certainly acceptable. Small room, even with two beds. No drawers. No shelves in closet. Had to use smallish love seat for unpacked clothes. Restaurant in basement serves both Japanese and US breakfasts. Nicely situated near Sunshine City Mall and Seibu dept store. Near subway line. Stop for Airport shuttle bus. All in all, for reasonably priced, clean, convenient hotel..... Not luxurious. I'd actually give it 3.5 stars.

During our recent trip to Tokyo we stayed in this hotel for 3 nights and found the hotel of a very food quality. It has more than 1100 rooms and is part of a big complex which has shopping complex, entertainment centre and an office complex attached to it. Rooms are larger than normally in Japan and have all the amenities. Staff members are helpful but language for International travelers may be some problem

We spent three nights at this hotel and was satisfied with the hotel apart from the very poor air conditioning, which if you were visiting in the hotter months might be a problem. However the room was comfortable and clean with the usual tea making facilities,fridge and TV. The buffet breakfast was very good with a good selection of both western and Japanese foods. The hotel is attached to a large shopping mall with all the usual shops and restaurants which we found very convenient. All in all for the price we were very satisfied with the hotel and staff were always friendly and helpful, but often lacked good English, but this was not a problem for us.

We've stayed at this hotel our last 3 trips to Tokyo over the last 6 years (hey every other year ain't bad). Let's get to the pointsThe good:1. Next to the Sunshine City Mall/Observation/Aquarium. That means food and shopping right here.2. Female side of Otaku shopping if you are so inclined.3. Sunshine City Dori (street leading from Station to Mall) is littered with more stores and restaurants4. Station on the Yamanote LineCustomer Service at the hotel was good, decent English, but a bit slow.The bad:1. Long walk to the station, about 15 minutes with typical traffic.2. Not close to big hotspots of Tokyo, so long train rides everywhere.

Because I spent almost two weeks there in 1980, another two weeks in November 2011, and two weeks this April, I feel very much at home in Ikebukuro, especially the Sunshine Prince Hotel. The desk staff has excellent English; the lobby has several Internet terminals; the location is wonderful. That said, the Sunshine Prince has several disadvantages. While it was bright shiny new in 1980, it is definitely showing its age. I suspect that the carpeting and bedding is original to 1980. Because its rates for standard rooms are fairly reasonable, it attracts huge tour groups, which can make the lobby and elevators a mob scene. BTW, some reviews complain of small rooms, but there are large Western-style rooms at the ends of the building. The major drawback is that there is no air-conditioning, and the windows do not open. There is a promising little knob on the wall labeled “airflow” and numbered one through five. As far as I can see, it does nothing but entertain you. At my most recent visit this April, I tried to avoid this problem by going for one of their premium rooms that goes for about $300 a night. While indeed luxurious, there is still the useless little dial instead of real air-conditioning. I'd like to stay there again, but it would have to be in very cool weather.

Arriving in the morning after 30 hours of travelling, I had to wait a few hours to check in but the view from my room on the 26th floor was amazing. The room was smallish and the furniture a little tired but the bathroom was well equipped with toiletries and had a good shower; also my introduction to all singing and dancing Japanese loos! Good to find a small fridge in the room, if no bottled water; also a kettle with some green tea available - but no coffee

My wife and I stayed at this hotel as part of our tour package (#1) and we also stayed one night after the tour left (#2). Here is our review:Transport from Haneda Airport (#1): We took the Airport Limousine bus service from Haneda airport. The ride took about 30 minutes and the stop is right in front of the hotel. At the airport we went to the desk and the agent gave us a ticket and we then proceeded to wait at the stop that she told us.Checking in: No problems with checking in, since we was part of the tour group everything was ready for us. One unusual thing was the hotel card key had our room number and also the hotel name. We found this a little unnerving becasue if we lost our card key someone will know the hotel and room number. We did notice that when we checked in for our other room after the tour group, the card key was a regular one (without the room number) so maybe that is tour group thing. It looked like they had some new workers training so the person that was assisting us had some minor difficulties but the person that was assisting her stepped in and helped us.Lobby: It looks like the lobby area is being renovated but it was big enough to handle the crowds. Since this hotel is very popular with the tour groups it was pretty crowded when a group arrived. Elevators: The only complaint is when a tour group arrived and there was a mass number of people going to the rooms, there was a wait for the elevators. Plus some people would line up for the elevators while other people did not. Also one elevator is used for the panoramic floors which some guests did not notice the sign so that made it more confusing. Maybe it would be a good idea to have a staff member at the elevators when a group arrives so they can make sure everyone is in order.Room (#1): For the tour we was assigned a regular room and the size was small. After reading other reviews we understand this is a standard size in Tokyo, but after coming from the Prince Sakura Tower Tokyo where the size of the rooms are huge, it was a minor shock to see the size of this room. It took a lot of maneuvering but my wife and I was able to fit four suitcases and two hand carry bags in the room. The room had a desk on one side and a 20 inch tv and refrigerator which we used for drinks and snacks. The bathroom was a little small and there was a step up into the bathroom. The air conditioned was working at a low level even though it was at high. I noticed the room would get a little cold only after the ac was on for a while (couple hours).Room (#2): After the tour left we stayed one more night at the hotel. We reserved for one of the "renovated, panoramic floor" rooms. The room was nice, you could tell it was renovated but the size of the hotel was the same as the standard room. The difference is the bathroom was bigger because there was no closet (there was couple hangers hanging, which looked odd). Also in place of the desk there was a sofa and coffee table. The good thing is we could use the panoramic elevators. Amenities: For the tour we ate at the restaurants. The breakfast buffet was good, but after four days of eating the same thing I was glad to look for something else. We also had dinner which had Japanese items which was good. There is a Family Mart off the lobby which sold snacks and drinks plus other items. This was great to have this to buy items.Location: The best part is the hotel is located right next to the Sunshine Mall and entertainment complex. There are a number of stores and restaurants to go to. Ikebukuro Train station is about a 10-15 minute walk from the hotel and you walk through one of the shopping streets with Uni Qlo and Tokyu Hands. Bought quite a bit at these stores. I noticed there was also restaurants between the hotel and train station. Just a warning the streets can be crowded at times and with all of the lights it can look like Las Vegas but everyone is pretty cordial towards each other.Checking out: Checking out was not problem. It was great that we could check into the second room after checking out of the first room. We did not have to wait until 3:00, the staff was very accommodating. The negative was the check out time was at 11:00 am, so the next day we had to check out at 11:00 even though our flight was not until 10:00 pm. The hotel let us store our luggage as we did some last minute touring. But since we did not have a room we did have to change clothes in the restroom.Airport Shuttle to Airport: We took the airport limousine bus to Haneda airport. Advice, please make reservations prior to leaving and you have to pay by cash. Unlike the other hotel where you could charge this to your room, we could not do this.Comments: Due to the size of the rooms, I don't think we would stay here again. Everything else was great, I really liked the convenience of having the mall next door. But the size of the room made it a negative.

This place was always full of guests so the lobby was a little bit crowded. The lobby is simple but large enough for everybody, it has 6 elevators that can accommodate the bulk of the guests. The room is average but it felt homey and comfortable. We stayed at the end of the hall, quiet and well lighted. Their breakfast provided more choices of food that will fit foreign guests. Staffs were nice. Easy access to mall. Good enough for those who wanted basic comfort for accomodation.

We checked in this hotel as a part of Japan group tour of Kesari Tours, Mumbai on 31 May 2016 for two days stay. Grand Hotel with Grand Ambiance. It is located in central market area and has its own malls with 24 hours shopping facilities around with rail and bus stations. Rooms are finely furnished with A class upholstery. Just come and stay without bothering to carry any toiletries. Just add a bottle of face moisturizer please. We have to carry empty water bottles as the packaged water is not provided. However, tap water is safe for drinking and refilling in bottles.

Stayed one night at this hotel as part of a Wendy Wu tour. Hotel is clean, friendly staff and rooms OK but wouldn't want a long stay here. Buffet restaurant closes at 9pm so if you arrive after 8pm no chance of a meal here! Hotel is conveniently situated for the JR Station (just a short walk) and there is a shopping mall and several eating places right next door. Hotel seems to be used for business stays and school parties. Lifts a bit slow.

We stayed for 2 nights as part of a Wendy Woo escorted tour of Japan so Icannot comment on value as was inclusive of all hotel costs. The hotel is located in a multi level shopping mall where there was plenty of choice of places to eat and with my Japanese translation card I managed to find somewhere that I could eat gluten free which was a relief. The rooms are quite small but perfectly serviceable and free wifi is available there using code given on check in. There is a kettle and tiny cups provided along with the inevitable green tea. We used the mugs from the bathroom and our own coffee and I strongly advise bringing your own tea/coffee if visiting Japan and you are not keen on green tea. There were loads of things in the bathroom- toothbrushes, hairbrushesamd razors. There was plenty of shower gel and shampoo and conditioner. Breakfast was a mixture of Japanese and Western tastes so no problems and the chef came and talked to me about my gluten fre requirements which was very good. The hotel is about 10 minutes walk from the railway and underground stations and we used these to get around quite well but it is a challenge as English is not that widely spoken in Japan but everyone was so very helpful and friendly which was a great help. It is worth memorising a couple of words in Japanese like thank you as it is appreciated.

I have used this hotel since 2012, they have renovated their upper floors recently and are in the process of renovating the lobby restaurants. Just beside a mall and near Higashi Ikebukuro subway station (JR Ikebukuro station is about a 10 minute walk). Sunshine 60 building and Sunshine street are very nearby as well. There is a nearby 24 hour grocery and a family mart on the first floor.

Like how Japanese do it, no frills no non sense place. No bells and whistles, just an old clean room. Its clean and the size of the room is also good for couples who will be spending most of the day outside. I highly suggest though that the instructions be in English and also some of the network tv channels as well. We have yet to experience their breakfast food quality tomorrow.

The hotel is at a very convenience location, with convenience store next to one of hotel entrances, connected to a shopping mall, underground passage to a nearby shopping district. Then can reach a JR station within a short walking distance. Shopping mostly during this family trip so the location fits the purpose well, or may be because so easy to reach the shops ending up buying so many things :)This is not a fancy hotel but very reasonably priced for a hotel in Tokyo in the city. I suppose that is why it attracted all kinds of guests -- westerners, Asians, mainland Chinese and more -- individuals and group tours alike. Services were good -- both at lobby counters and for the housekeep. Japanese always does a great job in these areas.I shall definitely consider this hotel when visiting Tokyo again.

We stayed 5 nights, booked by our tour company. On the plus it was clean with a decent bathroom, and the breakfast was ok. However the room was so tiny we couldn't unpack and the air con didn't work well so it was stuffy. Being attached to a shopping mall was good - lots of cheap places to eat plus coffee shops. It's about 15 mins walk to the train station/metro and at least 45 mins to downtown Tokyo by metro so not a great location for sightseeing. The whole hotel is desperately in need of a face lift, it's so old and tired.

Nice hotel, good thing is there's a mall connected to the hotel and shopping centers are just few blocks away. Only 40 minutes going to Tokyo DisneySea and 2 hours going to Mt. Fuji . Rooms are nice though old but it was clean and bed is comfy.

We stayed in this hotel for four days and we loved and truly enjoyed its location! Why? The hotel has an access/ connected to the Sunshine City Mall with lots of shops and restaurants! Definitely guests wouldn't go hungry. You can also walk around the block and find a lot of shops. The train station is about 13 minutes walk which you wouldn't even notice because of the variety of shops and restaurants that would definitely steal one's attention. The Seibu Mall is also a walking distance to the hotel. Buffet breakfast was great with lots of variety of dishes. The hotel has clean rooms with complete amenities however the rooms and furnishings are outdated.

Sunshine City Price Hotel is where I've been staying since I was a kid, my Mum and I always stay here when we visit Tokyo. There are many nice hotels in Tokyo but we like it here because of the location. The shopping mall right downstairs is perfect for us, as well as the entire Ikebukuro area. However, it is a bit far from train station (around 15 mins walk), it can be a tiring 'exercise' every night with all the shopping bags you have to carry back...lolI like how convenient it is to get to/from airport, with Sunshine City Price Hotel you don't have to carry your luggage through train stations or up the stairs, the airport bus is right at the door step.The hotel itself is an old building, a lot of the rooms does seems a bit worn-out, but there are newly refurbished rooms available right now if you are willing to pay a little extra.

To put this simply, the room we got in this hotel was clean and comfortable, basic and nothing spectacular but it did the job. It is a bit small compared to rooms that you find in hotels of other countries but this is Japan, most hotel rooms are small unless you pay for an expensive luxury 5 star. The on-suite was compact but decent enough with a small bath tub and electronic toilet. There is a mall below the building which had some decent clothes shops and a Ghibli store! Across the road there is a supermarket to get your drinks and snacks and the hotel is within a close walking distance to Ikebukuro station. If you get a room higher up, you get a great view of the city from your window. The staff were friendly and polite and you can book a coach to and from the airport. I can't give this place more than 3 as it is just about right to rate it in the middle, it did the job for me and my wife without any fuss.

We spent four nights in the hotel.The hotel is close to the center of Sunshine city district. About 10 minutes of walk there is a subway station.Staff are nice and helpful. The rich breakfast includes Japanese food but also Western food.The room was a bit small but comfortable and very clean.We enjoyed ourselves from suspend hotel.

Great Hotel! Staff speaks fluent English and Mandarin so communication was really easy. We booked the newly launched and renovated Panorama floors that gives us the view of Tokyo Tower! A pity we were not given a room that can view Mount Fuji. Definitely go for the Twin Type A for Panorama floors as the additional space is good for the shopping hauls and lounging around the room. Hotel is very conveniently located right above Sunshine City which has everything you will ever need! Supermarket, Toys'R'Us, Fashion Stores, Disney Store (you can buy disney land and disney sea ticket here), Starbuck, restaurants, J-Town, Namja world, Aquarium, Observatory, the list goes on. Although the walk from Ikebukuro station is a little lengthy, there are lots of malls, arcade, pacinko and drug stores to make the walk interesting. Lots of eatery nearby as well that will cater to every cravings. Seibu and Parco are very nearby as well that can get all the Food Omiyake for your loves one back home. Room are very clean (guess the renovation contributed to that factor) and housekeeping staff are very thoughtful (they left out a kids amenity kit for us everyday during our stay).My little lamb had a ball of time crawling around in the room that is so spacious and truly felt at home.

I am sure the best rooms at the top of this hotel are superb, but on floor 10, the countless people who have passed through over many years have taken their toll. These rooms are exhausted. First impressions normally count but in this case, as you enter the hotel you are met with stained carpets and tired decor. This feels like the 60's - when this place must have been built and not renovated since,As you walk to your room, the carpets are stained and the walls chipped from countless bags. Every item of furniture in the room had stains and the beds, which bow in the middle are one step up from a camp bed. I know getting reasonably priced rooms in Tokyo is difficult, but really it is time the owners spent a little money on this shabby place. It's definitely somewhere you would never want to stay again - which is probably why it is so run down, because no one ever does.

We went with a tour group and this hotel was the first we stayed at after landing at Narita airport. Although the rooms are very modest and it is a no-frills hotel, the greatest appeal is that it is attached to a multi-level shopping mall with great stores, a 24 hour food market and a 100 yen store (Daiso) which makes it so very convenient after being on the plane for hours. There a lot of restaurant choices for dining as well as a food court.

From the outside, the hotel looks nice. We had a twin sharing room, it was small. The bathroom was likewise small and height of the ceiling is 6'4", my husband is 6' tall. The comforter of one of the beds has a stain and it looks like blood stain. The room was cleaned daily and the bed was made daily but the stain was unnoticed. The AC in our room was not functioning. We can hear the footsteps of the guests occupying the upper room. There are 6 elevators but only 2 or 3 are being used. Breakfast was good. The hotel is connected to a big shopping mall. Uniqlo is just 3 blocks away.

Location is great, friendly staff but very very small rooms and bathroom. No wifi in rooms, you have to go down to the lobby for the wifi. Hotel looks a bit old and the rooms furniture needs to be changed.

I really liked the location, there is a shopping centre directly connected to the hotel, as well as nonstop supermarket.I stayed in a single room, which was really small, but that was not a problem, everything was there. Bed was comfortable and even in a small room like that there is a plenty of room for bags etc.Very good breakfast service.

This hotel is in the Sunshinecity mall with many stores and attractions. There is a 24 hour convenience store in the hotel. The rooms are so small and need an update. The hotel lobby is so crowded with foreign tourist and reminded me not in Japan. The Ikebukuro train station is about 6 minutes by walk. There are many restaurants and game centers near hotel and my 18 American high school students loved the area.

its's a good and clean family friendly hotel. very conveniently located since its connected to the mall. however i do think it needs a makeover on the room, esp: furniture, bed cover and curtains. i find the bed and pillow to be a little uncomfortable. usually booked for group tours therefore the lobby could be quite full, i find it hard to find empty spot on the lift to go down in the morning since usually tour starts in the morning so a lot of people are going down between 8-9am

Large decently maintained property in outskirts of Tokyo. Plenty of items close and restaurants in hotel if you don't want to venture out. But go ahead and head out!!There are lots of good places walking distance.Enjoy

Whilst this hotel was clean & tidy I felt that it needs a bit of a makeoverAccess to shower is via step into bath which can be quite hazardous if you are elderly or of the larger proportionLarge tour groups abound this seems to be the ideal pick for them as luggage is scattered around in the lobby waiting to either come or go..Situated next to a busy shopping mall ideal to while away the hours before check-in or check-out

First time to Japan so we didn't need a fancy room since we knew we wouldn't be in it that often except to sleep. The hotel is not close to the major attractions eg Imperial Palace, Meiji Shrine but it is close to 2 subway station that it didn't really matter. It is located above the Sunshine City mall so you can just walk through the mall to access the subway station. Restaurants are all close by and shopping is great in that area. We didn't try any of the restaurants in the hotel but there is a 24 hr convenient store in the lobby that had some hot food and beverages. The rooms were older but clean and had Wifi

As my family arrived during the peak season of cherry blossoms, our original intended hotel booking in Shinjuku could not be accomodated. Instead as a “substitute”, we were given the Sunshine City Prince hotel. I never heard of Sunshine City before and as our trip drew nearer, so was my apprehension. But hey, never had I gotten a bigger blessing in disguise. We got 2 adjoining rooms in the panoramic 36th floor and everything looked new, clean, and even spacious for a typical Japanese hotel room. For starters, there were 3 pillows per bed which was quite unusual. Toilet and bath were expectedly compact but well compensated by the Toto washlet and the generous Shisheido amenities. An air streamer was provided to probably offset the numerous complaints about airconditioning. Right at the lobby was a 24 hour convenience store (Family Mart); you also need not leave the building to experience an aquarium, planetarium, an anime-inspired gallery, shopping (including a bookstore, a 100 yen store, a three coin store where everything is 324 yen), grocery, and restaurants. Within a short 5 minute walk is the Ikebukuro pedestrian shopping street and the namesake train station sandwiched by 2 large department stores. It seems like you are in Akibahara and Shibuya at once but with less chaos. I must admit breakfast is ordinary and the price to pay for such an ideally placed hotel are the throngs of tourists that crowd the lobby especially in the late afternoon you would think there is some celebrity coming over, not to mention the competition for elevator space. But such is but a small price to pay compared to the immense comfort and enjoyment my whole family has benefited from. And despite the constant harassment, the staff remain ever friendly, polite and attentive to your every need. Next time out, this will become my first option as my Tokyo residence

A hotel usually booked for group tours. You may notice a number of buses outside the building and a lot of luggage at the lobby. Nice cozy and immaculately clean room and bath. I liked their hotel shampoo and conditioner, my hair was really soft and smooth. Filling buffet breakfast - just make sure to come in early as the restaurant can be packed. Good location - near restaurants and shops. Very helpful staff - many thanks to the Front Desk Team for helping me out in my Japan Wireless pocket wifi ^_^

Stayed two nights here as a part of a group. Many of us had smelly rooms, perhaps caused by smoking in the rooms, not really sure. Some demanded new rooms. We did not eat in the hotel except for breakfast. The one advantage of staying here is the centre next door has many restaurants, and a metro station is quite close. The breakfast was only just adequate. However there were two grades of breakfast, and we got the lower standard. The lifts are overloaded, and on occasion took more than ten minutes to get one that was not already full. So if you have to stay here, I guess the higher the better as the lift is less likely to be full going down.

My school group was booked into this hotel by NTA. It is awful. If you have allergies.. stay away!!! The nonsmoking floor, particularly 8th floor, still is very smokey. Other non-smoking floors also smell of smoke. A Motel 6 is better than this place. It is hot and smokey. And the management is weak. Don't expect much from them. I tried to get our money back... that was "no deal". Avoid this hotel at all costs with your tour groups or individually... also there is a Boy Book Store around the corner.. less than desirable location. It is connected to the Sunshine Mall, but there are many hotels connected to malls via the underground. My group was moved to another floor, but that floor smelled of smoke the next morning after our first night on the that new level. The non-smoking is not "non-smoking." The hotel, in general, needs updating as well. I am sure at one time, it was nice, but it is long overdue for an overhaul. My first room was so very small and had what looked like bloody hand prints on the wall. That was creepy and the room felt strange to me.

The hotel photo are a bit deceiving. The rooms are clean but need a major refurbishment. The rooms are stuffy as the air-con does not work as it is still winter apparently and have not done the switch. Airport drop-off and pick-up is at hotel. There is a family mart within the hotel and convenient to buy stuff that you have forgotten or a midnight snack. Trains are within walking distance and is covered, so convenient when it rains. Breakfast is simple and adequate. Staff is helpful. The lobby can be very busy as it has a lot of tour groups.

Very small room that needs new furniture; the current pieces are really beat-up. The room should be for one person only. The breakfast was just OK and the service is excellent. I liked the location on many transport lines.

As said in the title, everything was really good apart from the air conditioning in the rooms. Got really really hot at night :( apart from that, breakfast buffet was really good and loved the fact they had a 24/7 mini mart down stairs with almost everything you could need! Would stay here again. Good location, 10 minutes away from tube station and situated attached to a shopping mall.

I was here from three nights for a short trip to Japan.I wanted a hotel that was easy to go to and with good access to shopping and transit.The Sunshine Prince Hotel delivered what I needed.It was on the Airport Limo bus route and a 10 minute walk to the Ikebukuro Station.It was one block from a 24 Hour supermarket and had a Familymart in the lobby.The hotel was directly connected to the Sunshine City Mall and there were many shopping and dining options nearbyWhile the rooms were basic,I believe that location and access to shopping and transit compensated for this.Tip I joined the Prince Loyalty club 2 hours before checking in and got a 3pm late checkout for free,Staff was helpful and I will admit I only ate breakfast at the hotel.There were so many great food options nearby.I will defenitely return

rooms are clean, staff service is good and some spoke perfect english. it's right beside a huge shopping mall with a wide variety of dining options. one disadvantage- the lifts are really really slow. we were rushing to get our luggages down to the lobby so that we can load them onto our coach. every lift was full, and it took really long to reach our level.

Hotel is located 15mins away from Ikebukuro train station. There is airport express bus to and from this hotel. Tickets can be purchased at the lobby. Room is small but equipped with basic necessities. It is located above a shopping mall which has Jworld, pokemon center and disney shop. There is a Owndays spectacles shop where you can make glasses and collect it as soon as in 2 hours. Cheaper than Singapore and good service provided. There is a family mart near the lift lobby of the hotel. Good food can be found at the shopping mall above the train station.

Went here during winter. As with most Japanese lodgings, you get a functional but no frills establishment. Main lobby looks uninspired. Room has small floor area, dated interiors. All of the amenities are available at your disposal. I appreciate the modest wifi. Place is packed with power outlets for all your charging needs. Toilet is the usual high tech Japanese bidet. The main benefit you're getting here is the strategic location. There's a mall in the complex and its just a walking distance away from Ikebukuro shopping district.

We were in twin sharing arrangement. The hotel rooms are a little small but very clean and cosy. For people who are fussy as to cleanliness may blindly book this hotel. The buffet breakfast was delicious. The plus point of this hotel is that it is linked internally with a mall. You may do quick and good shopping there. We visited in early Feb so there was a huge sale. There is also Sunshine Aquarium and planetarium which is a must visit for tourists. Overall, a memorable stay!

Overall had a great experience here, hotel is in a great location very easy to find and access but the rooms are a little bit dated as are the bathrooms. The customer service was excellent and they were extremely helpful and pleasant!! The views from out room were also really great!! Would stay again.

Best 1. for location near by two train station and airport bus route Best 2. It sits on a huge mall yes no need to make another specip trip for a casual shoppingBest 3. Family mart right next to the elevators... if japanese food disappointed you or need something late at night its there.

too many tour groups, lobby is constantly crowded and noisy. the only upside is probably the location, a 5mins walk to 瓷带 station and where all the action is in this area. the hotel room is tiny and old, a renovation is really needed. Personally, will not opt to stay here again.

I was Stay 5 Night, 7 Jan 2016 to 12 Jan 2016, live in 2027 room. I need to use the vacuum for pack my clothing into the void storage bag at 11 Jan 10pm, So I call to the admin say i need vacuum, but the staff English is very poor, I Just use very simple English talk with him, he don't understand what I am talk about, he just say "housekeeping?", I Say yes, because I try to explain to him, he also don't understand, When another staff come to my room, he use very bad attitude talk with me and he say you just can use vacuum few minutes because now is night, i say ok, no problem,thank you. But he also said "I waiting your room outside when your finish" . What? waiting outside, I have very bad feeling, that will give me pressure, and I see that the staff showing very dissatisfaction on he face. The staff name call Mr.加藤. He let my trip remain very bad memory. I will never choose Sunshine City Prince Hotel (Ikebukuro Tokyo) again.

Hotel is in good location - walking distance from ikebukuro train station and shopping malls and eateries. Connected to Sunshine City shopping mall, a huge mall with everything you need.Busy lobby with many tour groups. Rooms are small,aged looking with smells of smoke even though supposed to be non-smoking rooms. Not a comfortable stay.Concierge staff were helpful but most could not speak English well.

The staffs are friendly and some can speak mandarin very well. This hotel is Strategically located with restaurants, Malls and shops. The room is small, worn out and a little pricey. Walking distance to nearest Sunway station is Ikebukuro around 10 minutes walk. There's another Sunway station Higashi-Ikebukuro but never get around to use that line.

Hotel is getting better. The new renovated rooms on top floor are really nice. I'll book that next year when I return. Wifi throughout hotel finally! Rooms still way too hot and air is stuffy. Beds in older rooms still suck as well. Terrible mattresses. Service was better this year. Breakfast buffet seems to be going downhill. But convenient location.

Relates to standard roomRelatively small room (compared to international standards).Good beds.Bathroom with bath and shower.Very large and crowded hotel.Brakfast buffet: good choice of international and Japanese food. Restaurant not very comfy.Convenience store in hotel.

This hotel is close to downtown and surrounded by many super market and stores .it is also close to Metro and JR train station. there are limousine bus that will take you from Narita Airport .The room was a bit small but all complementary are good and enough for you to have a good rest. Breakfast were not bad but they will not change any thing..all crew were nice , friendly and helpful .

Stayed here before years ago, but recently stayed here again with friends. The hotel is quite old with really small rooms, but it's expected for the price. Hard to lay out two luggages in the room.The location is a plus though, since it's connected to the mall and there's so much to walk outside on the streets. Great for shopping lovers. You might even catch the ramen cart outside at night!

We were given a choice between this and another hotel nearby in Ikeburkuo and we straight away jump into Sunshine City.!Have stayed here twice in past 3 years. It is within Sunshine City and the Sunshine Dori (Tokyu Hands!!) is such a happening place. One've got immediate access to not only the large shopping mall but also a private Museum, an aquarium, a planetarium and even a movie theater, plenty of shops selling stuff at reasonable prices. Just that the shops close pretty early! Beside the Lawson at entrance there is also a Seiyu 24-hrs supermarket just opposite the hotel hence made ready-purchases a breeze! For the bigger Department store of Tobu and Seibu. It takes at least 10 minutes to walk toWe did not try the buffet breakfast as there many other options available...Tully coffee, just nearby. The room was small, but comparable to nearby ones which we have stayed. Upper floor has a better view and we are luckily to have some far-views of surrounding. The Wi-Fi is good (even inside the bathroom).The reception is good with English and Chinese speaking staff. The location of the hotel is perfect, a 10-15 minute walk to the Ikebukuro station.. We bought the 2-day Tokyo Subway Pass so we used the nearer Higashi Ikebukuro more often. Really worth it. We took the limo bus to Narita from here so it is very convenient (no lugging of luggage’s required).Definitely a good stay option.

The hotel locates in a very convenient location, indoors of Sunshine building with an aquarium. The view over Tokyo is very impressive, however the room itself is too old and I cannot have an impression of a high clean bed. Everything is moderate. My room has issues with the toilet. We need to ask for repairman.

the hotel located in ikebukuro with airport bus stop at the front & a shopping mall next to it. unfortunately, the hotel is old that the first room they gave us was small & the air condition was not working. we compliant next day and they change another room for us in higher level in better condition.

The sun of glory of this hotel must have set down around two or three decades ago. It is not filthy or dirty but one cannot think about the room and the furniture as of "overused". I really missed fresh air - the windows are not made to open, its just a square of plastic set in the wall. At least you can see through...The cleaning staff ignored "Do not disturb" notice on my door, heavily knocked and had the receptionist call my room until I woke up and let them in.

For those who are looking for a hotel with strategic location and easy access for transportation from airport limousine bus, tour bus and so on, this hotel is a perfect choice. Stayed here recently for my short trip to Tokyo. It was my first time to Tokyo and I booked this hotel through travel agent. Had no idea about this hotel as I booked a package with flight and hotel. I was very surprise to found out that this hotel is closed to shopping center and amusement indoor park Namjatown, J-world, Sunshine City Aquarium and Ikebukuro station Yamanote Line. Very convenience if you want to go around Tokyo by train. There are vending machine in each room floor so you don't have to worry if you feel thirsty at night. Also, Family Mart a convenience store is also available at the Lobby level. I found that this hotel is one of the meeting point for many tour bus and importantly Airport Limousine Bus from Haneda or Narita airport. Although I didn't spend much time in the hotel due to my full schedule in Tokyo. I was spoiled by complete bath amenities they provided from large bottle of shampoo, conditioner and shower gel, bath scrub, toiletries including hair pin! The interesting part is this hotel provide weight scale for your luggage. It's useful for us as we have limited 23kg.verall the experience was good and I recommend this hotel very much for business traveler or city traveler.

I have been in Japan over 25 times and stayed in this hotel for more than 3 times. Upper floor has a better view. The location is convenient for shopping and food and there is a 24 hours open Seibu supermarket nearby. It takes at least 10 minutes to walk to big department stores and the nearest subway station although you will pass many shops and food outlets. The reception is good with English and Chinese speaking staff. The room condition such as the furniture and bedding is worn out. It is clean but looked like not changed for many years. The cleaning standard is just satisfactory and not as good as I stayed in the past. The Wi-Fi is weak inside the room but surprisingly it is strong inside the bathroom.

I had stayed at this hotel for one night.The hotel is very large , so that lots of people check in and gather at the lobby.Room is small and out dated, need to be refurnished.There are lots of shops and restaurants around the hotel. The sunshine city shopping mall is just beside the hotel.There is Lawson at the ground floor of the hotel .Wifi is free in the hotel.Breakfast is average , so recommend to have breakfast ouside hotel.

Satisfactory services provided, with fair room size and clean beds.Beside the hotel is Sunshine City, which caters restaurants and comic related stores.10-15 minutes walk from nearest underground station.

It was my first time to stay in Tokyo and I found this hotel different from the other I used to stay in other big cities. Hotel is located in Sunshine Plaza where you can find everything including Disney Shop for Disney Ticket. Tokyu Hands with connected with underground shopping. Room was clean and neat as standard 4 star hotel and vending machine available next to the elevator area. Breakfast was separated due to the group rate, but food was good with variety of choice. Family Mart is available next to the lobby. Hotel Bakery was good and I really enjoy it!Recommend for visitors who want to get the valued price and walking distance to Ikebukuro Station

We had a very quiet, largish room with a good view. It's in a great location in this vibrant suburb. It's attached to a big shopping centre so all shopping was easy. But like almost every Japanese hotel, the bed was hard and uncomfortable.

We stayed here 2 times, during our Japan round-trip, at our arrival and departing from Japan, 6 nights totally. This is a good hotel and has a very good location, very close to the huge Ikebukuro underground and railway station. Price/quality ratio is good (~170 Euro/night/2 persons with 2 breakfasts) – we are, however, in Tokyo, one of the world's most expensive cities! The room was quite small and especially the bathroom is very, very small, but, once again, we're in Japan…We experienced in the hotel a little earthquake (around 5.5* Richter) and all was ok. The buffet breakfast was decent, also the dinner. We could try the both Japanese and western menus. A very useful (and on time, all the time) shuttle bus (named "Limousine Bus") links this hotel with Narita airport. The hotel, being in an important traffic hub area, is full of tourists, but this is not an impediment, as we were in the city during all the day (as well in the evening). From Ikebukuro station (the world's second busiest underground/railway station – 2.71 million passengers per day), you are very close to the world first busiest underground/railway station – the famous Shinjuku (3.64 million people per day in 2007 – Guinness Book and there are around 200 exits). Very close is, also, the well-known Shibuya underground/railway station (3rd busiest in the world) and the amazing "Shibuya crossing", known as "The scramble", the world's busiest (once again) intersection! From Ikebukuro, you can reach very easy and fast every area in the metropolitan Tokyo, by train (really fast) or by underground. More, even Sunshine City Prince Hotel itself belongs on a huge mall, plenty of shops with reasonable prices, sometimes (all the prices in Japan are huge, at least for us!). You can reach the 60th floor (the 13th floor is missing), with a very nice elevator and you'll have an amazing 360* view of Tokyo area and even, if there is a clear atmosphere, you can see the Mount Fuji. All around Sunshine City Prince Hotel is a great commercial area, very, very animated. In this area (Ikebukuro station – Sunshine City Prince Hotel) is prohibited to smoke on the street and there is a kind of street rooms, without roof, with transparent walls, where the smokers have to enter in order to enjoy a cigarette.Finally, we really enjoyed this hotel and the surrounding area.

Stayed on this hotel for seven nights. The first impression of the hotel was not bad, but also not good. Just as it should for a 3 star hotel.The service was good, pretty much people in the lobby sometimes during the busy hours. English speech was not an issue for the personal. Very nice restaurant employees. The room was really small, for me it was no issue. I don’t stay more in the room then needed anyway.The location of the hotel is perfect, a 10-15 minute walk to the Ikebukuro station. Sunshine is also a big shopping mall, I was not aware of how big it was before the last day. Good prices compared to the shops closer to Ikebukuro. Visit this mall before moving on to the other shops in Ikebukuro.I liked the location most. I there is anything I want to change, that would be the breakfast. It could be a bit more various.

Ikebukuro is one of the fastest growing areas in Tokyo, and has really improved immensely over the last few decades and the Prince Hotel couldn't be located in a more convenient place. Right in the middle of Sunshine City you've got immediate access to not only the shopping mall but a great aquarium, a planetarium, a movie theater and even Namja Town with its world renowned ice cream. You have a bus that takes you directly to the airport and a shuttle to most of the major electronics stores. Going with all this, the rooms are quite nice and the price is very affordable, especially in this area. I've been there many times and plan on going again very soon.

Sunshine City is conveniently located in the bustling Ikebukuro area. Malls and stores are walking distance, and there's a convenience store and money changer machine at the ground floor. Rooms are quite small but comfy. Vendo machines are also found on each floor. The breakfast buffet is also good. The staff also responds immediately to your needs.

My teenage daughter and I had the twin room on the 30th floor. Rooms are clean, beds are supersingle sized. Only problem was the guests next to our room had friends over till 2 am 2 nights in a row. The walls are so thin, we could hear their conversations and one particuar guy kept laughing like a hyena. Other than this, the hotel is covenient for shopping, food and as a base. Covenient to go to the Railway Museum because there is a direct line there.

This was our first hotel in our trip to Japan. The hotel has quite a few rooms and the reception is always crowded quite like a railway station. We were prepared to see small room sizes in Japan so were it disappointed with the size of the room. We have stayed in smaller rooms in Europe. The decor in the rooms gives a jaded look and are in need of refit out.Breakfast was good with reasonable amount of choice.
