Staff quite courteous except for a few ladies at the reception one of who was even rude when asked a question surprising for Japan as every where we went other than this instant Japenese are very polite and helpful.The hotel is connected to Sunshine City and has a convenience store on the lower floor where you can buy most necessitates.

We love this hotel as it is very conveniently located. Sunshine City is just next to the hotel where most of shops give discounts to hotel guest. We took 15 minutes to walk to the train station, on the way there are also some shops and eateries like KFC and Lotteria etc. There is also a 24 hour super mart downstairs where we can get drinks and snacks. The semi-double rooms are quite small, but the twin room is much spacious. We love the toiletries provided as they are more than the usual. We also enjoyed the free wifi in the rooms. Staff are very helpful, they can speak English and able to direct us to the 24 hour supermarket, Seiyu where we bought lots of kitkat chocolates and coffee. They also provide good service with the limousine booking etc.Overall we have very good experience with this hotel, will definitely recommend to friends and relatives to stay in this hotel.

As a product of Japan, I recall Sunshine City as the next big thing back in 1978. Back then, everything here was new, modern and exciting. But visiting the area and this hotel in particular in 2015, nearly 40 years since its prime, it's clear that time has taken its toll. The hotel lobby and the hallways feel aged. No longer polished and kept up well. The hotel rooms feel similar to the very modest hotels in the US. For example, the bathroom appears as though it was last remodeled inexpensively about ten years ago. The carpet in the room is aged, starting to separate from the wall in a few spots. The walls have seen many visitors. I would think of this hotel as a convenient location to shower and sleep only. Don't expect much and you will be OK. One major irritation that I had was that all the room switches are connected to the central master switch by the exit door. Sure it's great for turning off all the lights when leaving the room but strangely this master switch also mandates the bright ceiling lights in the main sleeping area to turn on. So I cannot turn on just the small bedside lamp when this master switch is off. And no, I cannot turn on the bathroom light when this switch is off. If I wanted to use the bathroom in the middle of the night, I would have to also turn on this master switch exposing everyone to the bright lights in the main area waking them up. Good location with a retro feel, like visiting a grandparent's old house in need of a major update. Many restaurants are near by and you can shower and sleep. Well, you can sleep only if you are staying solo or nobody else needs the bathroom light in the middle of the night. But the price wasn't horribly expensive by Tokyo standards.

We had a string of bad hotels on this trip to Japan, mainly due to space issues but this hotel was amazing. First of all the staff here are excellent and made us feel very welcome. The location is prime! Short walk to the main Ikebukuro area where there is everything to do. Lots of shopping, restaurants, arcades, you name it it's there. Our room was situated on the 36th floor which was the second highest. The view was spectacular! The room was very spacious and so was the bathroom. The beds were very comfortable. Very glad to have been to find such a nice place. I really recommend this hotel if you want a nice place with plenty to do around the area. Loved it here!

The hotel is very busy, full of tour groups from all over the world. Sometimes getting an elevator was hit and miss.The room we had was very average, the chair fabric was ripped and stained, the curtains had rips in them and the furniture had water stains or some sort of stain on them. The room was bigger than I imagined as most Japanese hotel rooms are small.We had a buffet breakfast included in the price which was chaos if you got there at a busy time.There is a 24 hour family mart attached where you can buy all sorts of goodies including alcohol and at the back of the hotel is a huge shopping centre and restaurant complex.It is close to Ikebukuro railway station.

This place is a mad house of tourists from all over. The lobby area is usually full of tour groups coming in and out. Stay away if you are looking for a peaceful, quiet place. As for the room, this is not the Hyatt, Ritz, or anything close. Think Motel 6ish. The bed won't fit two people comfortably unless you want to be touching each other all night. If you must stay there, get two twins. You'll be able to sleep better until the lousy mattress quality wakes you at about 2am. A better choice? Get the tatami room where you sleep on the floor. Why 3 stars? This is average for a western style Japan hotel. On the bright side, the hotel is situated attached to a large shopping mall and shopping area. There are plenty of restaurants and shops to keep you busy. We used the Prince as a base for many sightseeing trips since it was not deep inside Tokyo. Traffic was never really a problem.

The hotel is conveniently located where all that actions in Ikebukuro and only 500m away from the train station, 5-10min walk. If you're coming with the Limousine bus, this would be convenient from the airport, coming by train, it might be tough on the first try. The hotel has lots of group tour crowds at the lobby, I've seen Philippines, China, Korea, Malaysian groups and check-in may be crowded, but they are efficient. Check-in / out is strict with the reception speaking not much English. Newdays at the bottom for convenient drinks and light sundries. Child friendly.The rooms are indeed small, but hey it's Japan. Everything is equipped and no qualms. Single beds are single beds, don't expect to share with your child. Didn't find the hotel that old, only they use keys instead of modern door access cards.Connected to Sunshine City - convenient for food, but there's more food outside.

Staffs are very friendly and polite, hotel only 13 minute walk from ikebukuro station. There is Shopping mall and 24 hrs mini mart inside the hotel. Room is clean and not too small when you expect from hotels in Tokyo

Location:the hotel is in the middle of busy part of Tokyo, close to the Ikeburo Station, close to shoppings. The hotel is connected to a mall and a train station. The hotel:The hotel is in need of updating. Low ceilings, old interior.The room:This is our smallest room in our week-long Japanese trip. the room is so narrow so it has no space to put the TV in front of the bed. So, instead, they put the TV on a small cabinet on the side. So you have to lie sideways to watch TV on your bed. The desk is so small so I had to remove the tray with glass cups elsewhere in order to use the desk. The bathroom is just like the bathroom is many Japanese hotel that reminds me of bathrooms in cruise ships. It is practically a box, you have to watch your step as you go in and out. I had the impression that the bathroom is more recently upgraded, but the room is not (yet). The bathroom has a small sink, a classic Japanese bathtub and a hi-tech toilet with function buttons on the right side (to spray and dry your bottom, etc.).It has a very narrow windows. The curtains on the side made you think the window is wider.The breakfast:Standard Japanese and continental breakfast. taste OK.The service:Not easy to get service, don't expect them to smile. However, they are polite. They also offer an internet corner. But free internet is available on certain floors only.

Hotel is accessible from airport via Airport Limousine. It stops in front of the hotel which is good news if you have large luggages. Check-in and check-out was fast and hotel staff were easy to communicate with in English.We were assigned in the 14th floor and as expected, the rooms were tiny. However, compared to Hong Kong hotels, I thought it was more spacious. What I loved about the room most was the toilet seat. Only in Japan will you experience heated toilet seats! The rooms were basic and acceptable if you will be out the whole day. Only complaint was that the rooms were too hot.Breakfast was quite enjoyable, with both continental and Asian variety.I think this hotel has a great location. It's not that busy, beside a park and a police station. It also has a Family Mart at the ground floor. There's also an access to a mall beside it that has a lot of shops and the Pokemon Center, Gamja Town, an aquarium and an observatory. The train is a 10-minute walk but you'll see a lot and maybe even shop along the way going there. There's Tokyu Hands, BIC Camera, Uniqlo, Sanrio, Seibu Mall and restaurants on the way to the train. What I loved most about this hotel were the staff. They were very helpful and courteous!

Very large Western style hotel adjacent to a huge shoppng mall. Caters mainly for tourist groups.A nice feature is the Airport Limousine Bus which leaves directly from the hotel (and can be booked at reception). Rooms are very small, but yet contains next to the beds a small desk.The bedding gives a bit the feeling of a tent: you have to get in from the food end as the room is not wide enough to facilitate a corridor between them. Lounge and reception area is somewhat bare and very crowded: there is no sitting space in the rooms, so many guest sit in that area. Moreover, it is used as a storage place for luggage (under large nets).This all may sound a bit negative, but it is certainly not a bad hotel. It's strong points are the Airport Bus and it's location in one of the prettier and cosier areas of Tokyo. Many shops and restaurants in the adjacent mall (nice when it is raining) as well as nearby outside. Distance to Subway and JR station appx 10-15 min. walk.

Have always stayed in this hotel though it's abit run down. Usually packed with group tour in the lobby, however for FE travelers, this is the most convenient hotel to stay as there is airport limo to/fro. Lugging yr luggages thru the train stations is no jokes, so this is the best hotel to stay! Free wifi in the room, family mart on level 1 & 24hrs Seiyu supermarket just opp the hotel. Everyday, when walking to/fro Ikebukuro station ... there are so much things to see & shop at Tokyu Hands, Uniqlo, cosmetics/skincare stores etc. Not forgetting, Sunshine City itself is full of shopping & restaurants....

Very nice location, perfect for travelling to areas like tochigi or nasu as it is well linked with the trains. Staff are not as friendly but not rude either. Location is great as the pachinco and restaurants around the area close quite late. The link to sunshine city mall was great as it provides you access to last minute shopping. Will definitely stay there again

Rooms are average by Japan standard but quite clostrophobic compared to other Asian hotels. Bathrooms are very small. Plus side is it is centrally located in Sunshine City and near Ikebukuro station. Alot of things to do within walking distance.

The twin sharing rooms that we were put in was of a decent size , not too cramped, not too roomy. The bathrooms also were decent sized and very clean and neat. We just stayed for a night , checking in late in the evening and checking out the next morning. So did not make use of the family mart within the hotel nor the shopping areas nearby. Although the lobby was crowded with many groups getting in and out , the service was very prompt and fast. The wi-fi service is only available in the lobby. The morning breakfast spread was also good with reasonably good options for both vegetation and non-vegetarian.

We had a great stay here. We booked a panorama room and we got a room at their topmost floor. Very spacious and extremely comfortable beds. Professional staff. Handy location near / in the shopping mall and at walking distance from Ikebukuro Station (you have to search a little). Coming from the airport we recommend the Airport Limousine Service as it drops you off in front of the hotel.

It's a high rise hotel with busy lobby in the mornings. Rooms are small but bathroom is good size. Family Mart in lobby is nice, its 24 hour and helps when you wake up at 4 am with jet lag and want something to drink or eat. Metro stop is a nice 8-10 minute walk from hotel. Hotel is also connected to mall. A major plus is the airport limousine leaves you right in front of hotel.

We chose this hotel because it is very closed to the pokemon center Mega Tokyo. It is only about 2 min walk!! (My daughter is a big fan of pokemon. )good points:1. the standard twin room isn't too small in Japanese standard2. has a 24 hour supermarket nearby3. has a family mart inside the hotel4. can go to many shops and restaurants easily5. has airport shuttle bus outside the hotel but we didn't take it. (more expensive, take longer time and operate about once in an hour only)6. free kid's set (towel, toothbrush, slippers and so on). really sweet and thoughtful. 7. some staffs can communicate in English well. 8. free wifi but weak signalbad points:1. the wall is thin so you can hear the noise outside or other rooms2. not as closed to the JR station as I imagined. well, it is still walkable of course. 3. the mattress and pillows are not too comfortable. not the worst but can be better. 4. can't control the air con well5. the hotel is rather old. don't worry, it is clean and tidy.

When we have arrived in front of the hotel I was mesmerized by the height of the building. Thought how it must have perfect views from the top floors. I wasn't wrong. The view from our room which was located on the 29th floor was breathtaking. On the last day, when the sky was clear, we had a perfect view of Mount Fuji.The rooms were small. So small that we did not have enough room on the floor to spread open our suitcase. The height of the ceiling in the shower was very low. I think that tall person would not have been able to take a shower standing up.The rooms were equipped with water heater, tea, coffee, pajamas, sleepers, tv with no english channels, air freshener spray, shampoo, conditioner, shower gel, toothbrush, razor. The water in the heater was changed daily. The breakfast was average. Nothing special. Filter coffee and not so tasteful eggs.The best part of the hotel was location. Ten minutes away from the station. Two minutes away from the mall. The mall is open until 21h. The Tully Coffee shop (similar to Starbucks) opens at 8 am.

The hotel is high-rise and about forty storey high. It is attached to a shopping centre which made the connection easy also. The room is cleaned, neat and decent. Toilet facilities and accessories are fully equipped. There is a 24hrs convenient shop located in the hotel too where snacks and drinks could be brought easily during late night. The hotel was a 5mins walk to the nearby Ikebukuro shopping belts with plenty of food outlets, a cinema, a Big Camera departmental store, small shops and convenient shops too. It is conveniently a 8mins walk to the main Ikebukuro subway station, whereby 6 subway lines inter-crossed. Coming from or going to Narita International Airport is easily accessed from the Ikebukuro station. Travelling was easy within the locality. It can be directly connected to the places of interest within Tokyo and also to Disney Land and Disney Sea.

Booked a twin room at hotel for 1 night during March. The walk to the station is about 5 - 10 mins on foot, so it is more advisable to take the airport limousine bus which stops just outside the hotel rather than to drag your huge luggage through the crowd. The only lift to the station is at the Tokyo metro area (from what I have experienced), so take that lift down to the platform before finding your way to the JR lines etc. We got a high floor room which was around 20+ levels up, room was small but clean and basic despite the room decorations looking a bit dated. As this is a huge hotel, there are always a lot of tour groups at the lobby, so just be aware of that. There is a huge family mart store at the lobby level which was really convenient! We sent our mobile wifi to the hotel but couldn't retrieve it until check in time, which was weird as we could do so for all other hotels so far. Also, they have a baggage drop counter which, I have to say, was very attentive when guests drag their huge luggage to the reception desk. By the time you exit from the queue, the staff will ask you if you would like to drop off your luggage and they will bring you to the other desk.

I like the location of the hotel and safe...it is connected to the sunshine mall and free wifi in the lobby and room, but AC or heater not functional in some rooms, very busy hotel during day or night ...nice staff and there is family mart to buy groceries ....

The hotel location is good. Shopping malls, transport of train station and bus are within reach. Not to forget the variety eating places around. Can see some improvement on the cleanliness and room condition since my last visit a few years ago. The stay is sure value for money.

The room is not too big but acceptable for two of us. It is clean. There are many shops and restaurants located near the hotel. There is a shopping mall located on the lower floors. There is a big convenience store 'family mart' on the ground floor. It is located a bit far from the JR station. We have to walk about 8-10 minutes between the hotel and JR station. But we choose to take the free shuttle from the hotel to the SEIBU department store which is next to JR station. The bus schedule is provided at the reception counter.

We stayed at this hotel as part of a group heading to Hakuba on a ski trip. We spent 4 nights here and found the hotel to be comfortable and as it is basically part of the Sunshine City shopping complex it was close to shops, food halls (including McDonalds - if the kids insist on that), bakeries and there is a supermarket just across the road. We couldn't believe how cheap the alcohol was. The hotel is quite a way out of town in the Ikebukuro area but the Metro is about 10mins walk away and from there you can get just about anywhere. We bought Pasmo cards from the Ikebukuro Metro station which is basically a tap and go card - don't insert it into the Day Ticket slot at the front of the automated entry machines or one of the station attendants will have to come and open up the machine to get your card back. There are lots of cafes and restaurants near the hotel on the way to the Metro as well as more department stores so finding a place to eat is pretty easy. Don't expect anyone to speak English at those eateries but they make an effort to get you what you want. Breakfast for us was included in the main dining area and was a buffet affair with both Japanese and Western food available and lots of it. The front desk helped us organise a day tour to Mt Fuji and were very helpful. The rooms have fridges and there are vending machines on each floor providing alcohol etc and nibbles.

The best hotel i've ever stay in Japan. Great location, fantastic service and clean room. Although the hotel is busy with the groups - Nu Skin, Kiev Opera and US Embassy, the manage it well without any major hiccups.Oh! The view of Mt Fuji from level 33 is breathtaking! Highly recommended.

Two week stay overall enjoyed. Had a larger American corner suite - awesome room comparatively speaking! Huge mall attached, 30 million people around you at all times. Rooms are clean, and maids are awesome, learning all your little quirks within a day or two... Lobby has a family mart and is attached to a huge mall with tons to eat, see and do. Out the back door and your ground zero for miles of shopping and food as well...

We are 2 adults and a 3 year old. I am here right now and looking outside of a sealed window. The room's window cannot be opened for extra air ventilation. No worries for me with a 3 year old kid. The room is big for japan standard and surprisingly quiet to think it is near the train station. Yes it is 15minutes walk to the station. Easy access to a connecting mall. J-world is here too. Many restaurants along the street across the hotel. Only downside for me is the cleanliness of the room. It needs an overhaul. Bathroom stinks and the carpet.. please you need to change.. yes I said change. Not vacuumed. Location wise, this is close to almost everything i need.

For the first-timer, I would suggest arriving/departing by airport limousine bus as it's quite a long, confusing walk from the train station weaving through congested pedestrian traffic. Was upgraded to a 2BR suite because the hotel made a mistake with my reservation; apparently Japanese service culture dictates that the customer must be compensated with something better. Love the scent of the toiletries. The area is quite local with something for everyone - entertainment (kids, girly bars if you walk down certain lanes), shopping, restaurants (even a cat cafe). I had initially wanted to stay in the more central Shinjuku area but now think that this is a good tourist class alternative especially if Tokyo is the sole destination rather than a base to visit other places.

Sunshine Prince Hotel offers excellent service, even with several customers checking-in you will not wait a long time. Their customer service is great, the staff will try their best to address your concern even if some staff speak little English, they will try their best to address your queries. It is located inside the Sunshine CIty Mall, quite far from the train station but you will pass by several stores while walking going to the train station so will not get bored. Prince Hotel support the Green campaign if you will not have your room cleaned for a day they will give you a Y500 voucher which you can use to buy from 7-11 store located at the hotel or any store/restaurant inside the hotel. There's a big supermarket just across the mall where you can buy bottled water at a cheaper price. The only negative thing is there's NO internet service in the room.

Though this is not exactly a cheap hotel, we usually stay here when we visit Tokyo because it's where the airport limousine bus stops so it's great that we don't have to carrying several pieces luggage and walk to the train or bus station. It's linked to the Sunshine City shopping center which has enough shops and restaurants to keep you occupied if you feel like spending a lazy day in and is next to Otome Road as well for people who are into anime and manga. If traveling with elderly or really young children, you might like to note that it is a bit of a walk to the train station though not super far (10-15mins) so please keep that in mind.

I love the hotel as I booked a twin sharing room. It was quite spacious and there are a lot of facilities within the hotel such as family mart, Thai spa, etc. It is also connected to a shopping mall called Sunshine City which you can go to shop. The room can be quite warm during winter, so a t-shirt and shorts will suffice as your loungewear.For those who are Anytime Fitness members, there is a branch nearby in front. Please bring your key if you want to work out.

It is very busy hotel ; like Tokyo, directly connected to the shopping mall and very close to Ikebukuro station ( use gate 35 for the hotel). There are different types of rooms available, but not big as usual in Japan. Small, clean beds and bathroom ;old style furniture and decoration. The best thing about the hotel is clean and close to shops, restaurants etc. The only problem is very thin walls, if your room neighbours are not Japanese they can be noisy. Good for short stays, and valuable.

Stayed here for 4 nights. Minus points - Very poor ventilation. Air con dun seem to be working. Can't control the temperature. Room is very run down. Just too old... Toilet is a huge letdown as well. Definitely need a major renovation. Plus points - good view of the city at high floor. Shopping mall just below the hotel. Conclusion - once is enough less they improved on the shortfalls.

This is an extremely busy hotel. There are no frills but for Tokyo the rooms were a decent size. The room was clean and reasonably well equipped. It was inconvenient not having wifi but we were only there for two nights so we managed by using the hotels Internet service in the main lobby. There was a shuttle service to and from the airport which was reasonably priced and efficient. The location was very good.

This hotel was for just an overnight stay in a different part of Tokyo. The room was small but fine with two twin beds and a small sitting area and full bathroom. The brunch is quite large with western and Japanese foods available.The Sunshine City area is full of activity at night with amusement park etc. Lots of young people in this area. The location is close to the JR trains and the subway system (about 10 minute walk through crowded streets). The Ikebukuro train station is huge with many different trains and subway lines with tons of people. We grabbed the Yamanote line to explore parts of the city and then took this to the Tokyo Monorail to get to the Haneda International Airport fairly easily in about 1 hour.

Back staying at this hotel after 10 years. As good as before. Fantastic location, just a door step to many eateries, polite and helpful staff and I really like the layout of the room that separate the washing basin from the shower room. Another bonus is that the Airport Limousine stop is just right in front of the hotel.

I usually stay at hotels in Shinjinku, Ikebukuro is also convenient for shopping and restaurants. The reason to stay there is only the special package of air ticket and hotel is really attractive for few days in Tokyo. The hotel is old. The location is 5 mins walk from Metro Subway and at least 10 mins walk from JR. It has convenient store just located at the lobby area, so you can have drinks and snacks at all times. Staff are usually friendly and helpful but English is not really good.

The Sunshine Prince could easily be called a "tourist" hotel. When the Toyota Amlux Tech Center (Showroom) with first opened in the early 90's I stayed here because of convenience. Of course, the Japanese Government paid the tab so I did not mind. Returning as a tourist some years later one would expect the place to be modernized with every kind of amenity. The rooms are kind of small and weathered. The beds are not as comfortable. Now that I am older, I did not realize that the train station was such a far walk. Otherwise, Ikebukuro is a fast-paced bustling city full of life, sights and sounds.

If I got a choice, I really won't choose this hotel in the first place.I had an ad hoc trip last week end and i booked my air ticket and hotel one day before my trip. Sunshine city Prince hotel was the only choice under USD200 per night in the market in Ikebukuro, that was why I chose sunshine city prince.After staying for two nights, it further reinforced that I will never stay in this hotel again. There is just NO, absolutely NO, advantage of this hotel over the others.Let's start with the location. It's more than 15 minutes walk from JR station and major shopping malls e.g. PARCO and Seibu etc. Although the airport shuttle stop right in front of the hotel, but I won't choose bus service when the train services are so reliable, comfotable and of equal price. About its amenities, the hotel is way too old. I think it has not been renovated for more than 20 years. The toilet has strange smell. And the sound isolation system it just crap!!! I heard the coversation of my 'neighour' every night. Of course, there was something to do with the voice of my 'neighbours' as well...........The hotel won't let you check-in earlier / check-out later, even for an hour. They will charge you for 1,000 yen for any extra hour. I know that it is a big hotel and any change in check out time would affect lots of things.... but, will there be a little bit flexibility for just an hour delay in checking out......Anyway, I shouldn't have forced myself to stay in Ikebukuro in the first place where this hotel was the only choice available.

I believe that this hotel was opened back in 1978 when the Sunshine City complex was completed. To some degree this shows -- the hotel is clean, friendly, and efficient but it is definitely dated inside. A thorough renovation would go a long way to making this truly a world-class property. But, for the price that I paid per night, the excellent location in an area of Tokyo that I am very familiar with, and the friendly staff that are well-versed in dealing with customers from around the world, the Prince Hotel is a great place to stay and I would definitely stay here again.

The hotel is situated above the Sunshine prince Mall, which provides an ideal location for tourists as well as business travelers. The rooms are better and connectivity to metro stations is also within the hotel basement itself. Would give 3.5 rating to this hotel. Cherry blossom (Ueno Park) is 10 minutes away, we enjoyed the season during our stay here.

I say this hotel is in a very good location because of the nearby shops, malls, restaurants and railway station (Ikebukuro). For first timers like us, it made it easy for us to roam around with lots of local attractions just by walking (a lot of walking!). Easy for us to buy some souvenirs, too. As for the hotel, I saw its popularity especially for non-japanese tourists in groups because the lobby is always full of checking-in and checking-out tourists. True enough as I have read in the previous reviews, the hotel room and comfort room are small enough but it's just fine. We tried to learn the push button toilet bowls and we loved it. We were also impressed by the fact that water even from the faucet is potable. Breakfast buffets at the basement was good with a lot of variety. One thing that concerned us was that they had the same breakfast menu everyday. But overall, I loved the place and I loved the people. They were so hospitable even though we didn't understand Japanese language but their actions and facial expressions said it all.

This hotel is about a 10 mins walk from Ikebukuro Station. Convenient because the airport limousine bus drops you right in front of the hotel. Hotel is a little old and there is no wifi in the room. Location is excellent! Lots of shopping and restaurants downstairs the hotel. There is also a Family Mart located within the hotel so it's convenient if you need to buy water or other miscellaneous. Not sure if I may return to stay here in the future because the rooms are really old but certainly if you are looking for an favorable stay in Ikebukuro, would recommend this hotel for its location and the amenities surrounding it. You can rent wifi from this site called Mi fi Japan at a very affordable price and you can request for it to be dropped off at the hotel prior to your arrival. Charges are probably about US$6 per day (charges differ) depending on number of days of usage. Very efficient and it helps a lot when you have wifi access! Try this japanese restaurant on the 59th floor of the Sunshine City called Sushi Fukusuke for affordable sashimi and sushi which is 100% authentic. Reservations recommended. Ask for a seat by the window so you can admire Japan's skyline during the day!

Very good hotel from the point of view of location, cleanliness, comfort, friendly and helpful staff and reasonable price. there is a shuttle direct from Narita to the hotel.The only downside is there is no WiFi in the rooms - but internet via cable is available so take you adaptor if needed. They say there is WiFi in the lobby but I couldn't get it to work. There are computers in the lobby you can use for 100 Yen / 10 minutes which is reasonable but finding one that the english shows up on was a challenge.

Hot tub provided, though very small. Staff are polite and clinical. Has great location, near to Ikibukuru station. However, I had a bit trouble finding the lobby, where is located outside a shopping mall.

Airport 'bus' to/from Airport directly at Hotel. 2 Subway stations just 5-10 minutes walk (lots to see, eat, shop around during the path to subway, whether its underground or above on the streets).Rooms are a bit old, but still clean. Ask for extra pillows. Bring a portable lan to wifi connector.There is a 24 hr Family Mart that has most things you may need.

Check in/Check-out : fast and smooth. Service: non-existent but staff otherwise polite and clinical.Location : excellent with a 24 hr supermarket (Seibu) opposite the hotel. Abundant shopping and fd options. Note : best food is found in the back lanes or if eating out is expensive for the budget traveller, wait till evening, when the supermarket food is on sale, buy back to hotel room and eat and it can be quite fun and economical to enjoy wide variety of food at great prices!Attraction : Very nice aquarium just like Epson Aquarium in Shinnagawa Prince which has world class dolphin show for little more than S$12 . Much more value for $ than the one in Singapore SEA aquarium and Dolphin Lagoon. .Downside : too many rowdy Chinese in tour groups turning the place into market place robbing the place of a hotel feel.Rooms : BASIC, Small and not enough space for my luggage. Semi double bed is too small for 2 persons if your hubby is big like mine. Loud and noisy at all times cos the mainland Chinese likes to shout across for each other and banging on each other doors.Eye opener : After going to Japan, you will realise how expensive Singapore is. Rooms in good location are cheaper here. Food is cheaper than in Singapore for a higher quality though their base is also much higher. S$3 -S$4 food court prices is non-existent in Japan unless you cook. Food and just about everything else are higher quality. For every S$100 spent, you can get so much prettier things and I am amazed by Japanese craftsmanship especially their wooden furniture, handkerchiefs and shoes. Shoes are so well made especially the made in Japan ones that it can easily last me 5 years and counting with constant wearing.Transport : EXPENSIVE. manage cost by travelling with JR pass.Express bus service : Enquire from hotel about express bus service to Haneda and Narita airport. Overall : reasonable price for its EXCELLENT location and SUPER Convenience. Definitely NOT for LUXURY or Fussy traveller.

We stayed in this hotel on July 30-August 3, 2014 for a family vacation. First of all, this hotel is quite far from Ikebukuro train station, may be about 10-15 minutes walk. Like many hotels in Japan, the room is small and the bathroom is tiny. The bed mattress is also considerably thin and the AC is not cold enough. There is no wifi connection in the room as well. To get one, we need to be at the lobby. The service, however, is satisfying. Hotel staffs, for example, promptly provided us with electrical adapters, fresh towels and ironing set, as well as quick check in and check out. This hotel is also located in a big mall so it is easy for us to find especially local foods which are plenty of choices. Another plus is a 24-hour convenient store located next to the hotel lobby. It is quite helpful shall we need to buy light meals, snacks and bottled drinks. Overall, I encourage you to consider all possible hotel options before choosing this hotel so you won't regret later.

Department store is right below the hotel.But it closed at about 8:00p.m.I think the hotel is quiet old but still clean.A bit far to reach.It took about 15 minutes walk to reach there because you must pass through a street with numerous people.It would be tired if your luggage is big.Many places to hang around there at night.Staffs are kind.Some can even speak Chinese.Many delicious foods in the department store.Reasonable room rates.

-Poor air con ventilation. Not cold at all. No difference between Low setting and High setting. Cause not much air blows out and we have to stuck with it for 5 days. Really pissed. High floor window unable to be open for ventilation since air con super poor. Sealed window.-Poor room sound proof. Can hear people dragging their luggage talking in middle of the night-Old furniture makes skin itch throughout stay. -Receptionists don't know speak or understand English and unable to communicate well with customers. A family mart cashier can speak better than any of the people standing at the reception.-Bell boy is the maintenance response guy. Who also don't know English. Hard time telling him air con sucks. He say "try" to tell the maintenance to on the centralised air con higher.. All other room same air con.- Location is the only plus. Near to subway, sheltered walk , small shopping centre. Been overseas countless times but never been to such bad hotel before. I will definitely stay away from this hotel. Beware.

The shopping paradise is just less than 5 mins walking. The room is normal standard - clean. I went with my friends so I also have a chance to observe my friend room. Some of the restroom look a bit old but I was so lucky my restroom look newly renovated.

Room is clean albeit a little old. Reception can get quite crowded when tour groups gather. Free wi-fi is only available at the Lobby. There is a Family Mart (local convenience store) located in the hotel. Hotel breakfast is quite good, with Japanese and western selections.There is a shopping mall right next to the hotel so it's convenient to do some shopping or have your meals. However, take note that the shops close by 8pm so shop before you eat, if you are short of time. Hotel is about 10 -15 mins walk to the Ikebukuro station. On your way to the subway, you will find lots of eateries and shopping including Tokyu Hands. Great location if you plan to commute by train and don't mind walking a bit back to the hotel after a hectic day.

This hotel was the first hotel we visited on our trip through Japan. Its a big hotel and well maintained. The lobby can get extremely busy as there is no Wifi in the rooms, just the lobby.The lobby connects straight to the very large shopping center Sunshine City. There are many place you can eat.The hotel is quite far from the nearest subway, you should consider a 10 minute walk every time. But this is a walk through a nice busy street, so no big deal really.The room was nice for Japanese hotels and everything you need is there. If the location would be closer to a subway, it would have gotten a 4 rating.

This hotel is the most convenient thing you'll find in a big city where it might be easy to get lost. The lobby of the hotel is merged with a huge mall that has everything from souvenir shops to tea stores to restaurants. There's even an aquarium. You might not even need to go out if you don't want to...or if you find yourself trapped inside because of a typhoon. The rooms are fairly small and kind of old-looking but clean. The price is great for what they offer and it includes breakfast (which is mostly Oriental-style but also has some fruit and cereal). The bathrooms are tiny, tidy cubicles and Japanese toilets are the most wonderful inventions in the world (the ones where you sit, not squat, although the latter have their advantages). It might take a while to understand all the buttons but, once you do, you'll want to take one home with you. Above all, this hotel is just very convenient because everything is right there. Seriously, if you find yourself unable to go out because of bad weather (which happens often in Japan), you will have everything you need just by walking out into the lobby and right into the mall.

Rooms were small, but wasn't shockingly so considering this is Tokyo. But the furnishing was rather old and musty. Disappointed that there was no in-room Wifi and was forced to make trips to the lobby for the hotel Wifi (though admittedly, not overly unusual for hotels of such calibre in Tokyo). Had to communicate with staff using Mandarin as they spoke that better than English. Was unwilling to help us make reservations for some restaurants we have scoped out. Redeeming features were 1) its proximity to the Ikekuburo Station (and the Ikekuburo area in general) and 2) the well-stocked Family Mart (convenience store) built into the ground floor of the hotel.

The room was small but adequate. The hotel is close to shopping areas and a 10-15 minute walk to the train station. Wifi only available in the lobby but was unable to connect for pretty much the two nights we were there.

My daughter and I stayed here for our last 2 nights in Japan. It was a great location for some shopping and hundreds of places to eat but the room was very small and quite stained and I didn't feel comfortable touching anything! The pillow was rock hard and there was no real airflow, really stuffy. There is a buffet breakfast available in the Lobby Lounge for ¥3000, it was ok, convenient for us with 2 kids. I would not stay here again.

Pretty Average and dated 3 star Hotel. The pro cons are 1.is next to a shopping mall thus extremely convenient 2. All amenities are provided except for an iron and ironing board 3. Pretty good selection of international buffet breakfast. However is a three star hotel thus, the furnishing and room is pretty much of a 3 star expected standard. I am pretty ok with the room size despite being 6 feet tall. Though, it did gotten pretty tight between me and my mum. The room is clean though and the housekeeping is efficient. First time to japan thus it did surprise me that the bathroom is pretty much a larger in built version of a potable toilet (with a bath tub hand wash sink and everything !) Guess maybe is due to safety reasons with the large occurrence of earth quakes. Is a pretty touristy hotel with large (and I really mean large !) group of tourists coming in and out of the hotel. Despite that I find the room still rafter quiet and mine even face right in front of the lift lobby. Pretty comfy to sleep in and chat and party in too especially if you have great traveling companion. Oh yay despite have 6 elevators it do take a long time to catch one at 'peak' breakfast hours ! Comfort level though I will give a 4 stars

The Sunshine City Prince is pretty okay. My whole band stayed here, and we were impressed with how cheap it was for Tokyo. It conveniently connects to Sunshine 60 and to the subway system. If you rent a room at either end of the floor, it's closer to American standards in terms of size (i.e. two beds, a bathroom you can walk in). It's very clean, and the staff is very accommodating (although they always seem to be in a hurry.) They put a humidifier in my room when I told them my allergies were acting up. I was able to buy beer from the vending machine outside my room in the middle of the night, which was great. The beds are like rocks though.The Family Mart inside the hotel is expensive (although a good place for touristy souvenirs for the family.) But it can provide you with a good oden if you're hungry and in the mood for a lot of sodium. And the staff is nice and generally speaks enough English.Just make sure you bring your own wireless internet router. You can get them cheap in Akihabara.

I just finished 9 day stay the the Prince, been staying here 9 years due to business. Sadly while never a 5 star hotel, it has gone downhill. I was very disappointed this time. The carpet and bed covers have never been changed since i've been staying there and are now stained and filthy, rare for Japan. I mean the carpet is absolutely filthy, I was on he floor doing to work and got up covered in hair. Under the beds completely horribly dirty. No care at all being taken to clean the place. My chair was so stained it was like a rainbow of dark colors. It is also hot, horribly hot like 80* F. Way too hot to be comfortable, and no way to change the temperature or open a window, hotter in the hallway. Every night I sweltered in an uncomfortable hot room.Find another hotel is my only advice.

We slept in a 3 bed room which is bigger than the normal 2 bed room. Then the hotel is connected to sunshine 60 mall which is big and is connected to a street full of shops. We took a whole day trying to explore the whole street but our legs couldnt take it. Great place to stay.

Hotel is just beside a huge mall (Sunshine 60) so you can do your shopping and dining there. Also there's a FamilyMart at the lobby for your on the go purchases. A 5 minute walk will also bring you to Sun City streets and 10minutes to Ikebukuro MRT station. The hotel room is quite small and looks old already but it could be manageable since we are always out during the day. Buffet breakfast is good also. The only bad thing i guess is there's no wifi in the room so you have to go to the lobby to access wifi. What's only available in the room is one LAN cable if ever you brought a laptop with you.

The hotel is actually quite a distance from JR Ikebukuro (East exit) and not so direct route as we have expected. One has to walk some 400m across the always-crowded Sunshine Dori St and then go through an underground passageway (beside the Tokyu Hands bldg) to Sunshine City. On our arrival we have to lug our bags through one of the busiest part of Ikebukuro- Sunshine Dori, a mind-boggling 10-15 minutes of crowd dodging. In terms of transport it might be a challenge if you intend to travel daily via Ikeburoko station. An alternative is the Tokyo Metro Higashi-Ikebukuro station. You can get to this sta. through the street level followed by about 5-7 minutes through interconnecting walkways.The hotel room we gotten was reasonably sized to fit just a double bed and small table with small TV (surprisingly comes with English/Chinese channels). The lobby is not well furnished and the many sofa chairs seemed always occupied with the many hotel stayers/visitors and tourists in large groups checking in or out of the hotel (testament to its popularity!) We stayed at 12xx so did not have much fantastic views of the nearby Ikebukuro and Shinjuku skyline.. In terms of amenities there are many dining and shopping options in that area including the Seibu, Parco and Tobu Department stores, on top of the many restaurants and fastfood outlets. The hotel breakfast buffet is priced about 1575 yen for hotel guest but it was not in our package. They are several options for breakfast outside the hotel; in the mall there is a McDonalds and Maison Kayser, and also Tully’s Coffee but all opened after 7:30am though. Many would agree that the Lawson (just round the bend of the lobby) is a plus as it is operating 24-hrs.. :>We like it's location with attached shopping mall and the best part is the airport limo stopping just outside the hotel. Overall our stay here has been good (apart from the long walk to station) and we are likely to come back again if the opportunity arises. :>

I was there with a group and we all stayed on to 20th floor. The rooms aren't large, but it was comfortable and quiet. Breakfast was quite good and and they have a family market shop on the ground floor. Also attached is the mall so plenty of options available. Close to Sun City streets and subway. Wifi was free but really bad for connections. In fact it's bad everywhere. Just a note, the lounge area doesn't allow eating or drinking. No other options available if you wanted to sit down with friends in lobby or restaurants.

We stayed there from September 11-20. 2013. group of 4. when we got in, we were given a room, without asking whether we wanted a non-smoking floor, obviously, if this was an option, we would have gone with the non-smoking floor, since we are not smokers ourselves.room was quite small. when i say small, i am not exaggerating. it looks like a room meant for 1 person and not for 2. location is nice since it is connected to a mall, where uniqlo and toys r us are located. but quite a hike to get to the train station. around 10-15 mins. depending on the level of exhaustion from the previous day, haha.staff was nice enough. rooms were clean.

It was my first time in Japan and I had quite high expectations based on the photo and their website. But the hotel room was too small for me and my hubby, low ceiling and quite tight for two. It was a promotion price maybe that’s why it is like that. It didn’t really matter since we are there not to stay whole day inside the hotel. What is nice about the hotel is that it is accessible to all and that’s the main goal why we chose it. It is attached to a shopping mall and some entertainment area and restaurants plus it is walking distance to the trains. It is also awake 24/7 and the hotel got its only convenience store. Overall we enjoyed our Japan trip and our stay was in the hotel was average.

Just spend few days with my kids to Tokyo. This is one of the Asian like hotel, as it quite close to down town, a lot of fun around, shopping, entertainment center, clip the dolls. a lot fun around. the best is the sunshine city, we spends 2 days for some entertainment & dumping what a nice holidays with family. For the hotel usual, a lot of Asian around, a convenient shop at lobby floor, room size as normal as Japan hotel, amenities really good use Aqua...... > i stay in 31 floor the city view fantastic. Room rate reasonable and the traffic convenience.

the location is awesome, inside sunshine city (so namja town, ice cream city, gyoza stadium and millions of shops) plus Sunshine Street and all the restaurants you want.short 5-10 minute walk to JR Ikebukuro East exit, the hotel room was extremely tiny, fitting just a double bed and small table and worlds smallest TV with not really any good channels to watch.laundry services expensive from hotel but there's a laundromat just a 10 minute walk which is self-serve and 24hrs which cost me 300 yen per wash.much better hotels for this same price closer to the JR.

Sunshine City Prince has a distinct advantage due to its location: there are few other buildings over 30 stories in the area, giving most rooms to the south of a view of the Shinjuku skyline. The rooms are small, but still have space for a double bed, desk and table. Also, the doors into the rooms and bathrooms might be a hazard for anyone over 6'2". The room was clean and the huge bottles of shower products were appreciated. The desk staff were friendly and spoke good English, which really helped check-in and check-out.The other advantage of the location is it's proximity to Ikebukuro station. There are tons of dining and shopping options in that area including the Seibu and Tobu department stores. If that isn't enough, take the JR line south to Shinjuku or Shibuya for more options.

The hotel is situated in Ikebukuro and near one of the major train stations. It is not new but is well maintained. The rooms are small but clean. It is Very accessible in a safe and secure location. Near restaurants, shops and convenience stores. I will stay here again.

I've been for one week at the Sunshine Prince Hotel.What was good: its position close (inside) a big shopping mall, shuttle bus from/to Narita airport. Clean rooms.What was not good: small rooms (I stayed at 31 floor), too small. Micro-TV, micro-table, micro-everything... no free Wi-Fi. Breakfast served in the 2 restaurants was poor, only japanese and chinese food. I like asian breakfast, but here it's too basic and of low quality compared to the hotel standards.

We stayed at Sunshine City Prince Hotel in July 2013 for two nights. The hotel's official website says that the hotel is just 8 minutes away from the JR Ikebukuro station, but our walk from the station was much longer than that - at least 20 minutes. The hotel isn't much nearer to the Metro station either. The place wasn't that easy to find, even though it's connected to the Sunshine 60 shopping mall. The furnishings in the room were quite old and the comforter on the bed was threadbare. The mattress was a little worn too so you could feel the bed springs underneath. While I could live with that at a youth hostel, I would've expected a better bed at a hotel. Nevertheless, the room was clean. There was supposed to be wifi in the lobby but we weren't able to access it even with the password provided by the hotel staff. The price of our stay wasn't high, and there are many shopping malls and eateries in Ikebukuro. But there are nicer hotels in the area for sure.

Arrived at midnight in hotel. Rooms quite good size and baths were also reasonable. Cleanliness is good overall. The gripe is the hotel lobby. So poorly furnished. Appearance appears tired looking. If the lobby can be spruced up to welcome its guest there will be a big difference

The hotel is in a good location connected to the sunshine city. Very clean. But very tedious Internet connection. Inthe rolf where Internet connection has to be in a jiffy it takes 8 passwords and 20 minutes of battle to get the connection. The breakfast was horrible

I remember this hotel as being one of the hottest properties when it first opened in 1980's. Sadly it still seems stuck in that time period and is badly in need of updating. Lobby is rather shabby. Rooms are clean, but furniture is worn. That said, the staff is extremely professional and well-trained (this is part of the Prince Hotel chain, after all). The location is great, as long as you don't mind walking about 10 minutes to nearest station (Ikebukuro). There is a 24-hour well-stocked convenience store on the ground floor, and many dining choices at the two adjoining malls. Clientele seems to be mostly tour groups from other Asian countries. There is an interesting small gift shop in the lobby catering to visitors from China. Lobby is a great place to sit and people-watch. I was able to check email on one of the coin-operated internet PCs there. 100yen for 10min of internet access plus free printing!On my next trip to Tokyo (I visit every other year) I'll stay at the Shinagawa Prince Hotel instead. That hotel is right across the street from the station, and has a spectacular buffet venue (Hapuna).

The room in this hotel was small, but sufficient. The breakfast food from the buffet was acceptable, but not delicious. Internet was wired in the room (wireless in the lobby). It was underwhelming to say the least, but not a bad utilitarian choice for a few day stay in Tokyo.

i like it's location with attached shopping mall and convenience store with airport limo stopping outside the hotel. You will find all those I just mentioned a blessing when you travel with young kids. However, it's quite a distance away to subway so need to walk a little. There are quite a fair bit of shopping stuff around the Ikebukuro JR station. The rooms are old but equipped with toiletries. Bed are too soft though. May stay there again this June 2013, hopefully we see some changes.

The hotel is rather dated and old, it's time for some renovation. Wifi is only available at lobby and the connection is terrible! Many hotel guests hang out at the lobby and the place is terribly noisy. The room is tiny by japanese standard and the furniture is rather old. Despite that, the breakfast buffet selection is quite good! Locatiom wise - close to shopping areas and lots of food around.... Would stay again? Maybe not.....

It was an old hotel. Do not even let me start with the bathrooms - it's like those found in trains. Anyway, despite the plain mustard colored small bathrooms, they were able to provide some amenities though and hot water. The hotel is in a good location. It even has a mall connected to it (the mall looks old either - nonetheless, perfect for strolling/not so urgent shopping if you're tired from walking in the city). Outside the hotel are shopping districts which has at least an ABC shoe mart in every corner! Just a few steps from the hotel was the Ikebukuro train station which is a neighbor to popular department stores. The breakfast buffet is so-so. They need to improve on their lobby though since most of the people connecting to the WiFi crowd it, they at least need to provide more sofas. Some guests have no choice but sit on the floor. They also need to maintain cleanliness of the rooms specifically the beds. I happened to take a look at the foam I was sleeping in and it had stains over it - good thing we were checking out after a few minutes.

Recently had a two night stay here in a “Semi-Double” room, which really was a large single. This is an another example of a bubble era hotel that really hasn’t seen any updates since it opened in the 90’s. The rooms were clean, but the furniture and walls, etc. were showing signs of age and looked original. Especially in the bathroom the plastics were discoloring and another example was the desk had the top veneer starting to delaminate from water damage. Sound insulation was good and actually had some good views from the room of the city. It looks like they are mostly marketing this place to Chinese budget tour groups due to the overall condition, which must be nicer than what they expect in China but for what you can find in Tokyo it’s on the rough side. For this part of Tokyo I was expecting better and it really needs a major remodel.One drawback to the hotels’ location is it’s a bit of a walk from the JR Station if you are lugging bags as you have to go through the busiest part of Ikebukuro- Sunshine Dori, and then through the bottom levels of Sunshine City to get to the hotel. It’s about 10-15 minutes of crowd dodging doing it the first time with luggage. Once there you do have tons of access for shopping and plenty of places to eat, but if you are planning to use this as a base for hopping around the city on the subway you might want to look closer to the station. It is in-between the Tokyo Metro Higashi-Ikebukuro station and the JR Ikebukuro station so it can give you some options to get around but it’s a walk to both. You can get to the Tokyo Metro through the 1st sub floor of Sunshine City (basically street level), its’ about 5-7 minutes through interconnecting walkways. Dining in the hotel I found the prices to be high, especially with all the options in the mall & just outside the hotel. The breakfast buffet was about 2200 yen per day if you didn’t get it in a package. I found several options for breakfast outside the hotel, in the mall there is a McDonalds and French bakery Maison Kayser that opens early, a higher end grocery store and a Tully’s Coffee in the mall, and just outside the south side by the expressway (door is by Maison Kayser) there is a Jonathan’s and a Caffe Veloce down the street toward the JR station, and a Seiyu (Wal-Mart) grocery store. You can see all of this on Google maps, it’s labeled.One thing to watch for if you booked through Hotels or Expedia. This is the second time where I’ve booked a non-smoking room through them and had it confirmed, but when I arrived they said the room was smoking. The first time the hotel quickly switched it back to non-smoking, but this time the Prince wouldn’t do it and kept insisting I made a smoking room reservation. I’m not sure if it’s due to issues in the two systems talking together and not translating the non-smoking properly, or the hotel switching room types due to the price since they usually get a higher rate for the non-smoking rooms adn sell rooms at a doscount to Hotels/Expedia. And this place looked to have a lot more smoking rooms so I think I got switched due to room price.Overall if you can get it at a good price it’s OK if you just want a basic room that’s not fancy, but if it’s higher priced than The B or The Metropolitan look elsewhere.

The hotel is next to Sunshine Shopping centre and Ikebukuro shopping areas. However, as I explored the city of Tokyo I realized that there are better hotels to choose from.Reasons why:* Some rooms are cramped. I felt there was not even adequate walking area in my room but some of my friends were checked in across the hallway and they had better rooms. Also my bathroom had a strong cigarette smell coming from the aircon which disappeared on Day 2 but was annoying.* Lobby is a disaster. Very shabby and concierge was not at desk at all times during my 3 day stay. It is filled with tourists in large groups checking in or out of the hotel, or with guests-in-residence who are down in the lobby to connect to wi-fi which is not available in rooms.* Location is okay but not exactly centrally located. It takes 10-15 mins to walk to the Ikebukura station via the shopping centre and not all of the walking distance is underground or covered. That can be a problem during rains/ snowfall.* The shopping centre has food court and a slew of restaurants but the nicer dining places in Tokyo for me were in and around Ginza / Shinjuku/ Roppongi.

Good location and excellent rooms. Had a fabulous view of Mt. Fuji on the first day stay. The lower two floors are connected to the Sunshine City shopping and Entertainment Mall. Easy to reach anywhere in Tokyo on the Yamanote line or Yuaracucho lines.

First times stayed here, next to a shopping centre, a tourist class hotel and a minimart next to the lobby.This is a tourist group kind of hotels, many tourist from asia are staying at this hotel, very good in term of location next to the mall.Consider as a normal standard size room in japan especially in a big city like tokyoShort walk to the subway underground station to connect you to all corner of tokyoModern facilities

This hotel is known to be contracted with some tours coming from Hong Kong, so you will always see lots of Hong Kong people around.I stayed once during my business trip, room is small, you could hardly find a space to open your luggage if it's a big one. The hotel itself is located at about 15mins walk from Ikebukuro JR Station, you can walk from underground malls extended from station but you could lost your direction easily! (I tried but I gave up eventually)As usual, only in-room cable internet is available for internet access, don't forget to bring your own broadband router or you'll have to bring your laptop to hotel lobby to surf internet.

This hotel is old and worn out. We got two rooms here. One of them, the bathroom reeked of urine so we asked for another room. The other room was stuffy, old, minimal air circulation due to ventilator/airco that hardly worked and a very noisy ancient fridge. The mattress was completely worn out with the springs already showing. The blanket has holes. This hotel seems to be for tour groups, so for those who have a choice, don't come here cause you'll be disappointed.
