Ying M
Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada

review_body: I been to this hotel few times since 2004 until 2010. My company will arrange this hotel for me to stay in. The reason why i believed is location. For a business trip this area is very near my partners company. I would like to say the hotel look a bit rundown... might need a new reno. to keep attract the customers. Near by got many restaurants you wouldn't be afraid noting to eat. Around 10 mins walking you can reach the train station, very convenience for travelers.

I stayed here on a business trip late in 2012.The rooms are quite old but clean and the suite we had was very spacious for Tokyo. It feels like a business hotel. The hotel is connected to the Sunshine City shopping mall, which has a decent range of restaurants(including mexican and subway for anybody chasing western food) and an aquarium and planetarium. It's obviously popular with families.There is also a subway station in the same complex, probably about a 500m walk from the hotel underground. Nearby there is a decent shopping and entertainment district - it's not the best place for shopping but has a few department and electronic stores, and plenty of restaurants including all the big chains. I would stay there again as I have friends in the area, but it's not in the greatest location in terms of really exploring Tokyo, it is probably good for a couple of days but then you would want to move on to another area.Good for business and families.

Having stayed here 10 years ago, the hotel is still the same now. Rooms are small, and old. However, the location compensated for it. It is just next to a shopping mall, and a short walk from the hotel will bring you to a busy street with shops like Tokyu Hands, many restaurants, & pharmacies. (Btw, pharmacies in Japan sells more than just medicine.)Do take note the mall & the shops closing time are early, between 8:30 to 9:00pm.

This hotel looked old. Very convenient location and room was clean.But they have no room service, no spa/fitness, no bar, and all restaurants are closed at 9pm. This hotel is right next to the shopping mall so there are restaurants there, but I arrived late and was tired so I didn't feel like to go out and eat.If you don't expect luxury hotel services, I recommend this hotel to go out for sightseeing or shopping.

Stayed here on my first trip to Japan more than a year ago. I was impressed that the room was pretty big for 2 guests! I stayed on the 26th or 27th floor and the view was excellent, especially in the morning. Rooms were clean, there was a 24hr convenience store in the lobby, and plenty of dining and shopping options at Sunshine City.However, walking to train station took about 15 minutes, and it might not be easy to navigate. But getting to and from the hotel from the airport was convenient on the Narita limousine bus (if a little pricey).Wifi was available only in the lobby, which sometimes caused crowding in the lobby areas, in addition to guests checking in.Overall, i would recommend this hotel if you don't really mind being a bit further from the hustle and bustle of the main city (Shibuya Shinjuku etc)

Location is amazing. The hotel is in Sunshine City, which is a huge shopping complex, so there is plenty to choose from to shop, eat and play (there's an aquarium, Namjatown - free admission for us with passports and room key, stage which we saw many boy/girl bands perform, etc). It's also connected to other malls (or so it seems), so you could just stay here if the weather was bad, etc. We had 3 adults and 2 small children, so we booked a triple occupancy room. Surprisingly, the room size was quite large (for Tokyo standards); probably what you would expect in a standard double sized suburban US hotel. The room had 2 double beds and a cot and there was still plenty of room for us. The bathroom is pint-sized...think of an airline bathroom x 2, if that, but functional. The sink was located outside the bathroom with a wall separating where the beds were, so that was nice (normally not my preference but with so many in one room, it was a plus). We booked a non-smoking room, and thankfully the room did not smell like smoke. The room seems like it was last renovated 20+ yrs ago...very tired, as many other reviewers have noted. The carpet was stained but the bathroom was clean. The beds...oy, the beds! They were hard, thin and I think I ended up bruising my right hip (I'm a side sleeper) after 3 nights on the mattress springs. The walls are thin too. With 2 young kids, we had to sleep early. The first 2 nights, it seemed like the guys next door were having a pretty great party as we could hear them cheering and shouting pretty late into the night (or so it seemed). There is no AC in December, so the first night was unbearably hot! Day temps running in the low 50's in the beginning of December. Turns out that the "fan" control in the room is for the heat only, during the winter, so either double-check with the front desk about temperature control or just leave it off. But it was annoying since there's no way to crack the windows so there was no air flow throughout the night. They actually give you an actually key for your room with the room number printed on it. As a former hospitality worker in the US, I was pretty horrified by this, but just be careful not to lose your key! I guess it's not much of an issue in Japan. We took the subway to the hotel, and it's not the easiest to find at first but once you know what andmarks to look for, it's fine. Walk towards the Toyota Amlux building if you are headed from the Ikeubukuro subway station since it is attached (see pic). Be mindful that Japanese maps often do not have North at the top of the map...it's quite disorienting, so you have to get your bearings based on landmarks. It's probably a good 15 min walk from the subway station, especially with luggage. You can also ask for the Tokyo Hands building in Ikeubukuro since the entrance to Sunshine City is right next door. It's much closer to the Higashi-Ikebukuro subway station (5 min walk) but it's on a different line and best to probably find the station from the hotel so you know how to get back. There is wired internet access available for free in the room. The hotel's website states it has free wi-fi in the lobby but I had problems accessing it and gave up. There is a FamilyMart in the lobby (ie: 7 Eleven), and it's a really great convenience. Try to find the Maison Kaiser (french bakery) in Sunshine City...it is amazing. The croissants, apple tarts, etc are delicious. I have to say that the Japanese sure do know how to make French pastries. I definitely had my fill while in Japan...and then some! Definitely also try to get lunch in the basement of the Seibu department store (where the Ikebukuro sugway station is located) or any of Tokyo's department stores. There's no tables to sit at but you can find chairs. The "food hall" is amazing, there's so much to choose from. Bottom line...would I stay here again? Due to location, yes (it's really all the hotel has going for it). But otherwise, no.

For starters, this hotel is located right across a driving school. Anyone in dire need to drive in Tokyo would appreciate it ;))That aside, the hotel reception area is unusually packed with airport-sized trolleys at first sight. Not something you would like to see on your vacation as it gives the impression that the hotel is disorganised. It was a relief that the staff speaks English and were helpful with your requests. Especially with my limousine booking back to the airport. They put me on a high floor and its only a while later that I realised vibrations are most intense during an earthquake when you are at the top most of a building.Furnishings are simple and there are only tea cups, in which making a piping hot cup of Milo is not possible. WC is wonderful with bidet attached plus a warm seat included.Overall, this hotel is excellent if your expectations are not too high. With the Sunshine 60 shopping centre next to it, you can while your time away with many eateries around. However, the nearest Ikebukuro train station is at least a 15-20mins walk away so do plan your trip well if you are using the subway.

We stayed there for 3 nights with 1 twin, 1 double and 1 single room. Compare to previous hotels that I stayed, Sunshine city would be a bit far away from JR - around 10 to 15mins walk. If you are taking Narita Express or Skyliner from airport it will be a bit of a challege to get to the hotel and especially if you have your heavy luggage on the last day.The price of the hotel is reasonable so the room is expecetd to be small as usual. They have wifi connection in the lobby area only. And there is a 24 hours family mart at the lobby so quite convenient. But if I travel to Tokyo again, I will prefer to stay at Shinjuku area which I find easier to get around with JR.

First it is really convenient. Easy walk to "JR" and Got airport bus stop at the hotel cos not many hotels get it. Second, it up above the big shopping mall you will be very busy shopping even after yr whole day out. One Whole floor of the mall is all "Food" got many choices, we had really good japanese food there! Reasonable Price.Beside that, near the hotel have a 24hrs supermarket!!Love it!!If you want free "WIFI" it only can connect at the Lobby, you need a password. "ask the staff.You also can request wifi connection in your room but only few floors they do that.(so ask when you book yr room)AC not too strong........ how ever if you plan leaving also by the airport bus, you must book at the reception desk one or two days before!!!

I enjoyed the single room I stayed over a week ago. The rate is very reasonable, the room is clean and spacious. The view from the 28th floor is wonderful, specially at night. The service is of typical Japanese courtesy and efficiency which is not always the case in other countries I travelled. I also like its convenient location to a huge mall which is also clean and bright.

Joined a group tour to Japan and stayed at Sunshine City Prince for 5 days . Good location with convenient super mall at basement. 5 minutes walk from the Ikebukero train station; a major hub for many lines. House keeper is diligent,maybe from China and Philippines.

We stayed 2 nights at Sunshine City Prince, a reasonably good hotel conveniently located in the city. It has 30 plus floors and over 1000 rooms. The hotel does not pretend to be above its class as evident by its simple, basic and clean lobby. A large percentage of its business is derived from conducted tour groups, so do expect a busy and crowded lobby. Although our rooms were small, but at least there were clean with comfortable bed. Our rooms had a wonderful view of the city. Perhaps the best selling point for this hotel is its location. It is located within 5-10 mins walk from Ikebukuro station, next to shopping mall called Sunshine City, and a 24-hour Seiyu supermarket is to be found behind the building. Exit the hotel front entrance, turn right and walk around 10-15mins, one would find Ikebukuro station as well as big departmental stores such as Seibu, Loft and Parco. Many smaller shops and restaurants are to be found in this area. Take the opportunity to visit MacDonald just opposite Seibu and try a pork burger (unique product as not many of their branches actually have this on their menu). If convenient is the key in choosing a hotel, then look no further then Sunshine City Prince.

Joined a group tour to Japan for 5 days and stayed at Sunshine City Prince for 2 nights. The hotel is big and busy with over 1000 rooms. We stayed in a standard twin room on 22nd floor. The room's small but clean and well equipped with all necessary amenities. The best thing about this hotel is its convenient location. 24-hr convenient store on the hotel lobby and also 24 hour SEIYU supermarket within easy walking distance. It's also only a few minute walk from various department stores, and train station.

I have stayed at this hotel 4 times over the last 6 years. Its getting a little tired now and I will look elsewhere next time. The twin rooms are very small and the room furnishings are looking pretty worn. It has over a thousand rooms but its a dumping ground for large tour groups. The ONLY good thing about this hotel is its location. Situated just 5 minutes walk from the Ikebukero train station; a major hub for many lines. it is also only minutes from the huge Seibu and Tobu department stores. In addition it is located right next to Sunshine City, a huge shopping centre and it has a wonderful 24 hour supermarket across the road where you can buy the nicest freshly prepared food and heat it up in the microwaves provided. So if you can stand the rooms being small and on the dingy side; and you didn't pay too much, it does have advantages.

Stayed 6 days this April 2012. The room and bathroom smell musky, beds and carpet had seen better days. Elevators is like riding the subway or train during rush hours except you had to squeeze between luggages too.There are no frills or service to talk about at this hotel and I would leave it at that. The only saving grace for this hotel is its close proximity to restaurants, shops and Ikebukuro station about a good 5 to 8 minutes walk.

Stayed here in April 2012. It was a good stay for 2 nights. The hotel has 24/7 mini mart at basement. Next door is a big department store. There are many nice places such as wine shop, fashions and restaurants.The restaurant at basement has great buffet. Steak, Sushi, King Crab and desserts.If you like Tokyo, stay here for convenient and you can spend the rest of your time for traveling in Tokyo.PS. the room is small as everybody mentioned but it has everything you needed, shampoo, toothbrush, even a razor and shaving cream are free.

Coming from the Ikebukuro station, look for signs to "Sunshine" which is the mega complex that the hotel is located in and get out at Exit 35. Cross the road and walk along Sunshine 60 which is a pedestrian walkway with lots of shops and restaurants and people blaring sales pitches from megaphones. Enter Sunshine City and ask for directions to the Sunshine City hotel entrance which is located inside the shopping complex. The rooms are small and basic but cheap, clean and comfortable. We stayed on the 23rd floor which has an excellent view of the cityscape at night. There is free wifi only in the ground lobby. Being part of the Sunshine City complex, do take the elevator up to the 58th/59th floor - it's very fast and quite an experience, and there are cafes/wine bars/restaurants on the top floors.

Hotels in Tokyo can cost you a bundle so we jumped at the Sunshine City Prince price. $140 per night, sure we'll take it! The hotel is located about 1 km from the Ikebukuro train station. Great location! If you are heading there for the first time I would recommend taking a taxi, for 710 yen it will get you there without any problems. The hotel is close to the station but trying to find it for the first time could be challenging. After our initial taxi ride we chose to walk to and from the train station. There is a big shopping area located very close to the hotel. Lots of shops and restaurants! First impressions of the hotel, is this a storage locker?! Seriously there was luggage everywhere in the lobby. The hotel is outdated and needs serious renovations but overall it was clean, not super clean but clean enough. You get what you pay for. Breakfast was not included but there was a few restaurants located inside the hotel as well as a Family Mart (convenience store.) We bought quite a few sandwiches and some drinks at the Family Mart. The staff was very friendly and overall the service was good, much like everywhere else in Japan! For the price, its worth it! I would hope that they would update soon though!

Decent hotel. Only problem was I had requested 2 single beds for me and my mate and when we got there it was a double bed! The hotel staff told me the hotel was fully booked which I found hard to believe as there were not that many people about. I asked to speak to the manager and he magically found us a different room with 2 single beds after checking my booking and confirming I did ask for this. Hard work! The hotel is park of a shopping centre which isnt as bad as it sounds. There is no noise or any other problems. There is a good little shop beside the hotel which is handy too! We hired a car (hotel has reduced rate underground parking which is good) and could not understand the japanese sat nav but a good tip is enter the hotel phone number into the sat nav (under the picture of the phone) and it will take you straight there! Smart bit of technology the UK dont have. I googled the phone numbers of everywhere we wanted to go like Fuji Mountain after that and it worked a treat. :)

Given this price, in Tokyo, the quality of the room has already exceeded my expectation. The room is clean and not so small. Walkable distance to the JR station. This is a huge hotel with over 1,000 rooms. However, the main entrance is located inside the shopping mall which is not easy to find.

We chose this hotel because we managed to book it at a discount and it did not disappoint us overall. Generally, staff were friendly and helpful. There were a few fluent English speaking staff at the front desk. We had a room for 3 adults on the 29th Floor. There were two single beds (large) and one rollaway. Room size was big enough to accommodate all of us. It would be good if the hotel could change the curtain in the room - looked worn out!! Bathroom ceiling was low though for those who are tall. Don't expect to have normal size bath tub here - it's small. Only green tea is given in the room. No coffee provided. There was free wifi at the lobby area and limited to 30 mins per use but hotel staff were able to increase usage time when we approached them. There are a few paid computer kiosks at the lobby - 100Yen for 10 minutes. Airport limousine bus stops right in front of the hotel, so is pick up. You can book and buy your limousine ticket at the hotel. There is a Family Mart near the hotel lobby and a supermarket (Seiyu) at the South Entrance of Sunshine City. Burger King, McDonalds and other eateries can be found at Sunshine City.. It took us about 10-15 minutes to walk to/from Ikebukuro Station. Lots of things to see along the way. The station itself is huge with many exits and there are departmental stores and shops linked to this station. So for those getting down at Ikebukuro Station, make sure you know which exit to take.I will hesitate to stay here again for my next visit.

This hotel has everythin' u wud want when choosin' a hotel. 1stly: it's huge!. Stayed @ the 38th floor & there's more!. Rooms r clean but can be small, so be sure to book the deluxe rooms tt r bigger. The only setback is tt the windows r sealed & the air can get staled coz the airflow is a little weak. Fyi, this was in Dec(winter time). Well furnished supermart on the ground fl. tt's abt 20 steps fm the elevator!. Rests r located on the ground & basement. Staff r friendly & helpful. 2ndly: Another 30 paces fm the supermart, u'll find yrself enterin' a shoppin' centre wz lots of great food rests!!. The shoppin' centre offers a wide variety of interests like shoes, clothin', cafes, rests, souvenirs, bookstore & so forth. On the other end of the shoppin' centre is an office bldg. 3rdly: Out fm the bldg, across the road, there're lots of eateries & shoppin' centres. Quite a number of gd ramen & bento rests tt open till late. 4thly: the main station - Ikebukero is located here. It's basically a straight walk once u cross the road fm the shoppin' bldg into Ikebukero. I wus estimate a leisure 12-15 mins walk. This stretch of road is jam packed durin' peak hrs right up till abt 9pm!. Fm Ikebukero station, u can move on to other places of interests like Disneyland & Shinjuku. Needless to say, the shoppin' centre abv the station is awesome!. Lots of gd buys fm the basement where the pastries, cakes & so forth r sellin' like hot cakes to both the locals & foreigners(read as tourists) alike!.Almost every nite, it's packed!. Lastly, u can catch the bus fm the hotel entrance to the a/port!. What u nid to do is to book in advance @ the main counter upon check in.So, I wud say, this hotel has abt everythin'. Wud surely stay in this hotel again, ie., if I'm in Ikebukero!.Cheers!.

Overall, it is such a nice hotel because of its reasonable price.After the unfortunately and shocking disaster arose in Japan, many hotel+flight packages was being promoted with the big sale prices.We stayed in the semi double room(1 double bed), the size is hardly enough for 2 persons and our stuff. (we had bought tons of stuff in this shopping trip)The room is clean and tidy, I espeacilly appreciate the neating skill of the hotel staff, since every morning we had turned the room as a dump and they can fix it up.And also they provide a disinfecting spray in each room and it smell good, green tea flavour.I try to have bath with some hot spring bath powder in the bathroom, but the ventilation system is terrible, i thought i could died for this reason.One more thing, the view from our room is nice, as my friend had requested for staying on a higher floor.

I got this hotel deal with flight via a travel agency. Here are what you probably should know:1) no free internet. Actually, most places don't have free internet. This was one of the main complaint for Tokyo. You can pay for the use of internet or computer with the hotel counter.2) There are tons of shopping drug store types open late near the JR station. They open about 8 or 8:30am all the way to about 10 or 10:30pm. 3) There is a Japanese version of Walmart called 24 hour SEIYU about 2 minutes walk from the hotel. It is on the back side of the Prince Hotel, you can get to it by cross through the Sunshine City Mall.http://www.seiyu.co.jp/shops/detail/00000139/4) The beds are soft, small, and not perfect. But when we booked the room, they already told us the bed is full sized bed. 5) There is free mini-fridge in the room to use as well.6) The room is clean though, and the staff is nice. 7) The airport limousine from Haneda stops right at the front door for 1200yen/person/way. Overall for what we paid for, this is very good deal. I would recommend this hotel to people as well just because the location.

This hotel could use some updating. The lobby is especially tired looking and lacking in seating. The service, however, was quite good during our stay. Our room was small, but workable and it had a nice view of the city. The bathroom was one of those modular units stuck in the corner of the room; it had nice amenities, a deluxe toilet and a very small tub. The included breakfast buffet had a very large selection of Japanese and western food.The hotel is a pleasant 10-15 minute walk from Ikebukuro train station, and is also connected by underground walkway to the Higashi Ikebukuro subway station. The hotel is also directly connected to the Sunshine City complex; you have access to tons of dining, shopping and entertainment options without ever stepping into the open air. The surrounding area has additional shopping, dining and entertainment (mostly arcades). Ikebukuro probably isn't the ideal location for touring Tokyo, but we found a lot to like about it.

We have stayed at the hotel from 30 June to 4 July 2011 and the following will be our feedback:a. The room - old, dated, small, compact, average room cleanliness and poor air-conditioning (very warm until we have to room change). b. Bedding - Panorama floors has new bedding from Simmons and it is comfortable. The only thing that the management should look into is to have a separate bed cover and duvet for hygiene reason as I noticed the duvet in my room has blood stain.c. Hotel facilities - Very basis. There is a 24 hours Family Store and coin operated internet access at main lobby. Spa service is also available.d. Location - About 15 min walk from Ikebukuro subway. Alone the way, there is lots of F & B outlets and shopping center such as Parco, Seibu, LV etc.Overall, the hotel is old and don't expect too much on service.

Larger than normal hotel rooms for a Japanese brand hotel. Check in counter and bell services were never busy and easily accommodated our group. Breakfast was nice and even with current power saving measures AC worked just fine. It was about a 12-15 minute walk to Ikebukuro Station but it was a nice walk past a ton of shops, eateries, and amusements. Within the complex is the giant Sunshine City Mall with even more shops, eateries, and amusements. I agree with others that the hotel is showing its age a bit, but it was still clean and great especially for the location and price. Note that the hotel does still use old fashioned 'keys' and gives only one out per room, this can be a bit of a hassle if you're pairing up with a roommate or have different plans than your friends or family.

Not the best for easy access, as the underground railway station is 15 mins away from hotel and requires crossing the road a few times, but rooms are not too expensive and offer satisfactory comfort. The staff struggles with English, but do their best to explain things and provide you with equipment (like electric adapters). The window is big and offers a good view of the city of Tokyo, but unfortunately cannot be opened. The toilets, while not high-end for Japanese standards, are equipped with several electronic features, which we Europeans found amusing. There are many conference rooms and restaurants on the ground floor, and for breakfast you can choose between Western and Japanese food in a self-service buffet.
Friendly staff, comfortable stay and convenient. Hotel is only a stone's throw from Ikebukuro Station. Clean rooms.

Just come back from Tokyo and stayed at this hotel. Firstly, the location is superb, close to JR line and metro station, it is inside a shopping mall so it is a plus for those "shop till you drop" type. Now, the negatives : the hotel is old, the lobby is crowded and tired, personally that won't affect me much as long as it is clean. The worst part is the bed, it sinks in the middle, like when you lie down, your back are pulled inside the concave area, very uncomfortable and cause back aches the next day. Next the heater in the room is way too hot, I have to call the front desk every night to request them to lower the temperature and sometimes, I have to call twice before they understand my request, and even after the supposed lower temperature has done, I still feel suffocate and couldn't sleep well. Lastly, you have to pay 100yen for the use of wifi computer at the lobby for online check in is sooooo "Cheap act"...

The location of the hotel is good with the shopping complex right at your door step. Food choices are plentiful just a short walk away, explore the various alleys for better food deals than those along the main shopping stretch. I really like the shopping in the Ikebukuro area, spent two days walking and did not cover all the shops the area had to offer. The room was clean but small with terrible a terrible bed that has seen better days, we were in a semi-double. The heater was way too hot and we had to make several calls to the front desk to lower the temperature practically every night we were there. The air-conditioning system kept sending cigarette smoke from other rooms into our room and that had me doubling my allergy medication but other than that it was okay. I had requested for rooms on the higher floors but was given the 17th floor, it was decent with the walls a tad thin and I could hear conversations from neighbouring rooms.

This hotel is celebrating it's 30th anniversary, and one can tell that are few renovations in order. The rooms are decent sized, but furniture and layout is quite outdated. The beds are like cardboard, very uncomfortable. The air-conditioning is old and works only on low setting. The walls are extremly thin, you can hear conversations from next door. This hotel is 25+ story high, probably 2000+ rooms. It is very popular with Asian tour groups. The hotel is connected to the Sunsheine city mall, with a food avenue/starbucks/mcdonald's/burger king downstairs, 10 minute walk to JR Ikebrukuro station.

My main gripe would be the hotel bed. One look and you can tell it sinks in the middle. This is a common gripe among my other colleagues as well. when you sleep on it, you can sometimes feel the coils within!the hotel rooms are really due for an upgrade. Location is good, 5-10 mins to JR Yamanote line, and there is a 24 hour supermkt nearby. But i would not come to this hotel again

I booked this hotel because it was cheaper compare to other hotels on west side of Tokyo and the room was bigger(as it was superrior room, 29 sqm). The other hotels with low price were the Grand Prince Asakasa, Shinagawa Prince and Tokyo Prince (near Tokyo tower) but the location of Ikebukuro was the best so I chose this hotel. It was also a brand hotel. When I arrived at lobby, it looked so small, not enogh for hotel with rooms more than thousands. The only thing that really renovated were the elevators. All the other facilities were old. At first when I checked in, there were three beds which didn't match to what we need so we changed the room to the upper floor, 28th. The view from the room was okay. Can see the skyscrapers in Shinjuku Area. The furnitures and decoration were also dated. The nearest subway station was Higashi Ikebukuro on Yurakucho line , 3 min walk from the hotel. The JR and subway Ikebukuro Station took about 15 min of walking, walking passed Sunshine 60 street and many department stores.) The hotel was connected to old shopping mall, Sunshine City, but the things in the mall was cheap.Only some staffs are friendly. No one can really speak English well.

I really love this hotel because there is so much shopping, amusement and restaurants in the area. I have to admit that the walk to Ikebukuro station is a little on the far side since it takes about 15 minutes to walk down the long street with plenty of shops and through the maze of the Sunshine City. Rooms are a little shabbier and sufficient for sleep and storing luggage. I still find lots more benefit and can live with the cons. The location is the reason that I keep going back to this hotel.
Good location with many shopping linking to the Hotel within Sunshine City.There is super market & Seiyu nearby as well. Hotel room is not very big though but comfortable.
very small rooms, you can not open a window, no internet in lobby, very slow help desk service, poor English

This is an older property and is not in the best location for touring Tokyo -- the surrounding Ikebukuro area is a fairly drab railway terminal without much of particular interest. That said, it's one of the best deals you can get for a full-service hotel within the Yamanote Line, and as long as you're willing to ride a train for 15 minutes to get somewhere you'll be fine here.

As A first-timer to Japan, I was nervous about communication, eating and most importantly accomodation. We got to the hotel with a bus route from the Narita Airport straight to the doors, the staff are friendly and pleasant and booking in was quick and pain-free. Although we didn't eat at the hotel directly, there is a small shop located on the bottom floor where we could get food for an early breakfast and as it is part of sunshine city, a large indoor mall/shopping centre, it was very easy to get food at any other time. However, because it is a shopping centre and a convenience, the prices (in my opinion) were slightly higher than other local areas.Travelling was very easy, a 5 minute walk down two roads to the local train station which is clearly signposted in Japanese and English.
